Among other things we ordered the ceasar salad, and it was the best we've eaten in a long time. It was such a positive experience, we wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to anyone.

Personally I think this is the best restaurant in Vung Tau.
Nice atmosphere.
Very nice French & Spanish dishes.

My partner and I visited this restaurant in early February of this year but did not post it until now so that I could reflect on my experience. It was a disappointing evening in so many ways, Gambo prawns starter very good apart from the potato/ croutons that were rock hard and inedible. The main was a seafood linguine that we both ordered which was packed with an abundance of fresh produce. However there was a distinct taste and smell that was not pleasant. We both could not eat it and returned both dishes explaining to the waitress our reasons. We asked for the bill to leave quickly and quietly. We were offered an alternative but did not want to continue as we had lost confidence in the venue. The bill came with no reduction whatsoever. This was followed by the (French) chef who handled the situation very badly. He was clearly affronted by our opinion of his dish and made out it was us not his freshly prepared dish that was the problem as no one had complained before. In my 60 years I have only sent back 2 previous dishes as I would rather eat and not return (Iâ€™m not a complainer) I told him I was prepared to pay the majority of the bill and left 65% of the total (only because I had no change) I stood to leave but was blocked from vacating the booth by the chef. He reluctantly moved and we left. This was not pleasant for either us or the other customers. Clearly this chef does not like criticism. Needless to say we will not return or recommend this restaurant.
Brilliant restaurant, everyone should come for great service and brilliant food
French food were so good. They have an excellent pumpkin cream with duck breast. But the cocktail is so so.
Cozy place, good food, beautiful presentation!  But it's hot, the air conditioner in the hall can't cope!

we really enjoyed our food here. garlic butter mussels, sautÃ©ed potatoes and duck breast with pumpkin mash.. everything was tasty and well-cooked.

the staff were polite and efficient. there was a small mistake on the bill but they fixed it right away and gave us some complimentary shots. also, my girlfriend left her card at the restaurant and the staff were prompt in phoning her to let her know and then arranging a grab delivery to our next location, which was super helpful.

one area of improvement would be the ambienceâ€”i like the interior but the layout, music and dining style donâ€™t really mesh so well. the music in particular felt out of place and overly loud.

also, they should stop advertising sapporo draft offers on every table if they donâ€™t sell sapporo draft, so that people like me donâ€™t end up with bottled beer they donâ€™t want. my partner loved her cocktail though.
The food tastes great. I recommend you try ðŸŒŸ

Lovely place to get some western food. Came from Can Tho just to have several items from their menu. No complains. Everything was good. I even had a privilege to have my pet come in with me. Keep up with the good job guys â™¥ï¸
Great restaurant great food great service , Nhi  was great she has super friendly and helpful
Fantastic steak by chef Ben and excellent service by Than!
Cute little place, delicious food and great service. I had the chicken penne and it was yummy!!
A proper restaurant with a tasty menu and options. Tuna tartar was super delicious but the tuna steak was not very good. Dry and hard. It was too cold inside. Will come again to try some meat.
I wanted to eat escargot what i've eaten in paris but totally different. Even workers were busy to close the restaurant at 9:50 pm. It seemed like they acted to kick off the customers asap.
Amazing food and great service. I will come back this nice restaurant for sure.

My friend and I were yesterday. What can I say, the interior is great. The waiters are very nice and fast. From food we ordered 5 dishes. PORK TIRRINE - is delicious, The duck is excellent cooked, but the mushrooms, mush potatoes and goat cheese salad were terrible.

There are four stars because the food is quite good. The menu is limited which is a good sign that they have a focus on quality.  However three simple things would have improved my experience.

Firstly it was ridiculously hot so perhaps a glass/jug of ice-cold water on the table.

Secondly I donâ€™t mind waiting for food but why not send the breadbasket out before the meal.

Finally, seeing the owner/chef smoking in his own restaurant is really disappointing.

Would I go back? Maybe.

Been a frequent visitor for 4 years. But after changing the menu, alas, I no longer want to return. Always took salads, portions were large and excellent sauce. Now portions have been reduced by 30-40%, prices have risen. Tuna tartare is also delicious, but the portion is reduced by 50%. Too bad, it was one of the few restaurants I went to. Now, alas, my path to him is closed.
Food was amazing! The fondant was a standout, service was very punctual and the staff spoke very good English. The restaurant was very clean as well. Canâ€™t fault it 10/10

Great meal and service.

We ordered the duck breast which was cooked to the finest perfection, complement with the saute potatoes.

Next, beef burgundy was an excellent dish from the chef with a moist and tender cut of beef.

The wine, was not an excellent choice the food we ordered.

Overall, the food at Don Quijote has given us different surprises like how Don Quijote in his journey under Miguel's words.

We did not expect these kind of dishes came from the bistro in the corner of VT city.

The best restaurant in Vung Tau. Great european food (meat or fish) and great presentation of the dishes. Very professional staff and a really nice environment with a high level of hygiene.

I highly recommend it
We only had a quick early evening meal, but the prawn and tuna salads just perfectly hit the mark for us.

Me and my friend had a lovely time. Food was amazing, dessert was amazing and the person taking care of us (Nelly) was lovely to chat to, also very attentive and light-hearted. Thanks to Donquijote for doing everything right â€”a lovely experience.

Must have when you are in Vung Tau. The seafood paella is top notch, burger and creamy penne pasta wonderful.

Overall a lovely experience dining here.
I had a good afternoon at Don Quijote. People were very  friendly and the dishes were quite nice
Food ok, however french fries where  terrible, i could not eat it. Beer from the tap and service was very good.

Loved everything we had at Don Quijote's so much we had to return (and if we had stayed in Vung Tau longer we would have been back multiple times). The menu isn't extensive, but each item is done to perfection. The owner is very nice and dedicated to providing great meals. We'll definitely be back.

The food was delicious. We tried seafood paella - yum! Lamb chops were juicy! Tuna on veggies ratatouille - amazing! Even simple stewed veggies were well seasoned and tasty! Totally recommend this place!
Awesome place, great atmosphere. great menu of southern France and northern Spain. Green mussel soup is just worth michelin star level. Meat is outstanding. Have to try for a great evening.
Lamb chops are juicy. The food is perfect for me. They use natural day light so my food photos are too white and miss some bounce lights. Suggest to turn on interior lighting for better ambiance.

Ate here around 8 months ago and well satisfied and put a 5 star review

Went back for dinner 23 April 2023 and extremely disappointing.  The cold plater and cheese was 250,000 VND and it was miniscule, maybe enough as a starter for a 10 year old. Very expensive. Don't mind paying for quality but this it was not.

I came back twice in 1 day! I had seabass and prawn/mango salad, 2 desserts (creme brule & chocolate fondant) and an Old-Fashioned cocktail. Tasty food, awesome desserts and very friendly French (?) chef. Love it and will keep coming back.
Delicious food. All the dishes we ordered were delicious. Probably the best burger Iâ€™ve had in Vietnam. The restaurant is also very clean and the staff is friendly.
Great place to come back anytime we visit Vung Tau
Exceptional customer service & great food.
The waitress Thanh gives an amazing service in both Vietnamese and English! Good is splendid
very nice food. new place have good decoration. Owner friendly

New, clean restaurant, but lacks atmosphere; lighting too bright, chairs not so comfy, service 'distant'.
Food is nice, tasty and a little pricy, some dishes on the menu were not available.
Really high quality restaurant.  Fresh ingredients a wide menu with interesting well put together dishes with reasonable pricing.  The paella is a great dish to share.
Great food, decently cheap. However, my lamb was amazingly bland, almost as if they forgot to season it. The sauce was bland as well. Other than that, it was a great experience.

A very nice real Spanish atmosphere: Wooden (wine) barrels with high wooden bar stools, white-washed walls, pictures from Spain on the walls (San FermÃ­n - the running of the bulls, La Giralda - The cathedral of Sevilla with its 2 towers, wind mills - the molinos of Don Quijote), wooden tables with high chairs .... I felt a bit homesick.
The menu is extensive, as well meat as fish. I had tuna salad for starters, rib-eye as second dish. The salad was really good, tuna is quite dry, normally, but not here. The rib-eye was superb. This is obviously a cook who understands cooking, and loves his profession.
Highly recommended ðŸ‘ ðŸ‘ðŸ‘ðŸ‘.
Hidden gem. Air conditioned. Superb food. Very reasonably priced. Excellent service.
bellissimo! Our food was mega

A fantastic dinner: the food here is delicious, great menu, all fresh and very good service.

This is a high end French restaurant. I have no complain and food is delicious. The price is a bit high end but you get what you pay for. It just fantastic food.
Toulouse sausages and the Tagliatelle pasta are two of my favorites. Also, the basque style chicken is good. Some like the goat cheese salad.
Delicious duck burger and we also share the tuna steak. Proper good honest food with exciting twists. Highly recommend!!!

Genuine French Cuisine with heavy Spanish influence. Helmed by French man Ben , one can't get more authentic than that here in Vung TÃ u.  In addition prices are very reasonable for such haute cuisine
AMAZING FOOD!!!! One of the best I have had ever. Simple but so well done and so full of flavor. You have to come and try. I highly recommend

Food is very good. Best western food in Vung Tau.

Amazing place for the good steak and cocktails. You can spend here hours enjoying your time. Also got cheese plate. It was very good quality.
Totally recommended and very friendly!

It was a mix of feelings, much like the place itself. Was it French, Spanish, or American? The menu featured seafood paella, burgers, American-style dÃ©cor, and even duck confit. The beef patty was cooked to the wrong temperature, and when we sent it back, the buns were simply re-toasted instead of preparing a fresh burger. From a decent restaurant, I would have expected a properly cooked, brand-new burger instead.
The service staff was good, 5 stars , but the kitchen hands had much room for improvement.

*. I requested a medium-cooked patty, but it arrived closer to medium-rare, with blood oozing out and soaking the patty. When I sent it back to be corrected, it returned overcooked, with hardened buns.

After more than 2 years I returned to my once favourite restaurant in Vung Tau ... and it's even better! New central location, with a great atmosphere, complimented by excellent food at absurdly reasonable prices. Local tip, finish your meal off with a glass of Cupito!
I gave four stars on the food as my Chicken Cordon Bleu was a little overdone, but mussels from NZ in cream sauce were heavenly as an appetiser.

A nice western restaurants with seemingly many foreign regulars. The waiter is professional and the service is great so that it feels like a fine restaurant. I came in thinking about getting their pasta, but the waiter told me their main thing is the fish and meat, so I changed my mind and got pan fried sea bass. They have todayâ€™s special menu, so I picked one from there as well. I have had better sea bass dish in this country, but the portion is pretty big here, so I think itâ€™s a good value. The ravioli had foie gras in it and that was pretty good, but their cheese cake is like a hard cheese cake that makes you thirsty, so that was not really my thing. The main chef here is French and this is a pretty nice good western restaurant overall.

The food and wine was good. The amount for the price is small, and it was a bit undercooked. We made a reservation ahead of time, but the staff weren't prepared at all when we arrived. Service was extremely slow. I understand that Sunday can be busy, but it should be something that the restaurant is prepared for. Other customers ordered after us and received food before us, so it's possible that our order was originally forgotten. Overall, for the price, there are better options available.

Went for afternoon lunch with my family. Very good service. Our waitress was fast and very attentive.
The food was magnificent.  We ordered from across the menu to get the maximum flavour profile. The portions were very generous and the flavours were spot on.
Thank you, a lovely experience.

The food was the damn good. European style. Absolutely delicious! The service wasn't perfect, but wasn't bad either. The atmosphere ainâ€™t bad. Wait till after sundown and get a table upstairsâ€¦.very nice. Given what they had to work with, I don't think I could offer any suggestions to improve the atmosphere. The kitchen appeared the most professional kitchen I've seen in Vietnam. There were 4 or so 'Chef's', and they were using a variety of pots/ bowls will preparing orders. Also stove tops and oven. It sure appeared to me that detail was of great priority. The dish presentation was flawless. AND EVER DISH WAS SERVED AT THE SAME TIME. Scattered dish arrival is so common in Vietnam, and this restaurant allowed the whole table to enjoy a fabulous meal together. We had a party of 4 and every thing set on table was enjoyed, nothing left, and no hunger after the meal....decent portion size! I'm planning another trip to this city for the expressed desire to eat there again.
And I have returned. Took a ferry from HCMC for the expressed desire for another meal. LOVED it. Worth it. I do not hesitate to recommend this joint. Have dinner here, I doubt youâ€™ll be disappointed.
Plan on leaving a tip here.

This is the 3rd time we've been here and each time we have left super happy. The food and service is fantastic. Big up to our waitress who not only remembered us but was also super attentive. The owner is kind and generous. The price is absolutely correct for the quality and we are really happy that this is the representation of French / Basque culture in Vietnam. Bravo ðŸ‘
Great food and service, value to money. Highly recommend

First time here and I was very happy with the service. The therapist was skilled and knew exactly where to focus. The space was quiet and tidy, perfect for relaxing. The food is great, exceptionally good at reasonably price. However, when come at dinner time the place can get quite noisy as it is really popular and crowed. The food was forgotten by the kitchen a lot when this happen, thus can create a somewhat disappointing when eaten.

Tips: come in the afternoon for good food and service

The food here is delicious, staff are friendly, efficient and enthusiatic. Food will be served in no time after orders are placed, which is certainly a plus point for those in a hurry, the others may feel pushed if they want to pick their own pace. The restaurant is newly opened but the service and food quality are very good, the restaurant space is spacious and clean, the dishes are served quickly, the staff is attentive, the food is reasonably priced, fresh and delicious, suitable for my family's taste. If you go to Phuoc Hai embankment, try this restaurant, it is right in the center, convenient to go near the beach. My personal feeling is very satisfied.
The restaurant cooks delicious food, fast, reasonable price, fresh seafood, seafood restaurant but clean floor, tables and chairs, clean restroom with air conditioning, overall satisfied.

Newly opened, clean restaurant, no other restaurant in the embankment area has a clean toilet like this one - has air conditioning and music. Fresh food, not cheap compared to other restaurants and Vung Tau. You should choose this restaurant if you want a clean, polite place to sit.

Rate 5 stars to support. There are 2 suggestions:
- Working in the kitchen, there is no such thing as throwing away grouper stomach
- Need a waiter to pick up ice for customers
Clean toilet with air conditioning. Fresh food, enthusiastic service, clean and comfortable seats with sea view. Price is okay, not high, grilled oysters with scallion oil 79k/10 oysters.

The store has a spacious, airy space, especially the restrooms are extremely clean, this is a big plus for the dining experience.
About the food: seafood porridge is okay but not too special.
Highlights include steamed snails and snails with salted egg sauce - the snail meat is sweet, chewy and crispy, with rich sauce flavor, very worth trying. Steamed shrimp and salted egg shrimp are also excellent, the shrimp meat is thick, fresh, and extremely chewy to eat.
Grilled oysters with onion fat are well presented but the taste is a bit bland, not really flavorful.
Steamed crabs are a bit small, the meat is sweet but not yet eaten.
The fries and stir-fried vermicelli were okay, nothing special.
The biggest minus point is the fried beef noodles - the beef is very hard, the noodles are dry and lack sauce. The restaurant should consider breading the beef to make it softer and stir-frying it with thick sauce to make the dish more flavorful.

In short: snails and shrimp should be tried, but beef noodles should be skipped!

The waiter was very rude. I told him it would take 10 minutes to prepare the dish, but he waited 20-25 minutes. Then the stingray hotpot came out and smelled fishy and burnt. I told the restaurant to argue, I was helpless. The tall, skinny guy's service attitude was unacceptable!
If you come to Phuoc Hai, you should visit this restaurant. It's clean, the staff is enthusiastic, and the price is ok. 10 points

The service is so bad. I sat there for almost 2 hours and only 2-3 dishes were brought out even though the restaurant wasn't very crowded. Everyone should consider carefully before entering the restaurant.

Seafood (mainly snails, oysters ...) is simply prepared like steamed, grilled with scallion oil, cheese ... in general, it is ok to eat, dishes that require a little more skill are only average like stir-fried vermicelli with crab, vermicelli and vegetables with crab legs are separate and not sticky ...
The restaurant is right on the Phuoc Hai embankment, quite clean, sitting outside in the evening is airy and cool.
The staff is very enthusiastic and polite.
The restaurant is very crowded, the food is delicious, the price is reasonable.
It's so delicious, you should try the striped mantis shrimp, reasonable price, good service, fresh food, delicious and fragrant porridge. I only remembered to take a picture after eating ðŸ˜…

Along the embankment, there is this clean and airy restaurant. The price may be a little higher than the surrounding area, but it is suitable for families with children and adults. 
Seafood, fresh and delicious food, and a lot of it. The whole family spent more than 1 million and was full. 
The staff is quite quick, cheerful and enthusiastic.
Delicious food, reasonable price and fast service. My family visited the restaurant twice a day. Will come back next time.

There are many seafood restaurants on this street, but I chose this place because it's clean, airy, and spacious. It's a bit crowded on weekends, but the seafood is fresh and delicious, the prices are reasonable, and the staff is very enthusiastic right from the parking lot ðŸ‘

The nth time I ate here. A familiar place for my family. The food is very delicious, once I stayed at Thanh Hao homestay 100 steps away from the restaurant, the room had a sea view.
This time I went with a friend who took 4 children out. So the hotel has a place to play. When I finished eating at the restaurant, I got caught in the rain and couldn't call a taxi, so the owner drove me home. We thank him very much. The people around always praise him, but today I just got to meet him.
While eating, we can watch the sea, and on a lucky day, we can also watch the rain.
The staff is very enthusiastic. Ordering at the end of the day is not difficult at all. The food is delicious and fresh.
Open air seating space, food is OK, served a bit cold. Staff is extremely enthusiastic, actively cleans up, super friendly. Reasonable price.
The restaurant is clean and cool. You can sit and eat comfortably when the air outside is hot and sunny.

The restaurant is located right at the beginning of the embankment, running down there are other restaurants, although the restaurant looks a bit fancy compared to other restaurants, I think the price is about the same as the restaurants I have eaten recently. 

Fresh seafood, most of the dishes I ordered were cooked well, however later I ordered 1 portion of steamed clams with lemongrass and 1 portion of steamed clams with Thai style, I found the steamed with lemongrass to be more delicious, the water was naturally sweet, the steamed Thai style with spices but not as good, the water was a bit brackish, not delicious. The oysters here are steamed for 35k/kg, I ordered oysters with cheese, salted egg and scallion oil, which were delicious, but the milk oysters were quite small and not very satisfying

The day I went to the restaurant, it was quite empty so the service was fast, the staff were also enthusiastic and comfortable. Our bill was more than 800k and divided by 4 was also very reasonable
The shop is clean, the prices are reasonable, the staff are extremely enthusiastic and cute. Will recommend to friends to come to the restaurant

The menu has a variety of dishes. Seasoning is delicious, suitable for the taste. Cheap oysters are only 35k/1kg. My table of 5kg was tired from eating. Fresh crab, fresh tiger prawns. Fresh seafood is delicious. You should also try the fried rice because it's delicious.

Thanh Hao seafood restaurant on Long Hai embankment. The restaurant is spacious and clean. The seafood is not delicious, but the price is reasonable. Looking at the oysters brought out makes me so bored that I don't want to eat them.

The restaurant looks cleaner than other restaurants along the embankment, and the dishes are served quite quickly. They sell by portion and by kg, and the food is fresh and swimming. The oysters are a bit small, the mantis shrimp is big but the meat is quite soft and a bit flat. The clams and squid are ok. The price is not as cheap as some people often review in VT, it is on par with SG.

Oysters were fresh and delicious. Squid was not fresh. Asked for mai fish and got fresh fish but the sauce was bad and the vegetables were missing star fruit and green banana. Fast service. Parking available across the street.

My family went in a large group but the service was very quick, the seafood was fresh and delicious, the price was not too expensive. Right on the embankment, after eating we could go out to cool off, the restroom was clean and cool.

I visited this place because of its favorable reviews while visiting Vietnam for a company workshop.
It's a clean restaurant with fresh seafood and affordable, delicious food, so I think Koreans will love it.
The staff and owner are especially helpful. They speak English well. Since our hotel was far away and Grab wasn't available, I asked if they could help me get a taxi, and they happily obliged.
They had rice paper, and they even kindly explained how to eat it to us, even though we weren't sure how to eat it.
Every dish is delicious, so if you're ever in Vung Tau, be sure to stop by.

delicious food, enthusiastic and lovely staff, reasonable price, clean, wifi, clean and fragrant toilet (there is air conditioning in the toilet), new facilities, but I don't know why it seems quite empty, hope the restaurant tries to maintain this level!!!
For me the food is ok, everyone should come and enjoy the experience. It's delicious.
Good food restaurant. Reasonable price. Lovely and enthusiastic service...

âœ“ The restaurant space is airy, near the sea.
âœ“ Fast and attentive service. I saw the guys cleaning the table very quickly, and it was also clean.
âœ“ Delicious food. Spring rolls and squid rolls, I recommend everyone to try.

One of the most elegant seafood restaurants on Phuoc Hai embankment. The restaurant is very airy, with a cool sea view all day long, and especially does not smell of seafood. The seafood is extremely fresh and well-prepared. There are dishes from popular to high-end, with a variety of dishes. The staff is very enthusiastic and dedicated. The restaurant is often very crowded on weekends, so you need to come early to get a table.

A restaurant worth visiting and even coming back after the first time is something that 99% of you do not need to worry about. My family and I came here for dinner and came back many times because of the following criteria:
1. The restaurant's location is beautiful, overlooking the sea and the open design with maximum sea view so that every early afternoon you can enjoy food while watching the sea view and sunset. If you say it is as beautiful as a cafe with investment, it is not, but I can rate it at 4.5/5 stars on this point.
2. Food quality: 4.5/5 stars. The food is quite fresh, diverse and well-prepared.
3. Price: 5/5 stars, very reasonable price.
4. Service quality: 4.5/5 stars, the weekends are quite crowded so we can't expect perfection, however the staff are enthusiastic, advise you on dishes, take good care of the children, and give ice cream to the children after eating, which is something that few restaurants I've seen do.

5. Hygiene: 4.5/5 stars, the restaurant has clean and beautiful restrooms and air conditioning.

I will come back here if I have the opportunity to stay in Long Hai or Ho Tram.
A seafood restaurant worth experiencing and enjoying.

#Highly recommended restaurant

I went on April 30th and it was very crowded. The staff, although very busy and visibly tired, were still enthusiastic, immediately provided whatever I asked for, not daring to show any displeasure. Overall, it was okay, I will come back next time.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at BOHO and it was truly an exceptional experience from start to finish. From the moment we walked in, the warm and inviting atmosphere made us feel right at home. The staff was incredibly friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable, offering excellent recommendations without being intrusive.

The food was nothing short of spectacular. Every dish we ordered was beautifully presented and bursting with flavor. The steak and lobster was perfectly cooked and seasoned, and the oyster was the perfect finishing touchâ€”light, delicious, and memorable. You can tell that fresh, high-quality ingredients are a top priority here.

What really sets BOHO apart is the attention to detail, both in the food and the overall dining experience. The ambiance is cozy yet refined, making it an ideal spot for both intimate dinners and special celebrations.

Overall, I canâ€™t recommend BOHO highly enough. The combination of outstanding food, top-notch service, and welcoming atmosphere makes it a must-visit. Iâ€™m already looking forward to my next visit!

I rate this 1* so that the owner would see and take the action.
- Everything is great here, from the hard working servers to the delicious food cooked by the experience cooks.
- So, why 1*?
- I'm a 35 male Vietnamese, and I haven't been experiened a slow and stupid management system for drink (maybe food too) like this.
- Let's not talk about technology, if you're a human being, you won't let your guests wait for more than 30 minutes for their 1st drink, would you?
- It's how it works there, and 2nd drink? You asked, it's the same.
- As being a patient traveller as I am, I was seeing people left after 30m since they had no drink after they ordered them.
- If the owner read this, then read it again, you have a great team working for you, they deserve a better management system.

If you come here on holidays or weekends, I think you should book a place in advance or if possible, some snacks to keep your table and be served faster, because the food and scenery here are very beautiful, so most weekends or holidays here are very crowded with diners from everywhere to visit, as for the scenery, there is no need to mention, in the light windy afternoons you sit and watch the waves rustling along with the sunset gradually fading, extremely suitable for family trips or maybe a couple's date, the food here is diverse, especially seafood, you can choose the type of seafood you want to have it prepared right at the restaurant's aquarium, not only that, there are also other typical dishes of the restaurant such as roasted chicken with sweet fried green bean sticky rice and beef pressed on a smooth rock with side dishes, here you can experience attentive care service and interact with very enthusiastic and cute staff, if Vung Tau were my home, I would choose this place as my first ideal dining place over other food service places.

The space is spacious, airy, the restaurant is beautiful and the view is also beautiful. The food is very suitable for my family's taste. The dishes my family ordered were all very delicious, the stone-grilled fuji beef was extremely delicious, everyone should try it, the sturgeon hotpot and grilled sturgeon were also very fresh and delicious. The manager and staff are very cute and enthusiastic, the day my family went, there was a very enthusiastic staff named Phuong. Everyone should try it if they visit Vung Tau.

The food here is only seasoned so-so, for example, the beef and taro salad, the onions in the salad are extremely pungent, after being shredded, it should be soaked in cold ice water, then soaked in vinegar oil, it would be better, but the taro is not flavored, it tastes out of place. The corn soup has no corn, the snails with cheese sauce also have no corn, maybe the kitchen bought too much corn yesterday??? Not to mention eating snails without toothpicks or forks, having to wait to be reminded. The staff are not professional, for each dish served with a dipping sauce, you have to wait for the customer to remind you, then when bringing it out, there are some bowls of dipping sauce, some don't have any. When asking the customer to pick up the fork to put in the new dish, they turn their faces away and yell like they're ordering a child or a soldier, it's really shocking! The plus point is that the steamed shrimp is fresh and delicious, but the grilled shrimp is very strange, the meat of each one is somehow mushy ðŸ¥²

- Seafood soup: seafood is tough, the soup has a lot of MSG.

The first time I went to the restaurant with a friend, the first impression was that the space was extremely spacious, with an outdoor area, an air-conditioned room and a VIP area.
The staff were friendly, enthusiastic and served very quickly.
In terms of taste, the restaurant's menu has a wide variety of dishes and mostly focuses on seafood, in addition to pork, beef, chicken and frog dishes.
I ordered 4 dishes that all suited my taste:
Fried squid with fish sauce 179K, fresh squid, hot and crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, served with vegetables and pickles so it was very tasty
Shrimp according to the current price (850k/kg) I made sashimi with wasabi and crispy fried shrimp heads, this is my favorite dish so I found it very delicious
Thai stir-fried vermicelli 129K, with seafood, shrimp, squid, fish cakes stir-fried with vermicelli and bell peppers, spicy Thai style, small and chewy vermicelli noodles that are not boring
Beef dipped in vinegar 189K, tender beef, delicious broth, served with raw vegetables, cucumber, star fruit, green banana and vermicelli
If I have the chance, I will come back

The minced beef spaghetti is delicious, the garlic butter bread is okay.

She also ordered entrees of samova which as standard come with two tips one of which is a mint coriander yoghurt mix. It was 10 out of ten hot. I asked the waitress to dress the heat level down by adding 50 percent more yoghurt. She said with a straight face this is indian food and if it is too hot just don't eat it. However it is a big part of the dish. I had to sternly tell her to take it away and add the yoghurt. My dish was roganjosh which came in a sauce which was OK but thinner than a standard soup. It flowed straight through the rice so spoiled the dinner which I had to eat with a soup spoon to get the source in with the meat. Overall very disappointing dishes. A Delightful Experience!

We initially planned a quick stop, but the charm of this beautiful restaurant convinced us to stay for lunch â€” and weâ€™re so glad we did! The place is tastefully decorated, filled with natural light and fresh air, creating a relaxing and inviting atmosphere.

The food was absolutely delicious, and the staff were exceptionally friendly and courteous.

Full marks for the positive vibe, beautiful ambiance, and mouthwatering food. Highly recommended!

â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ | A Perfect Start to the Day!
Had my first meal of the day here and it did not disappoint! The food was delicious â€” fresh, flavorful, and truly authentic Vietnamese. The staff were very warm and accommodating, making the experience even better. The cozy and aesthetic vibe of the place just adds to the charm. Definitely a spot Iâ€™ll be coming back to!

We had lunch at Sol Cu Chi after our Cu Chi Tunnel tour, and it was a great experience. The place was clean, modern, and had a pleasant ambiance. The staff were genuinely friendly and accommodating, making us feel very welcome. The food was of good qualityâ€”flavorful and well-preparedâ€”though the serving sizes could be improved. Overall, a solid spot to relax and refuel after the tour.

Sol Cu Chi Restaurant is a delightful find for anyone craving authentic Vietnamese cuisine in a warm, welcoming atmosphere. From the moment you walk in, youâ€™re greeted with the comforting aroma of herbs, spices, and simmering broths that promise a memorable meal.

The menu features a rich variety of traditional dishes, but the **signature Cu Chi-style pho** and **fresh spring rolls** truly stand out â€” beautifully presented, perfectly seasoned, and clearly made with care. Their **grilled pork vermicelli** is another must-try, with tender, flavorful meat and a perfectly balanced fish sauce dressing.

What sets Sol Cu Chi apart isnâ€™t just the food â€” itâ€™s the genuine hospitality. The staff is incredibly friendly and knowledgeable, often offering recommendations or a quick explanation of the origins of certain dishes, which adds to the experience.

The ambiance is cozy yet modern, making it ideal for both casual lunches and relaxed dinners. Whether youâ€™re a longtime lover of Vietnamese food or new to it, Sol Cu Chi delivers a heartfelt, high-quality culinary experience every time.

Highly recommended â€” a true taste of Vietnam in the heart of the city!
I really enjoyed my lunch here! With Orange as my server, she was very attentive and friendly throughout my meal!

Excellent food and service. Our server, Pinky, was thoughtful and attentive to our requests.

This restaurant has just opened recently, the model is also strange so I tried it. 

The restaurant sells hot pot dishes with beef, pork, seafood... 

The slightly different point of the restaurant is that you have to order 1 meat dish to choose 1 pot of hot pot broth, the cheapest is about 260k-300k per portion of meat, and everyone sitting down to eat must order. It's like a buffet ticket but in the form of ordering. You will be able to use the line counter freely, with no limits on vegetables, mushrooms... desserts... 

I am very satisfied with the quality of the hot pot broth and meat, fresh, politely decorated, beautiful. I think the hot pot broth has stewed beef bones that are worth eating, light and refreshing, Tom yum is a bit sour. 

The line counter is diverse, the side dishes such as fried chicken, fried tofu... fruit, sweet soup are very ok. Especially the ice cream machine is very fun, I ate that dish 3-4 times. 

The overall space is very beautiful, but a bit cramped when crowded.

The staff were polite, it was very crowded that day but they were still very nice and enthusiastic. 

In short, I rate this as a pretty good restaurant worth trying. However, if you go with a group of 4 or more people, the price here is a bit higher than if you go to a regular hot pot restaurant.

I didn't expect to be surprised when I came to eat hot pot. It's the first time I saw so many instant noodles on the wall. They are all my favorites. I really hope I can try every flavor. If you in Vietnam must visit Cu Chi for experiencing the mind blowing war techniques against American.
Vietnam is a country that truly captures the heart of anyone who visits. The people of Vietnam are among the most welcoming, humble, and kind-hearted individuals I have ever met. Their warmth and hospitality make visitors feel at home from the very first moment. Whether in the bustling streets of Hanoi or the peaceful villages along the Mekong Delta, thereâ€™s always a smile to greet you and a helping hand ready when needed.

The culture of Vietnam is equally rich and inspiringâ€”a perfect blend of tradition, resilience, and grace. Deeply rooted in family values, respect for elders, and community spirit, Vietnamese culture reflects a harmony between the past and the present. Festivals, music, and art beautifully showcase the nationâ€™s history and pride, while its cuisineâ€”fresh, flavorful, and balancedâ€”perfectly mirrors the Vietnamese way of life: simple yet deeply satisfying.

What stands out most is the peopleâ€™s positive spirit and their ability to find joy and strength even in challenges. Their respect for nature, tradition, and human connection is truly admirable.

Overall, Vietnamâ€™s people and culture leave a lasting impressionâ€”a reminder that kindness, simplicity, and unity are the true essence of a beautiful life.

It is a symbol of Vietnamese people's resilience. Going through the tunnel was one of my thrilling experience in life. You will feel anxious while entering into the tunnels. Lot of tourists are visiting this place but still able to explore all the tunnel areas. There is a shooting area where you can practice shooting with M14 or other guns. We also got opportunity to ate cassava prepared by Vietnamese and it tastes good. Our tour guide was so knowledgeable and explained all the things nicely.

Iâ€™m really happy I got the chance to visit Cu Chi Tunnels â€” itâ€™s an amazing and emotional place. The guide told the stories so well, it made me imagine what life was like during the war. Itâ€™s hard to believe people actually lived and fought from those tiny tunnels. I couldnâ€™t go inside because the air felt too heavy for me, but just walking around and listening to the history already touched my heart. Itâ€™s both impressive and sad at the same time â€” a real reminder of how strong the human spirit can be.
#it was raining during visit, i suggest you to come early in the morning to avoid rain and traffic.

We visited the Cu Chi Tunnel on Sunday. It is one of Vietnamâ€™s most significant and popular historical attractions, located approximately 55 km (around 1.5 hours) from Ho Chi Minh City.

I highly recommend visiting with a guided day tour rather than going on your own. There is so much detailed history to learn about the Vietnam War that only a knowledgeable guide can explain effectively. The tunnel system here is incredibly extensive, stretching over 250 km underground as our guide shared.

What you will see and experience here:
â€¢	Narrow tunnels built for escaping and hiding during the war
â€¢	Small spaces and hidden rooms where soldiers used to stay undetected
â€¢	Underground kitchens with cleverly camouflaged smoke outlets
â€¢	Weapon-making rooms and storage areas
â€¢	Sleeping areas, meeting rooms, and various underground living setups
â€¢	Models explaining war strategies, traps, and daily life of Vietnamese soldiers

The most fascinating part is experiencing the tunnels yourself. The tunnels are extremely narrow, dark, and complexly interconnected. It is truly unbelievable how soldiers moved and lived inside them. It was difficult even for us to crawl a short distance, and experiencing it gives you an immense sense of respect for their courage and endurance.

Additional notes:
â€¢	The entire site is located amidst a dense forest area. If the weather is hot, it can feel extremely humid and uncomfortable, so carrying water, a cap, and wearing comfortable shoes is highly recommended. In pleasant weather, the walk becomes enjoyable.
â€¢	There is a large souvenir shop to buy local items and handicrafts.
â€¢	You can also try shooting at the shooting range (note: this activity is chargeable and not included in the entry ticket).
â€¢	Entry ticket costs around 125,000 VND, and I have uploaded a photo of the ticket for reference. This was included in our day tour package.

Overall, visiting Cu Chi Tunnel was an inspiring and humbling experience, showcasing the intelligence, resilience, and determination of Vietnamese soldiers during the war. If you are in Ho Chi Minh City, this place is a must-visit to witness an extraordinary part of Vietnamâ€™s history.

The site shows the underground network used by the Viet Cong, with narrow passages you can crawl through, traps and weapons on display, and guided tours that explain daily life during the war. Itâ€™s undeniably touristy â€” some areas feel staged, and the shooting range adds to the spectacle, but it still delivers powerful insight into the resilience and hardships of that era. Worth visiting if you want to understand the war beyond the textbooks, though be prepared for crowds and a somewhat commercial atmosphere.

Visiting the Cá»§ Chi Tunnels was an eye-opening experience. The guided tour was informative. Walking through the narrow tunnels really made me appreciate the resilience and ingenuity of the people who built and lived in them. The site is well-maintained, and the displays, including traps and weapons, are fascinating. I highly recommend this place for anyone interested in history and culture. Wear comfortable shoes and be prepared for some crouching!

If you are going to go here, make sure you find a guide who knows a lot about the place. The travel is a bit farther out, so you will want to make the most of it. Some of the tour offers you will find on Klook have guides who will take you there and share some basic information, but if you want to enjoy the experience, make sure you find a knowledgeable guide.

That said, we still enjoyed being able to see the tunnels, the displays, and the bunkers. You will have the option to walk through some of the tunnels aside from the famous photo op where you lift the cover of the manhole. There are tanks there and also a shooting range, but we didn't opt to try that out.

It's hot, so bring a cap and water, and a mini-fan if you have it. Expect a lot of walking and dust. Remember that it's a literal part of a jungle so don't expect it to be like other museums or educational experiences!

Took us about an hour from city centre.

The attractions are a showcase of war time tactics used by the soldiers during vietnam war. Most of it are a recreated version.

I tried a 20m tunnel. It was challenging due to my size. It is not for those who are claustrophobic. It is narrow, less oxygen and if crowded with people behind you make it even more discomfort.

The shooting range seems to be main attraction as the crowd is huge with long queues. It will take an hour plus before you could get your turn. A barrel with 10 bullets to be purchased is also pricy.

Tour guides are very good they make the attractions even more dramatic with their explanation.

If you visit Vietnam the Cu Chi tunnels are as the ware museum a must to get a understanding of the history of this country. You get a feeling about jungle live in different station. Most impressive, with going trough this narrow tunnels. But just do it if you feel comfortable with that! We did it with a tour from Ho Chi min, is recommendable.

The Cu Chi Tunnels are about 50 km from Ho Chi Minh City, but definitely worth the journey. I always prefer renting a motorcycle when I travel, and the ride to Cu Chi was great, I got to enjoy the views, pass through local villages, and see everyday life of the Vietnamese people along the way.

The tunnels themselves are an eye-opening experience. You learn a lot about how the Vietnamese soldiers lived, fought, and survived underground during the war. The tour includes hidden entrances, traps, underground kitchens, and even a chance to crawl inside a real section of the tunnel. It really shows the toughness and creativity of the people during that time.

This place is not just a tourist site, itâ€™s a deep look into Vietnamâ€™s past. Highly recommended if you enjoy history and adventure!

Cu Chi Tunnels offer a fascinating glimpse into Vietnamâ€™s wartime history and impressive underground ingenuity. The guides are knowledgeable, and itâ€™s definitely interesting to see how the tunnels were used. However, itâ€™s located quite far from Ho Chi Minh City expect over two hours each way in heavy traffic, which makes the trip feel long and tiring. The shooting range was also a bit of a letdown, not as exciting or well-organized as expected. Most bullets for automatic guns were soldout. Overall, itâ€™s worth visiting for the history, but be prepared for a long commute and some underwhelming parts of the experience.

We didnâ€™t want a big tour so we got a taxi there and paid entry. We wanted to go at our own pace. We we were forced to sit down to watch a video for ten minutes about the history of the tunnels. We didnâ€™t want to watch the video. We wanted to go and explore. The staff said no you must sit down. We tried to get up to explore but we were told again to sit down until the video finished. The video was blurry and inaudible. The video eventually finished and a staff member said they were going to take us around. This shouldâ€™ve been made clear from the beginning when we didnâ€™t want to watch the video. I wouldâ€™ve happily waited for this reason. Being told to sit down and wait until the end of the video made us feel like we were being treated like children. The tour took about 45 min in total. The guide was very good.

Visiting the Cá»§ Chi Tunnels was such a fascinating and eye-opening experience! The site is very well organized, and our tour director did an amazing job explaining the history and significance of the tunnels during the war. Walking through the narrow passages really gave me a sense of the determination and resilience of the people who built and used them.

I also appreciated the way the tour combined education with hands-on experience â€” from seeing the hidden entrances to actually crawling through parts of the tunnel system. Everything was safe, well maintained, and respectful of the history.

This is definitely one of those â€œmust-seeâ€ places when visiting Vietnam. It gave me a much deeper appreciation for the countryâ€™s history and culture. Highly recommend!

Somewhat entertaining and informative. The main reason for our visit was to shoot the M-60 machine gun. When we in the part of the tour where you can shoot the guns we were informed that they ran out of bullets for the M-60 (we were there before noon). The only gun that they had bullets for was a carbine which would have been my last choice but that's all that they had.

We paid for the ammo and were directed to the firing range. Apparently they don't maintain their guns very well, it jammed five times while going through one clip.

If the main reason for your visit is to shoot the guns, I would advise against it.

Very cool. Guides were funny and informative and made sure everyone could make use of the experience. The tunnels are tight and not recommended for big or unfit people. You could chose to go through one or more tunnels no pressure to do too much. If you are skinny it is super fun to try to fit through the smallest holes. Would recommended to make the trip from HCMC if you are there.

Historical place, visiting this place is recommend, so many things to learn about Vietnam war , have a real gun shooting place can visit that and try, cost is little high so be prepared. U can get tickets nearby to hotel or in hotel in ho chi min city, or in klook or others.

Wow, what a creative idea by Vietnamese.

The tunnels were used by Viet Cong soldiers as hiding spots during combat, as well as serving as communication and supply routes, hospitals, food and weapon caches and living quarters for numerous North Vietnamese fighters.

A pretty cool place to visit, especially if youâ€™re interested in or want to learn more about the war against the US. Lots of practical examples from the war, and itâ€™s also possible to travel through some tunnels and experience what it was truly like! A must see place when youâ€™re in Vietnam. Fairly easy to book tours whilst staying in Ho Chi Minh City, they will organise your transport to and from the site included in the price.

Visited the Cá»§ Chi Tunnels yesterday â€” itâ€™s about 1.5 hours from Ho Chi Minh City (expect traffic during rush hour). Thereâ€™s an entry fee, and as a foreigner youâ€™ll also need to pay for a guide, but itâ€™s worth it.

The site gives you an incredible look into Vietnamâ€™s wartime history â€” how people dug and lived in tunnels during the war. Itâ€™s like an underground city stretching over 250 km. Of course, you canâ€™t explore everything; they show you a few entrances and short sections, so you get a feel for it without going deep inside.

Plan to spend at least 3â€“4 hours here. There are food stalls around if you get hungry, and also a national defense shooting range. The shooting costs about 600,000â€“650,000 VND for 10 rounds. If youâ€™ve never tried shooting before, it can be an interesting experience, but since the guns are fixed to the railing, itâ€™s not the same as holding them freely.

Overall, it was a fun and very educational visit â€” definitely a must-see to better understand the history of the Vietnam War.

A Journey Through History Beneath the Ground
Visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels was both eye-opening and unforgettable. The site offers a raw and powerful glimpse into the resilience and ingenuity of the Vietnamese during the war. Crawling through the narrow tunnels, seeing the hidden entrances, and learning about the wartime strategies made history feel real.

The guides were knowledgeable and passionate, sharing stories that added a deeply human layer to the experience. It's not just a tourist attractionâ€”itâ€™s a tribute to survival and determination. Highly recommended for anyone wanting to understand Vietnam beyond the surface.

The tunnels were very cool though you want to get there early in the day to avoid the crowds. Thereâ€™s a lot to learn about the American war, and if youâ€™re in Ho Chi Minh City for a couple of days theyâ€™re definitely worth visiting.

We enjoyed our few hours here. We had a guide which I highly recommend. We learnt so much
as he was so knowledgeable on this topic.

The area is so well set up. You get a real sense of what it was like for both sides of the war

Very well run

Iâ€™d suggest getting there early before all the big buses arrive

3/4 of us shot the guns there. They have a AK47 and an M45 which you pay by the bullet

There is a great cafe there offering food and drinks. Reasonable prices too

Watch out for the big centipedes everywhere. Iâ€™d suggest covered shoes not just thongs

This was somber and awe inspiring. We went to the tunnels furthest from HCMC and it was not very busy. Videos from the time of the war play before you enter the tunnels. Please do watch this as really helps to understand how the tunnels functioned. QR codes are dotted along the way for you to learn more. The gift shop is well priced. We also went to the firing range and shot an AK-47. You have to buy min 10 bullets at approx $4aud a bullet. It's expensive but how often do you get to shoot a gun like that?!

During the war, Vietnam defended itself using guerilla warfare, relying on stealth and sabotage to fight a superior military power. To support this, the Vietcong had a vast network of tunnels that lay beneath much of the country. Here you can see a part of the tunnel network they used.

To get to Ben Duoc, the site that hosted the tunnels, you can get a bus from Ho Chi Minh City. The public buses run past the site, so it's not hard to get there.

Ben Duoc is more than just the tunnels. It's a whole tourist destination and museum, with other activities you can try, including a shooting range where you can fire various weapons.

The site hosts war memorials, honouring those that sacrificed their lives to liberate the country. Near the entrance is a temple, a place where people can pay their respects.

There are many displays of weapons in Ben Duoc, giving an impression of the amount of munitions used in the war. Many spent bomb cases and shells, howitzers, and disabled rifles bring you into the world of Vietnam at war, when guns were everywhere.

Scattered about the site are several destroyed and damaged vehicles recovered during and after the war. Old tanks, jeeps, helicopters, and even bomber planes are on display.  They're impressive to see even in their ruined state.

The tunnels themselves provide a guided tour so you get an explanation of everything as you go through the exhibition. Before being shown the tunnels, you are shown a brief movie that gives an overview of the tunnels, how they played a part in the war, and how they were used to help plan the Tet Offensive.

Our guide was good at both being entertaining and informative, teaching us history and encouraging us to interact and explore the tunnels. We were allowed to crawl in and actually see and feel what it was like down there. The tunnels here have been widened and have lights installed, so they're a little easier to navigate than they were during the war, but you still get a feel for it.

You will also be shown the kind of traps that the VC used during the war, as well as several mock scenes of what life was like in the tunnels.

At the end of the tour we got to enjoy some local Vietnamese food while we talked about our experience. It was a educational experience, and one I would recommend to anyone interested in the history of the Vietnam War.

I recently visited the Cu Chi Tunnels and it was such an eye-opening and unforgettable experience. Learning about the Vietnam War on-site made everything feel so real and emotional. I was truly amazed by the creativity and resilience of the Vietnamese peopleâ€”how they were able to live, move, and survive underground in such extreme conditions is just incredible. Itâ€™s a powerful reminder of how thinking outside the box can make the impossible possible.

You actually get to experience the tunnels yourself, and let me tell youâ€”itâ€™s intense! The temperature was around 22Â°C, which helped, but you still have to bend, squat, crawl, and slide your way through tight, narrow passages. Itâ€™s physically exhausting, but also really fun and totally worth it.

One of the highlights for me was the shooting range. You can try out some of the actual types of guns used during the war. I got to fire one, and it was both thrilling and surrealâ€”like stepping straight into history.

If you're visiting Vietnam and want a deeper understanding of its history, this place is a must-see. Just wear comfy clothes and prepare for a unique, hands-on adventure!

Visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels was an unforgettable experience. The guides explained the history very well and gave us a real sense of how people lived during the war. Crawling through the tunnels was both exciting and eye-opening. Itâ€™s a must-see if you want to understand Vietnamâ€™s past.

Must visit. It was an amazing experience to know how the tunnels were made and used by the locals during the war times.
Do visit the shooting range and walk through the tunnels. Worth the money!

Amazing experience! It was very interesting exploring the tunnels and learning the history, but obviously be aware this can be a sensitive subject for Americans. The guides will tell you how long each tunnel is so you can judge for yourself if you want to go in.

Very impressive what the Vietnamese build during and before the Vietnam War.  3 layers up to 12 meters deep. I barely fitted in the tunnels so I couldn't go to level 2 or 3. had a wonderful time here! so interesting to learn about the tunnels & the entire underground world. super tight & hot inside the tunnels so beware of that, but the guides will allow you to wait for the rest of your party on the outside if you donâ€™t feel comfortable going inside. our guide was wonderful as well! with that being said, we did feel a lot of confusion for the shooting range. the first man we talked to said the minimum bullets you could buy was 5, so we said ok we will get them, but then he walked away and someone else came up

As we were visiting independently without any tour guide, we visited the Cu Chi tunnel of Ben Duoc. We traveled by booking on Grab and it took us 2 hours to reach there. Very cool! I loved the history of it! Got down in one of the holes to hide against the enemyâ€™s! And we went down into the tunnels too! Omg! 1 metre height.. and you can go for about 100 metres I believe, but there is a way out every 20 metres. Apparently the 1 metre height was made later, and it was actually half a metre! How sad for them. What a horrible situation for war.
The whole place was fantastic definitely worth going. You can also shoot a riffle where you pay for bullets. I didnâ€™t do this and just waited for my group. The one thing is I think they should give the ppl waiting the ear muffs! It was SOOOOOOOO LOUD! Too much! Omg. Like definitely ear piercing!

I had the incredible opportunity to explore the Cu Chi Tunnels, a remarkable testament to resilience, ingenuity, and the indomitable spirit of those who fought during Vietnam's turbulent history. Walking through the narrow, dark passages, I gained a deeper appreciation for the strategic brilliance and courage of the Vietnamese soldiers who used these tunnels as a vital part of their defense.
The experience was both humbling and eye-opening. Itâ€™s one thing to read about the history, but entirely different to physically stand where history was made. The ingenuity behind the trap systems, the hidden entrances, and the underground living conditions truly showcase human resilience in the face of adversity.
A huge thank you to the guides and local experts who shared their knowledge and stories, bringing the tunnelsâ€™ history to life. This visit has left me with a profound respect for the resilience of the Vietnamese people and the importance of remembering our shared histories.
If you ever get the chance, I highly recommend visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels â€” itâ€™s a powerful, educational, and moving experience that connects us to the past in a very personal way.

Significant infrastructural development has transformed the Cá»§ Chi Tunnels complex since three decades prior. The construction of modern visitor centers, amenities, and curated historical exhibits has been implemented to support its growing role as a key tourist attraction.

Very educational with lots of displays and hands-on activities.  A bit of walking but paths were good (but might be slippery in rain).  You get to go inside tunnels -- difficult to walk with very low ceilings, but there is an exit every 20m so you can get out at your choice.

One must keep atleast 6/7 hours to see this great place. It was really very informative. My salute to Vietnamese people of those time who with their limited resources defeated mighty Americans. Actual length of tunnel was 250 km and Vietnamese used to hide inside when attacked and come out in night and attack American base camps. They had made all arrangements to stop flooding during rains and also made provision for fresh air to come inside. A lot of traps were made over tunnel due to which a lot of Americans were injured or killed. Overall 58000 American soldiers were killed in this war. Nowadays they allow tourists to see only 100 meter of tunnel with exit at every 20 mt. One has to crawl to go through this. Old and claustrophobic people shoul avoid the tunnel. There is also a firing range where one can shoot with AK47/M15. A guide is a must here. Don't miss this place if you are in Ho Chi Minh.

An eye-opening experience. Can't imagine how the Vietnamese people used to live with their families under the small, dark tunnel. The next day I had some knee problem from the tunnel experience.
Great experience of the historic war tactics of the Vietnam soldiers, amazing tour. Gun firingalso available AK47 firing for 10 bullets at 650k.

Nice historical place Vietnam and USA war place can see many different tunnels and which is used in the war Guns , vehicles, equipments AK47,etc everything is there and also have guides are there they will explain very clearly and once you see all done there then they will give you one kind bamboo fruit to eat with peanut very tasty ðŸ¤ŸâœŒï¸ðŸ˜Š

Had a wonderful afternoon with Ms. Sunny from Vietnam Adventure Tour, booked via the Viator app. Choosing a non-touristy small group was a great decision â€” minimal queue for the Cu Chi Tunnels and even for the ladies' washroom!

Ms. Sunny was engaging, always smiling, and spoke excellent English. She, along with the very capable driver, made the experience smooth and enjoyable. Despite being briefly stopped by the police (for the usual â€œcoffee moneyâ€), the driver kept everything efficient and got us back to Ho Chi Minh City on time for dinner â€” which I really appreciated!

The afternoon tour was an excellent choice â€” the weather was cooler and more comfortable. I even had the unique experience of firing an AK-47 â€” half a magazine cost 1.3 million VND, and it was totally worth it for the adrenaline rush.

A well-organized and memorable tour. Highly recommended!
Many small tunnels that have been preserved since the Vietnam war. Learning the history was a good experience too. Would recommend anyone who is into history to visit this amazing tourist attraction.

The war tunnels that were once a survival passage and now tourist sites for individuals like me who never experienced war to feel how it was like traveling underground in an enclosed space while life is at risk.  I had a remarkable time but would highly recommended to come on a mild weather day to ensure it isn't too hot

A must-visit for anyone interested in the war history of Vietnam. The Cu Chi Tunnels offer a fascinating and immersive experience â€” walking through the actual tunnels used during the Vietnam War gives you a real sense of how the Viet Cong lived and fought. The guided tour is informative

If you like history, you will really enjoy this place.

Special mention to my tour guide Wing who is very resourceful and energetic! A fun guy to talk to and very nice. Ping me if you want his number lol

Cu Chi Tunnels are a shining symbol of the bravery, intelligence and indomitable patriotism of our army and people during the resistance war. The exclusive tunnel system, built with strong will and extraordinary creativity, has become an impregnable fortress underground. Every meter of tunnel, every secret cellar tells the story of silent sacrifice and determination to maintain self-made independence. I would like to express my admiration, deep gratitude and respect for the heroic spirit of Cu Chi land, "the land of steel and bronze".

You can experience World War II and Vietnam War sites in person â€” the old, worn-out weapons are full of historical traces. Itâ€™s hard to believe they lived underground for such a long time. Definitely worth a visit.
Excellent visit to Chu Chi Tunnels near Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam. Very Informative and interesting Tour of underground tunnels explained by our Tour Guide.

Memorable experience at HCMC. The site located quite far from the city center. Booked the trip with THK Travel on tiket.com. It was a great experience, both the service and the experience on Chu Chi Tunnel. Must visit if youâ€™re in HCMC.

Cu Chi Tunnel is around 44 Km away from Ho Chi Minh City. It takes around an hour to reach by road.

This place gives a glimpse of war between America and Vietnam army. How Viet villagers and soldiers fought with American army. How they lived underground  and survived for so long.

A fascinating and immersive insight to the Vietnam war and the Cu Chi people of Vietnam. We enjoyed our two hour tour with a great guide.

At the shooting range you can pick a gun out of 3 options (AK47, Carbine, Pistol). The cost per round is 60,000 VND and you are expected to buy a minimum of 10 rounds.

There are multiple other attractions on-site which have separate charges. So ensure you check for it while buying your tickets.

We rented a bike for 150,000 VND for a day to reach the location (takes about 2 hours) which is the best option if you wish to enjoy the ride on the way and explore local restaurants en route.

Thereâ€™s 200km of tunnels where one can easily get lost - an amazing feat! You get to try a 40m and 15m tunnels which are altered for tourists to fit in. Either way you get a real experience of the tunnels and appreciation of what life must have been like during the war.

If youâ€™re visiting Vietnam, the Cu Chi Tunnels is a place you have to visit. They hold incredible historical significance to Vietnam, due to their involvement in the Vietnam War in the 1960s and 1970s. Tunnels used during the war have become well known in Western culture, through movies like Platoon, and games like Call of Duty Black Ops.

You are able to see many interesting things while youâ€™re here, such as secret tunnel entrances, various bobby traps used by the North Vietnamese and Viet Cong, and even an old American tank that remains lying where it was crippled during the war.

The Cu Chi tunnels should be visited, not just because they are an incredibly interesting historical site, but also because they serve as a reminder of the atrocities and the horror that occurred in the Vietnam War. Both sides dehumanised and did extremely evil things to one another, and this should never be forgotten.

I would recommend having a local guide to guide you through the site, this way you will get more knowledge and insight from them, and be able to ask them questions as well. Our guide was fantastic. He spoke to us about how the war affected him growing up when he was a little boy.

Overall I would highly recommend visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels. 5/5 stars.
A perfect not so crowded spot, a bit longer drive but worth it. Do try the tunnels if you dare

Learned a lot about the history of Vietnamese war and crisis. They have preserved it pretty well for tourists to see and hear from the tour guides.

If you're in HCMC or surrounding areas, it's a must go for those who like history. I would recommend going with a tour guide as they will also drove you there and it's around 2 hours to get there but it's well worth it and very very interesting.
Worth the trip although going back and forth to the area was quite exhausting. The tunnel experience also can trigger claustrophobia so might not be for the weak of heart.

What a fantastic experience and place to learn more about the Vietnam war and history around it. This place was one of our stops on tour and our guide was amazing. Visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels was an incredible and eye-opening experience, offering deep insights into Vietnamâ€™s history and the resilience of its people. We had booked a tour group, and the bus picked us up from the Old Quarter, making the journey convenient. The ride itself was smooth, and after reaching the site, our guide walked us through the history of the tunnels, explaining how the Vietnamese soldiers dug them by hand using basic tools, enduring immense hardships. These tunnels played a crucial role in their victory during the Vietnam War, allowing them to outmaneuver and resist much stronger forces.

There are two tunnels that visitors can enter, and going inside was both thrilling and humbling. At times, you have to crawl through extremely narrow spaces, truly experiencing the conditions the Vietnamese soldiers endured. The guide led us through the tunnels, ensuring safety while sharing fascinating details about their strategy, survival techniques, and daily life underground.

It was a great and lasting experience, making history come alive in a way that books never could. Highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting Vietnam! After the tour, we were conveniently dropped back at the District 1, wrapping up an unforgettable day.

The Cu Chi Tunnels, located near Ho Chi Minh City, are a fascinating and historic attraction that offers insight into the ingenuity and resilience of the Vietnamese people during the Vietnam War. Here's an overview based on visitor reviews:

Pros:

Historical Significance: The tunnels provide a vivid glimpse into the lives of the Viet Cong soldiers. Visitors can explore the underground network and learn about their strategies and survival techniques.

Interactive Experience: You can crawl through sections of the tunnels (some have been widened for tourists), which gives a real sense of the challenges faced by those who lived and fought there.

Educational Tours: Guided tours offer in-depth historical context, often accompanied by displays of wartime relics, weapons, and traps.

Scenic Surroundings: The site is located in a forested area, providing a peaceful environment that contrasts with the harsh conditions of war.

Cultural Understanding: Visitors gain a deeper understanding of Vietnam's history and the impact of the war on its people.

Cons:

Crowds: The site can get very crowded, especially during peak tourist seasons.

Not Suitable for All Ages: The experience might be challenging for young children or those who are claustrophobic, as the tunnels are narrow and dark.

Tourist Commercialization: Some visitors feel that the shooting range and other attractions on-site detract from the historical gravity of the place.

Distance from Ho Chi Minh City: The site is about 1.5 hours away by car, so it requires a half-day or full-day commitment.

Tips for Visiting:

Wear Comfortable Clothes: Light clothing and sturdy shoes are recommended as you might crawl through tunnels.

Prepare for Heat: The tunnels and surrounding area can get hot and humid, so bring water and sunscreen.

Book a Guided Tour: A knowledgeable guide enhances the experience with detailed stories and explanations.

Plan for Kids: If traveling with a 5-year-old, consider the less intense activities at the site as the tunnels may be too challenging for them.

Overall, the Cu Chi Tunnels are a must-visit for history enthusiasts or anyone interested in Vietnamâ€™s wartime history. It's a humbling and thought-provoking experience.

I recently visited the Cu Chi Tunnels, and it was one of the most surreal experiences Iâ€™ve ever had. The heat inside made it feel like a sauna, and you really have to squat and shuffle to make your way through. It gave me a new appreciation for the conditions soldiers endured.

The site itself is incredibly well-preserved and full of interactive exhibits that bring history to life. From seeing the hidden entrances and clever traps to learning about daily life in the tunnels, every part of the tour was fascinating. Thereâ€™s even a shooting range where you can try out different riflesâ€”another unique experience that adds to the adventure.

Overall, visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels was both humbling and exciting. If you ever find yourself in Vietnam, this is an absolute must-see. A guided tour helps you understand the rich history behind the site, and taking your time to explore it makes the visit even more memorable.

Visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels is a must for anyone interested in history and culture. The site offers a deep dive into Vietnamâ€™s resilience and ingenuity during the war. The guided tour was incredibly informative, with detailed explanations of the tunnel system, its significance, and the challenges faced by those who lived and fought there.

Walking through the narrow tunnels was an eye-opening experience, giving a glimpse of what life must have been like underground. The interactive exhibits, including the chance to see hidden trapdoors and sample traditional food, added to the immersive experience.

The grounds are well-maintained, and the staff is friendly and knowledgeable. The shooting range is an optional activity for those looking for a unique thrill. However, be prepared for some areas to feel crowded during peak hours.

Overall, this is a powerful and thought-provoking visit that provides a deeper appreciation for history. Highly recommend adding this to your Vietnam itinerary!

The Cu Chi Tunnels are a truly extraordinary site, a testament to the resilience and ingenuity of the Vietnamese people during the Vietnam War. Stepping into this network of underground passages is like stepping back in time, offering a visceral understanding of the conditions endured by those who lived and fought within them.

The tunnels themselves are a marvel of engineering. The multi-layered design, the ingenious ventilation systems, and the hidden trapdoors all speak to the strategic brilliance of the Viet Cong. Walking (or crawling) through a section of the tunnels provides a profound sense of the claustrophobia and hardship faced by the soldiers. The sheer scale of the network, stretching for hundreds of kilometers, is staggering.
The displays of booby traps and weaponry, while sobering, offer a crucial glimpse into the realities of guerrilla warfare. They highlight the resourcefulness of the Viet Cong in utilizing limited resources to defend their territory. Learning about the hospitals, kitchens, and command centers within the tunnels underscores the remarkable self-sufficiency and determination of those who lived and operated underground.
The Cu Chi Tunnels are not just a historical site; they are a powerful symbol of the human spirit's ability to adapt and overcome. They provide a unique and unforgettable experience, offering a tangible connection to a pivotal period in history. If you want to understand the Vietnam War from a different perspective, this is a must-see. The raw experience of the tunnels themselves is powerful enough to make this a five star experience

The War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City offers a powerful and thought-provoking experience that dives deep into Vietnam's wartime history, particularly the Vietnam War. From the moment you enter, you're met with striking exhibits outside displays include American helicopters, tanks, and bombshells that set the tone before stepping inside.

The museumâ€™s galleries are well-curated, showcasing raw and emotional photography, first-hand accounts, weapon displays, and reconstructed prison conditions. One of the most impactful sections focuses on the long-term effects of chemical warfare, especially Agent Orange, with sobering imagery and survivor stories.

The prison exhibit with life-sized mannequins and a preserved guillotine is chilling and historically significant.

Thereâ€™s also dedicated space exploring global support during the war, along with detailed panels about Da Lat and Phu Quoc prisons. The layout encourages reflection and personal interpretation, rather than forcing a political stance.

Youâ€™ll want to spend at least 1~2 hours here to take in the emotional weight and historical context fully. It's not a light visit, but it's an essential one for anyone wanting to understand Vietnamâ€™s past from a Vietnamese perspective.

Respectful dress and quiet observation are appreciated in there.
