Visiting the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City was one of the most powerful and emotional experiences of my trip to Vietnam. I went in expecting to learn about history, but I left with something much deeper: a profound reflection on humanity, suffering, and resilience.
The exhibitsâ€”especially the photographsâ€”were deeply moving. Some images were so raw and disturbing that I almost cried while walking through the galleries. I found myself needing to pause and take time to process what I was seeing. The human cost of the Vietnam War, especially for civilians, was heartbreaking.

What struck me most was how personal the museum felt. It doesnâ€™t just present facts or military artifacts; it shows the faces, names, and lives of people affectedâ€”both Vietnamese and foreign. The section on Agent Orange and its lingering effects across generations was particularly difficult to take in.

I left with a heavy heart but also with a greater understanding of Vietnamâ€™s past and an even stronger appreciation for the strength and kindness of its people today. Despite everything the country endured, I was met everywhere with warmth and openness. This visit changed the way I think about war, history, and reconciliation.

If you're in Ho Chi Minh City, I believe this museum is a must-visit. Itâ€™s not easy, but itâ€™s important.

Amazing little museum. 3 floors of information pertaining to the Vietnam war and itâ€™s lasting effects. In particular, I found the â€œWar Photographersâ€ section to be captivatingâ€¦a lot of stories in there about journalists all over the globe that were intent on capturing the war and the brutality therein, often times paying the ultimate price for their attempts to broadcast the truth. The entire museum could easily take 2-4 hours if youâ€™re intent on reading all the descriptions (provided in Vietnamese and English).

One small note - I didnâ€™t see any warnings, but some of the content in here can definitely be unsettling. Iâ€™m glad they havenâ€™t shied away from this, as itâ€™s important to show the horrible effects of the war directly. But there are quite a lot of pictures of dead and mutilated bodies, especially within the â€œWar Crimesâ€ room. Also, thereâ€™s a large section dedicated to the health ramifications of Agent Orange, showing the deformities (in both children and adults, Vietnamese and foreign) and mental conditions caused by that horrible chemical. I saw a lot of families with young kids in here, and a lot of the children had slightly terrified looks on their faces. I assume if it was affecting to me, it may have been doubly so for them. Again, I recommend coming and not turning your face away from the horrible facts and effects of the war, but if youâ€™re sensitive or have young children who may not be mentally prepared for such imagery, you may want to avoid certain exhibits that you feel could include such photographs (mainly War Crimes and Agent Orange are the two areas that are disturbing, I havenâ€™t included any pictures from them below).

If youâ€™re in Saigon even a little bit interested in the history and lasting effects of the war, this is a must-visit museum. I visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was crowded, but still easy to see everything.
Very busy. Good layout. Clean. Well airconditioned. Friendly and helpful staff. Very reasonable entrance fee. It serves as a reminder of how horrid humanity can be. Let us never forget.

War Remnants Museum â€“ A Powerful and Eye-Opening Experience

As a family of four, our visit to the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City was both powerful and educational. The museum presents the Vietnam War from a Vietnamese perspective, offering insights and stories that challenged our previous understanding and encouraged meaningful reflection.

The exhibits are thoughtfully curated, with impactful photography, preserved war artifacts, and deeply personal accounts that humanize the tragedy of war. Walking through the displays, we learned a great dealâ€”not just about the history and events, but about the ideology and perspective of a country that lived through immense suffering and resilience.

Some sections are difficult to take in, especially for younger visitors, but they sparked important conversations for our family. We left with a deeper understanding of Vietnamâ€™s history and a strong appreciation for the value of peace and empathy.

This is not just a museum visitâ€”itâ€™s an experience that stays with you. Highly recommended for families seeking a deeper, more global perspective on history.

We happened to visit the War Remnants museum on the 50th anniversary of reunification. So it was a huge day in Vietnam marking 50 years since the end of the war. The museum was only 80,000 Dong each (~Â£2.30) to get in. We felt this was amazing value.
Before entering me and my girlfriend had no knowledge about the Vietnam war. However exiting 3 hours later we felt as thought we knew a lot. Inside the museum you can read the full timeline of the war. Itâ€™s quite distressing seeing what the Americans did and many people were quite emotional. There are photos which are very disturbing and show the extent of the pain the Vietnamese went through.
Outside the building there were military vehicles and weapons which were fascinating to look at.
Overall really glad we went and it has given us a real insight to the horrors that occurred.
This really is a must if you are visiting Ho Chi Minh City.

A visit to the War Remnants Museum was very interesting and worthwhile.
The old machinery left by the US Army has been kept in very good order.
I was a child in South Australia, when the protest movement really moved things along, particularly at the universities. There were some old news paper clips of some of the Australian protests around, along with other countries also protesting the Vietnam war.

Didn't take many pictures inside but it was truly a worthwhile visit with lots of things to learn from this very tragic event in history. Also shows how cruel human beings can be! ðŸ˜žI guess the saddest part is to know that recent events happening in the world have shown that mankind still hasn't learnt from our past mistakes.

Eye opening experience. Vibe was heavy as the museum highlights the harsh outcomes of war and the toll it takes on humanity. A lot of graphic images, war artifacts on exhibit. A must go when in Saigon to learn about its troubled and bloody history. I had a very educational and humbling experience. Definitely worth my time.

There is a short flight of stairs to enter the main museum, once inside, there is an elevator which is convenient for those with wheelchairs and kid strollers.

A real eye opener on the Vietnam war and the utter devastation caused by agent orange, hundreds if not thousands of artefacts on display including types of explosives, weaponry and military vehicles. Informative, interesting, heart breaking and much more, I truly recommend this as a cant miss stop on your trip.

The Museum is easily accessible from central areas such as District 1 by motorbike, taxi, or bus. Opening hours are from 7:30 AM to 5:30 PM (ticket counter closes at 5:00 PM). The standard entrance fee is 40,000 VND; children aged 6â€“15, students, seniors, people with meritorious service, and those from remote areas receive a 50% discount; children under 6 enter free. The museum consists of an outdoor display area and a three-story exhibition building with about 4,522 mÂ² of indoor space, plus over 3,000 mÂ² outdoors. At the front yard and outdoor grounds, visitors can see military equipment such as the M48 Patton tank, UH-1 â€œHueyâ€ helicopter, F-5 fighter jet, A-1 Skyraider aircraft, and various bombs, along with artifacts like the reconstructed â€œtiger cagesâ€ used to detain political prisoners, a guillotine, and victim statues, offering clear representations of wartime conditions.

Inside, the ground floor introduces the theme â€œThe World Supports Vietnam in the Anti-American Warâ€ with more than 100 photos and 145 documents. The first floor focuses on â€œWar Crimesâ€ and â€œConsequences of Agent Orangeâ€ through images, artifacts, and documents. The second floor includes exhibitions such as â€œHistorical Truth,â€ â€œVietnam â€” War and Peace,â€ â€œMemoirs,â€ and war photography by Japanese and international correspondents. Displays feature captions in Vietnamese, English, and Japanese. The museum does not have a dedicated parking lot; visitors can park motorbikes at nearby spots a few meters from the entrance, with fees around 4,000â€“5,000 VND. The indoor space is kept clean and organized by exhibition theme.

Powerful and somber, the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City offers a stark look at the Vietnam War through photos and artifacts. A must-visit for history buffs, though emotionally intense. Highly recommend.

Incredibly cheap to get in. No need to prebook.
Excellent museum with all the old US army vehicles, planes etc.
well worth a visit.
Has a cafe and shop.

Typically when I visit a museum in America I'm both enlightened and uplifted - not the later case here in VietnamðŸ˜‘. Horror. Dread. Empathy. Remorse? The images are too graphic to post. But if you've ever fought in war, heard stories from family members who have, or have been associated in any way with the destruction that wars cause, then well... you get the picture. As an American it's unsettling but at the same time unifying to share the experience with people from all different countries (and perspectives), including Vietnamese. If you're not emotionally moved after visiting then I can't imagine you're human.

Place full of history about the vietnam war, a really deep and raw insight to the country's history as well as the story of the people that lived through the war. The exhibits on the upper levels were what made the visit memorable with all the stories about the survivors of agent orange, the prisoners kept in the harsh living conditions and many more.

A must-see! If there is one thing you do in Ho Chi Minh, it has to get the war remnants museum.  While it is interesting seeing the war machines, planes, choppers, tanks, artillery, etc. It's when you get inside that the photographs, descriptions, and facts that you must read describe the events during the war is truly awakening. Discretion is advised as some images are horrifying and had me emotionally moved that I needed time for reflection.

Learnt a lot about the History of Vietnam ðŸ‡»ðŸ‡³ especially the war with America. It's really a sad story which happened 50 years ago. There is display of American Armoury, weapons,Tanks,Fighters etc. It's over two floors of History. I admire the present Vietnamese generation. They are all smiles and  go out of their way to help you. Saigon can be very challenging and frustrating with the traffic jams. Always plan ahead.

Very good place to inform yourself of the atrocities done during the Vietnam War. Itâ€™s one of the living testaments as to why these things should never happen again. Glad I could see eye-to-eye detailed first-hand accounts and pictures regarding the war, and definitely learned a lot from the visit.

Visiting the War Remnants Museum is a powerful and emotional experience that really stays with you. It's one of those places that gives you a deeper understanding of history in a way that books or documentaries sometimes can't. The museum focuses heavily on the Vietnam War, especially from the perspective of the Vietnamese people, and it doesnâ€™t shy away from showing the impact of the conflict.

The exhibits are very well put together, with a mix of photographs, personal stories, official documents, and military equipment. Some sections, like the one about Agent Orange and the aftereffects of chemical warfare, are heartbreaking and hard to look at, but they are incredibly important. Itâ€™s not always an easy visit emotionally, but thatâ€™s part of what makes it so meaningful.
Outside, thereâ€™s a display of tanks, helicopters, and fighter planes, which adds to the scale and reality of what happened. Inside, you move through rooms that tell different parts of the story, from the roots of the war to the protests around the world and the aftermath thatâ€™s still felt today.

The museum isnâ€™t about taking sides. Itâ€™s about remembering the human cost of war and learning from the past. It's also a reminder of how resilient people can be. I really appreciated how respectful and thoughtful the space felt, and how it encourages reflection rather than judgment.

If you're in Ho Chi Minh City, this museum is a must-visit. Itâ€™s not just about history, itâ€™s about empathy and understanding. Give yourself time to take it all in. Itâ€™s not something youâ€™ll want to rush.

This museum is more than just a record of history â€” it carries the deep pain and sorrow of humanity. Once inside, I felt the preciousness of human life and the profound wounds caused by war. The museum serves as a powerful reminder that we must strive for peace in the world.

A powerful and well-curated glimpse into Vietnam's history. The preserved war remnants tell compelling storiesâ€”both haunting and inspiring. A must-visit for anyone wanting to reflect on the past and appreciate the sacrifices that shaped the present.
It was an interesting trip down to memory lane, added learning to understand the history and culture of Vietnam. Definitely add it to your bucket list if youâ€™re visiting Ho Chi Minh.

Visiting war remnants museum in ho chi Minh City was informative as well as emotional experience. We saw the what war could do to the people. How tough and resilient local people were against americans.

You would never even guess the amount of atrocities the Americans committed in VIetnam. This is the place where this has been documented, with evidence and photographs. Extensive collection on the use of Agent Orange as well. Takes 1-2 hours to finish if you look at all floors. Independent photographers collection is amazing.

Museum on the History of the Vietnam War. Numerous exhibits in the outdoor area as well as within the building. On the left side you can see how the prisoners were treated. In the middle part of the exhibition, numerous photos can be seen showing the horrors of war and the suffering of the various people. Certainly not everything is suitable for children. All in all, a very objective account of the Vietnam conflict shows what war means for the affected people, no matter which side.

Heart wrenching stories of the Vietnam war. I would suggest people to go to second floor and start from the room 1. We went from ground floor and itâ€™s not the correct way. You will surely cry when you come out of the rooms. I wish no more wars in the world. Everyone deserves to live the life the like.

A very good must see museum from the (North) Vietnamese view of the war, however it is extremely confronting and there is no way to describe the sheer scale of the battle lines and the horrific trauma on all Vietnamese peoples during this time. Overall I would suggest visiting as it doesnâ€™t sanitise and gives an appreciation of how terrible warfare is.

The museum brings home the suffering that regular civilians endured during the conflict.

The atrocities committed, the wide spread use of chemicals against a poor population and the enduring suffering for so many people years after the fighting ended, highlights the futility and pointlessness of the war.

Definitly a place i would recommand to unterstand more about the history of the country, even if you are not a history nut. No need to book a ticket before, its 40k VND per person, we waited 5min in the queue at 12am

Tourists must come here to closely understand and emphasize with Vietnamese people & their history and the pain they have gone through, colonial crimes & war crimes been passed generation to generation and treated like experimental rats by Americans. Of course propaganda is an usual thing you will see in museum like this. But I admit that if you already watched documentaries about Viet Nam war, or part of it, you will be satisfied with your subjectivity. Ticket is cheap (1.5USD), I want to pay more so they could expand the sites and more room to display.

A must see place to visit. Very touching!

The entrance is only 40K pp and itâ€™s totally worth it. In my opinion this place is a must visit if you ever come to HCMC because it tells in so many details about the war and its history. Besides that, for all the westerns itâ€™s an opportunity to get some knowledge besides that spread and teach in schools. I must say itâ€™s a very dense visiting. I spent about 3h and wasnâ€™t able to read everything

War Remnants museum is reminding us of the war days of Vietnam against the US.There is a great peace of exhibition i.e tank,missiles and plenty of pictures are put in us in those days and we feel pride How Vietnamese are resilient .A must visit this historical monument.

Certainly worth the visit. It gives you a real and raw perspective on the Vietnam War. Included in the exhibition is a section capturing photos of the carnage of the War including the Pultizer prize winning shot of the Vietnamese girl burned when the US napalm bombed Vietnam.

It was sobering and yet so important for any tourist to understand the impact of War on innocent lives! This year was the 50th year of the end of the the War!
Moving and inspiring giving the current Vietnam. My respect and admiration for the people Vietnam has increased even more, even though it was pretty high already.
What happened during this war is heartbreaking. Learning more about it gives you such an insight to how hard Vietnamese people fought for freedom. A trip to the Chu Chi Tunnels is a must too.

Highly recommended doing it that way over just rocking up on a whim. As mentioned above, it was difficult to actually stand and read all the info, so having a private guide was certainly worth it!

There is lots of pictures to look and weapon plus ammunition the one thing this place needs or that others usually have is a Thanks section where there give thanks or recognise the help form other countries eg ANZAC they only show enemies.
A must do in HCMC, learned a lot about the Vietnam War, be aware that some photos hurts, I was not ready for that but you have to visit ! For the historyâ€¦

Recommended. Nice exposition of aircrafts, tanks, helicopters, weapons. Very illustrative museum, with plenty of information.
Good to learn about Vietnam war, but remember that war museums always shows one part of the history, the coin has always 2 sides ðŸ¤“

Exceptional collections of remnants/ memorabilia.  Gives one the true story of the war and not just the Americanized version that is so well known. Makes one appreciate the struggles of the Vietnamese and the hard won freedom.

Impressive and shocking museum ever I visited before. There are plenty of things that you can learn about the history of Vietnam on 20 Century. We didnâ€™t expect this kind of museum. But it was really impressive and helpful to understand and learn about the misery of war and suppress of people. But you need to prepare your children to encounter exhibits. The exhibition is fact and part of history but it is too violent for kids. My daughter was frightened and crying when she met some pictures. If I knew that, I would prepare it.

Wow. A fascinating and emotional experience highlighting the atrocities of the Vietnam War. Very informative and organised. There are some distressing moments. But an absolute must visit when in Ho Chi Minh.

Visited here. Word of warning âš ï¸ It can be quite a harrowing visit, especially the Agent Orange effects exhibition. Despite that, it's quite an enlightening experience. Recommended but have at least 3 hrs.free to do it justice.
Definitely worth visiting when you visit HCM. Usually, you can get the tickets online, but we are able to get it at the Venue without any complications.
Very reasonable entrance fee, amazing exposition of US military equipment from 60's and lots of stories to hear out.
Remember to go to every floor. Amazing museum, and the history tells you a lot about the suffering that the Vietnamese faced during the Vietnam War. Stop War!!

Lots of really interesting stuff here. Add some buffer to however much time you plan on spending here, especially if you're into this kinda thing. Coffee onsite that you can bring into the museum which I appreciated given the heat.

Very interesting museum with a lot of thought provoking moments throughout. Definitely a must visit if in Ho Chi Minh. I arrived early but when I was leaving there was a very large queue so advise would be to go early

Before coming here, I thought i knew everything i needed to know about the  Vietnam war. I knew there were war crimes comitted but i never really understood the gravity of the situation until my recent visit. It was heavy and heart wrenching going through the well documented American atrocities on the civilian population, especially on the children looking severely frightened as they are held by their elderly grandmother moments before they were murdered in cold blood. Nothing can prepare you emotionally seeing photos of lifeless infants, stiff, bloodied and riddled with gunshots lying on the street. What did he do? You keep asking yourself.

Yet you can't help reflect why humanity never learns. I still think about it alot, especially at this time when the same is being done on the Children of Gaza. We just stood, watched, and cry about it in a future museum somewhere to serve as a reminder. Yet the reminder was simply just a reminder, not a lesson to learn from.

Amazing big museum about the VN war with US army. How they Vietcong destroy the stupid US army, which never win a war in history ðŸ˜‚ poor USA ðŸ‘ðŸ»

Very interesting museum. It was very detailed and full on. Many pictures and stories were shared and displayed. Itâ€™s not for the light hearted. I needed something to cheer me up afterwards. So many awful stories what the Vietnamese had to live through

This was well worth the money ($40k) to visit. You can use your credit card to pay separately from the ticket dispenser next to the cashier. You learn about their war history especially agent orange - very sad. Might be a little too graphic for the younger audiences.
A really insightful place to visit and an important part of Vietnams history displayed. Wouldnâ€™t recommend the 2nd and 3rd floors for children due to distressing images.
Worth a visit to see full exhibit of the Vietnam War. Some parts have very brutal pictures of death and destruction.

I was overwhelmed for the better part of 4 hours. I immersed myself in all the history presented in these carefully catered exhibitions, and allowed myself to feel everything that arose, even the guilt for my ignorance and oblivion to some of the biggest atrocities ever played out in history.

It's fascinating how, in our little comfortable white previlege bubble, we so easily consume any information we are presented with and even make entertainment out of it (i.e Hollywood movies), mindlessly gorging on biased content, creating dualistic views of the world.

Yet, when I see some of us coming into a place like this, realising they come from a country (to no fault of their own) that was the true perpetrator, and getting overwhelmed with pain and shame, thus having to leave the place "because they can't handle it", is a notorious reflection of how society has come to be.

When you come into a place like this, the minimum you can do is allow yourself to feel the pain, to suffer, to cry, to be uncomfortable, to sit with all the emotions and reflect. We all owe it to these people, the unmeasurable human pain and suffering that took place not so long ago, from which impacts are still affecting current generations.

Whatever you may feel in there, will not amount to a sliver of the smallest amount of pain lived by these brave people, these fighters. So stay, respect the place, read, take your time, and FEEL. It's the only gesture you can make that truly can make a difference because the only way to change repeating history is by moving our hearts.
you MUST pay the extra for the recorded guide headset, it changes everything for your understanding of what truly happened, Very sobering, to see the atrocities committed.

The place is quite unique and especially if you are into understanding the origins of modern Vietnam this is the best place. It accurately depicts the reasons and more importantly the depth of impact of the war. It takes you on an incredible journey of their history and how they fought for their freedom. Please take around 2 to 3 hours to enjoy the entire journey.

Well worth a visit. This was a big event in the history of the country. And if you think it only finished 50 years ago! Iâ€™ve grown up only knowing one side of the story, but as usual there are two sides. Thereâ€™s an interesting article about an American senator that served in Vietnam. Ive added some photos for interest. Thereâ€™s a large indoors exhibition. The tiger cages were not what I was expecting.
I would definitely recommend..it's a hard read and watch but it gives you a no holds bard of what actually happened during the war...
Heartbreaking !!! Every American should visit this place to understand what kind of war crimes they committed. I will share the "light" pictures, when you see the hard once you will be shocked !

War Remnants Museum, Saigon

A very impressive and moving museum. The exhibits on war crimes and the devastating impact of Agent Orange are especially powerful and painful to see. It's a difficult but important reminder of the human cost of war. Everyone should visit this place to understand history better. Sadly, it also makes you reflect on how little humanity seems to learn from the past.

My experience at the war remnants museum was extremely emotional. Sometimes I felt like looking away from the depressing photos but still made myself look as the experiences and events the people have gone through is not to be forgotten.
In the left side in the front of the museum there is a small place which shows the cages and torture methods that were inflicted on the people imprisoned. I would really recommend to look for it as it is easy to miss.

The vietnam war is a horrific part of human history and the museum does a fantastic job of being that to light. Ir is quite graphic and confronting but to show was happened in the war it is necessary.

If you want to learn about this tragic war, this is the spot! Very nice museum in the center of downtown. Outdoor and indoor exhibits with a decent shop for gifts. I was there with friends who are locals, have to admit some parts were very emotional. Makes you appreciate the fact I have never had to experience such a war in my lifetime.

I was horrified by what I learned today.  I only knew that America sent 19 year old to Vietnam to fight, and the Americans were up in arms today.  Learning about he absolute horror of the atrocities inflicted on the civilians, the shocking way men,women, and children were gunned down in cold blood and the pain and suffering from napalm bombs, was absolutely sickening.  I went to Auschwitz not long ago, and i truly believe Vietnam was the American's Auschwitz.   I truly hope that those who carried out those  war crimes were held accountable and made to pay.
The only good thing today, was the art gallery with the children's paintings about soldiers. My 11 year old Grephew said, "The pictures have a lot of meaning."
Great activity for a great price. Horrifying to see how bad the war really was. Great learning experience. If youâ€™re in ho chi minh, you must go

(Very smooth self service ticket machine, we went on a cloudy monday. Big museum with many different segments. AC/fan in every  closed space.)
Easy to purchase entry tickets. Enjoyed the history of the Vietnam War. I feel the presentations and sharing are raw (alot of reading expected).

It is a really cool place. I will admit it nearly brought me to tears. The price is fair. And there is so mucho see. My favourite was all the tanks and planes. And the huge array of weapons on display.

Get ready for some serious truths about the war. And the struggle of the people.  Sad but a must see

Must visit place in Hoh Chi Min city.. its a treasure of information regarding the war fought in vietnam.. it shows the photos of the struggle of the Vietnamese people during the war period... outside the collection of fighter jets and tanks with varieties of helicopters used by US during the war period....

Went there in the morning and was already quite busy. The place looks well maintained, nice set up and we decided to rent the headset guided "tour". The only issue (just my opinion) is that all was a bit chaotic, bit difficult to find the right storyline, which is rather important. Nevertheless, all what was displayed was interesting, some images were pretty shocking but it is showing the brutal reality on what happened during, but eventually important, also what happened after the war.
The visit is anywhere between 1 to 3 hours, depending on how deep you want to go.

A very interesting museum with plenty of information, photos, and artifacts about the Vietnam War and its aftermath. A big plus: all texts are also available in English, making it easy to follow along. The exhibition feels factual and not propagandistic, allowing for a thoughtful engagement with the subject. A powerful and thought-provoking place: highly recommended for anyone interested in history.

Primarily about the American atrocities from the Vietnamese side. There is always 2 sides to a story as you will see if you go to the Cu Chi tunnels. There are a few military exhibitions but primarily, it is photographs and stories.  Not expensive to go in so well worth a visit. Saw someone visibly moved to tears, so be prepared.
Very good museum to visit and learn about the war and history. Some very disturbing images.
Great and touristic place by all means. I have to say that I felt pain in my heart when I visited the museum. Canâ€™t believe how those people suffered to get their independence.
A great place to know about the history of US invasion in Vietnam.Hope a peaceful world

Another reminder of the evils of war & human conflict. Nothing like unleashing the dogs of war to reveal the depravities of human nature.
The museum is well done in terms of the exhibits. Much thought and energy has gone into preserving the memories and highlighting the lessons learned. The public forgets easily.
It shows all the stuff that went on in the Vietnam war kind of sad but very informative very knowledgeable. Glad I went.

Oh my gosh this museum shook me to the core! Very painful yet very real â€” it shows the incalculable cost of the Vietnam War, of any war. Visiting this museum is something that everyone must experience to deepen their understanding of humanity.
Great place knowledge and history about wars and must try cu chi tunnels and fire sone ak 47 and machine guns

Beautifully designed. Kept up in great shape. You can see the entire palace, all the rooms and their functions, and everything very well explained. It tells the story of a very interesting time of Vietnam's history.

Visiting the Independence Palace was a  fascinating experience. Walking through the historic halls and rooms, I could really imagine about the important events that took place there.  Addtional, i used to use the audio guide that was a really helpful experience. It gave me clear and detailed explanations, so I could understand the history and meaning behind them. The instructions were easy to follow, It felt like having a personal tour guide with me, and it made the visit more interesting and meaningful.

The Independence Palace is worth a quick visit for its history and architecture, but honestly I donâ€™t think the audio guide is worth buying. There are already plenty of signs and information around, so you can still understand the place without it.

Itâ€™s definitely a spot filled with history, and you get a sense of the important events that happened here. A good stop if youâ€™re exploring District 1, but Iâ€™d recommend just walking around on your own.

Entry fee was 80,000, so not expensive
Tour the Historic Rooms: Explore the president's office, state rooms, and war command room.
View Artifacts and Exhibits: See historical objects and photographs from the Vietnam War era.
Walk Through the Gardens: Enjoy the beautifully landscaped grounds surrounding the palace.

A must-see for anyone curious about Vietnam's modern history.

Wow. You go back in time here with very well preserved rooms and furniture. It's exactly how it was in the days. Many symbolic events took place here. The bunker is brilliant. If you want to go back in history, this is the place to visit.

Very good place to visit for a couple of hours. Will always be remembered for the tanks bursting through the gates and the helicopter taking staff ect from the roof during the final day of war. Entrance fee 80k vnd per adult.

Independence Palace in Ho Chi Minh City is a must-visit if you are interested in Vietnamâ€™s modern history. It played a central role during the Vietnam War, serving as the headquarters of the South Vietnamese government. This is also the place where the war officially ended on April 30, 1975, when tanks of the North Vietnamese army broke through its gates, marking the fall of Saigon.

The place gives a unique glimpse into the lifestyle of the ruling family and the political atmosphere of the time. While the architecture looks more like a government complex designed to host international guests rather than a royal palace, the historical importance of this site makes it very memorable and valuable to visit.

There are many historical exhibitions.
The facility is 3 stories and you can take pictures where ever you want.
I did buy tickets at entrance price of 80.000 including museum admission fee.

Also incide of the palace they do sell beaverage.
Water 15.000

There are different ticket prices at the counter if you buy it on arrival, they called it foreigner price. The Vietnamese guy behind me even speak out and said "this is how it's work here".
You can buy a normal price, just one local price on Klook app.
We only want to go see the bunker room. Very tight, narrow, hot and busy space.
The shooting room is pretty cool.

Visited the Independence Palace in Ho Chi Minh City and it was such a fascinating experience! ðŸ‡»ðŸ‡³âœ¨ The place is full of history and gives you a real sense of the countryâ€™s past. Everything is very clean and well preserved, and the staff were friendly and helpful throughout the visit.

Itâ€™s not just educational but also really impressive to walk through the different rooms and halls. Definitely a must-see when youâ€™re in Ho Chi Minh City! ðŸŒŸ

I recently visited Independence Palace, and I must say, the experience was quite memorable. The palace is absolutely huge much bigger than I had expected. It felt like I was walking through a never ending maze of grand halls, historic rooms, and long corridors. After a while, I actually started to feel tired from all the walking! If youâ€™re planning to explore the entire palace, definitely wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to spend a good few hours there.

One thing I noticed and something that did affect the experience was that many parts of the palace didnâ€™t have air conditioning. Given how hot and humid the weather was during my visit, it got quite uncomfortable in several sections. Some rooms were noticeably stuffy, and at times I found myself rushing through just to get back to cooler areas.

That said, the architecture and historical significance of the palace are undeniable. The design is both elegant and symbolic, and each room seems to hold a story of its own. I especially enjoyed the presidential meeting rooms and the war command center in the basement both were fascinating glimpses into Vietnamâ€™s past.

Overall, while the lack of AC in many areas made the visit a bit exhausting, the sheer scale, historical richness, and grandeur of the Independence Palace still made it worth the trip. Iâ€™d recommend it, but maybe plan your visit during cooler parts of the day.

Well presented and well organized. Easy to self-tour without the audio guide. The film in the basement is very informative too. Available in multiple languages. The bunker was the least impressive place.
Impressive historical site with beautiful architecture and well-preserved rooms. A great place to learn about Vietnamâ€™s history and the Vietnam War. Worth a visit!

.

We paid around 160 VND for two persons, which I felt was not worth it. Parking is  available inside premises.

I would not recommend it.

This is also another place for you to add to your places to visit when you come to Ho Chin Minh City.

Beautiful architecture and design, rich in history, this place os a must when you are around!

The Independence Palace doesnâ€™t just display historyâ€”it *lives* it. From the moment you step inside, it feels like time has paused somewhere in the 1960s and 70s. The long wooden conference table still lined with high-backed chairs seems ready for another urgent cabinet meeting. The vintage telephone quietly rests on the presidentâ€™s desk, as if waiting for one more critical call. The private cinema, the war command room with old radio equipment, even the underground escape tunnelsâ€”all whisper stories of a country once divided and the people who made bold decisions in those very rooms. The architecture itself speaks volumes: wide, open hallways reflect the ideals of transparency and progress, while the fusion of Eastern motifs and modernist design captures a Vietnam standing at the crossroads of tradition and change. Walking through the palace feels like walking through chapters of a living history bookâ€”each room, each piece of furniture, a storyteller in its own right.

The Reunification Palace (Independence Palace) in District 1, Ho Chi Minh City, stands as a majestic historical landmark, once serving as the residence and workplace of former presidents of South Vietnam.

Its grand architecture, blending modern and classical styles, captivates visitors with sprawling halls, lush gardens, and an aura of timeless elegance. The palace is not only a visual masterpiece but also a treasure trove of Vietnamâ€™s turbulent past, offering a vivid glimpse into the nationâ€™s history.

For just a few tens of thousands of VND, the affordable voice-guided tour is a highlight, narrating the stories behind each room, from opulent reception areas to strategic meeting chambers.

The journey takes you through the palaceâ€™s upper floors, adorned with intricate decor, before descending into the secretive basement. This underground bunker, a wartime command center, reveals a fascinating network of tunnels and control rooms, evoking the intensity of Vietnamâ€™s conflict-ridden era. The contrast between the lavish upper levels and the stark, utilitarian bunker underscores the palaceâ€™s historical significance.

Visiting the Reunification Palace is a must for anyone seeking to understand Vietnamâ€™s political and cultural heritage. Its well-preserved rooms and immersive storytelling make history come alive. Whether youâ€™re a history enthusiast or a curious traveler, this iconic site offers an unforgettable experience, blending beauty, education, and intrigue.

A trip here is a journey through time, leaving you with a deeper appreciation for Vietnamâ€™s resilient spirit and storied past.

Independence Palace (also known as Reunification Palace) is a must-visit landmark in Ho Chi Minh City, especially if you're interested in Vietnamese history. This was the former presidential residence and the site where the Vietnam War officially ended in 1975, when a North Vietnamese tank crashed through its gates.

The building is very well preserved. You can walk through meeting rooms, the presidentâ€™s office, living quarters, and even a war command bunker in the basement. Each room is kept as it was decades ago, with original furniture, maps, and communication equipment still in place.

Outside, the palace is surrounded by a large, peaceful garden. The open green space, old tanks on display, and wide courtyard make it a pleasant place to explore.

There are guided tours available or you can walk at your own pace. Information signs in English and Vietnamese help you understand each section.

âœ… If you're in Saigon, this is more than just a tourist stop â€” itâ€™s a window into the countryâ€™s past.
Allow 1â€“2 hours for the full experience.

As a traveler deeply moved by culture and history, visitingÂ Independence PalaceÂ in Ho Chi Minh City was one of the most powerful experiences during my trip through Vietnam. This iconic landmark, once the residence of South Vietnamâ€™s president, became the symbol of national reunification when tanks rolled through its gates onÂ April 30, 1975â€”a moment that marked the end of the Vietnam War and the beginning of a unified nation.
Walking through its halls, you feel the weight of history. The preserved war rooms, vintage communications gear, and elegant 1960s architecture offer a rare glimpse into a pivotal time. The lush gardens and open spaces add a sense of peace and reflectionâ€”so different from the turmoil the building once witnessed. April 30th, now celebrated asÂ Reunification Day, brings the palace to life with local pride. Flags wave, families gather, and the stories of resilience and peace echo louder. It's a deeply moving day to be there and feel the spirit of Vietnamâ€”strong, unified, and full of hope. If you're traveling through Vietnam, donâ€™t miss this site. Itâ€™s more than just a buildingâ€”itâ€™s a living chapter of the nationâ€™s soul!

Bargaining is common hereâ€”if you negotiate politely, prices can drop significantly, so good bargaining skills really help!

Visited a few years ago with my family. It was an eye opener because on Fri Sat and Sun evenings, all the roads were closed for people to enjoy.

And it is organised by section, with each section catering to the interests of different age groups.

Toddlers can drive toy cars and play uno stackers on the closed roads.

Kids a little older can do arts and crafts and play games.

Teenagers and young adults can dance and sing with their instruments or busker, play ball games, play chartek, tug of war or just sit around to chill with their pets.

Older adults and elderly have their own sections to do rock and roll and ballroom dancing.

And much more.

I felt the community spirit as the local people reached out to welcome me to join in and i did.

We should have this in all cities to promote social harmony.

There are many shops, cafes, eateries and very beautiful hotels (local and international) in the old quarters. I recommend staying there over the weekends and in local hotels. The service and food are impeccable.

Hanoi Old Quarter is an unforgettable experience and the vibrant heart of Vietnamâ€™s capital. Walking through its maze-like streets feels like traveling through time â€” a place where history, culture, and everyday life blend seamlessly. The narrow alleys are packed with energy, motorbikes weaving through the crowd, colonial-era architecture, ancient temples, and a sense of organized chaos thatâ€™s uniquely Hanoi.

Each street tells its own story, often named after the trade or craft once practiced there â€” from Silk Street to Silver Street. The local food scene is unbeatable! You can grab a bowl of authentic pho, bite into a flavorful banh mi, or sip on Hanoiâ€™s famous egg coffee in one of the many hidden cafÃ©s.

Shopping is a true adventure â€” filled with markets, souvenir stalls, and tiny shops selling everything from handcrafted items to trendy clothes. Bargaining is expected, so bring your best negotiating skills.

At night, the atmosphere becomes even more electric. Ta Hien Street is perfect for a cold beer, and the nearby Hoan Kiem Lake offers a peaceful escape amidst the buzz. Donâ€™t miss the water puppet shows for a taste of traditional Vietnamese entertainment. A must-visit destination that captures the soul of Vietnam!

Hanoi Old Quarter is the heart and soul of Vietnamâ€™s capital, offering a perfect mix of history, culture, and energy. Walking through its narrow streets feels like stepping into a different worldâ€”one filled with charming colonial buildings, ancient temples, and the constant buzz of motorbikes. Each street is unique, often named after the traditional craft once sold there, like Silk Street or Silver Street.

The food here is incredible! From famous pho (Vietnamese noodle soup) to delicious banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich), the street food vendors serve some of the best meals youâ€™ll ever eat. Donâ€™t forget to try the famous egg coffee at one of the many cozy cafÃ©s.

Shopping in the Old Quarter is also an adventure. Markets and small shops sell everything from souvenirs to handmade crafts at bargain prices. Be ready to practice your bargaining skills!

Despite the hustle and bustle, Hanoi Old Quarter has a unique charm. Whether youâ€™re watching a traditional water puppet show, enjoying a beer at Ta Hien Street, or simply wandering around Hoan Kiem Lake, thereâ€™s always something exciting to see. Hanoi's Old Quarter is a vibrant and historic area that captures the essence of Vietnam's capital city. Known for its narrow streets, bustling markets, and centuries-old architecture, the Old Quarter offers a unique blend of tradition and modernity. Each street is traditionally named after the goods or crafts that were once sold there, adding a layer of cultural depth to the experience.

Visitors can explore a variety of attractions, from ancient temples and pagodas to charming cafes and boutique shops. The area is also a haven for food lovers, with countless street vendors and restaurants serving iconic Vietnamese dishes like pho, banh mi, and egg coffee. The night market, held on weekends, is a lively spot for shopping and sampling local delicacies.

The Old Quarter's lively atmosphere is complemented by its rich history, making it a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Hanoi. Whether you're wandering through its maze-like streets, enjoying a cyclo ride, or simply soaking in the vibrant energy, the Old Quarter offers an unforgettable glimpse into the heart of Hanoi's culture and heritage.

When you visit Hanoi, I highly recommend spending time in the Old Quarter. This historic heart of the city is a fascinating blend of the past and the present, featuring narrow streets each traditionally dedicated to a specific trade, such as silk, spices, or handicrafts.

And make sure also venture out of the district to other parts of Hanoi.

Begin your exploration at Hoan Kiem Lake, ideally in the early morning for a tranquil experience. The lake is a central piece of the Old Quarter and is home to the charming Ngoc Son Temple, situated on a small island.

Donâ€™t miss the opportunity to visit Dong Xuan Market, Hanoi's largest indoor market, where you can immerse yourself in the vibrant local culture and shop for everything from souvenirs to fresh produce.

Make sure to visit St. Josephâ€™s Cathedral to witness a stunning example of Hanoiâ€™s French colonial architecture and enjoy a moment of peace in its serene interior.

The culinary scene in the Old Quarter is not to be overlooked. Indulge in authentic Vietnamese street food, including dishes like Pho, Bun Cha, and the unique Egg Coffee.

If your visit falls over a weekend, the Night Market on Hang Dao Street is a must-see. Itâ€™s perfect for experiencing the lively atmosphere and picking up unique local items.

The Old Quarter is not just a place to visit, but an experience to be lived. It offers a profound glimpse into the dynamic fusion of historical charm and bustling city life in Hanoi

The Old Quarter (Vietnamese: Phá»‘ cá»• HÃ  Ná»™i) is the name commonly given to the historical civic urban core of Hanoi, Vietnam, located outside the Imperial Citadel of ThÄƒng Long. This quarter used to be the residential, manufacturing and commercial center, where each street was specialized in one specific type of manufacturing or commerce.
The residential and commercial area that is now the Old Quarter came to be during the LÃ½ and Tráº§n dynasties and was then located east of the Imperial Citadel of ThÄƒng Long and along the Red River. During the LÃª dynasty, scholar Nguyá»…n TrÃ£i already mentioned some of the areas each specialized in one particular trade. It was then surrounded by a defensive wall with several gates.
During the LÃª dynasty, the area included several lakes and wetlands, the largest of which was ThÃ¡i Cá»±c lake. These lakes, as well as the TÃ´ Lá»‹ch River were connected with HoÃ n Kiáº¿m lake and the Red River. Near the end of the 19th century these lakes and rivers became isolated from each other.
During the LÃ½ and Tráº§n dynasties, many people from the surrounding plains migrated to the city and settled in what is now the Old Quarter, creating the densest urban area of the city. The LÃª dynasty period saw an additional influx of Chinese immigrants who arrived to trade, creating several Chinese neighbourhoods..
When the French ruled over Vietnam, they partially rebuilt the area. This period saw many French and Indians settling there to conduct business. Two small markets were demolished to make place for Äá»“ng XuÃ¢n Market. Furthermore, a tramway was constructed through the quarter.
The area is still the commercial heart of Hanoi.

One of the experiences I looked forward to the most before going to Hanoi was visiting Hoa Lo Prison, and it didn't disappoint. The museum is thoroughly educational and really gives you a sense of what life was like there, and shares a lot about those who were imprisoned there from French colonial rule, until during the duration of the Vietnamese-American War.

I have to say that the Vietnamese truly do have deep commitment to and extreme talent in preserving these historical artifacts and turning them into an educational experience. Not all countries or cultures are this invested in taking the trauma and turmoil from their past and turning it into a lesson. It's been two weeks since we came home from Vietnam and I still find myself thinking about the displays there: the clothes used by prisoners, the torture items, the stories we read. It was extremely eye-opening and reminded me of the effects of war on us all.

At the end of the exhibit, you can light an incense stick for the soul of those who passed during the war, and those who passed in Hoa Lo Prison.

There is an option to get a human guide or an audio guide, but we opted to go without either. It was still an educational experience. Tickets were 50k dong I think, and you would need an hour and a half to soak up the whole exhibit.

A Profound Journey Through Vietnamâ€™s History

Visiting Hoa Lo Prison was a deeply moving experience. The museum offers a stark and powerful glimpse into Vietnamâ€™s turbulent past, from its days under French colonial rule to the Vietnam War. Walking through the preserved cells and exhibits, I was struck by the resilience and courage of those who endured unimaginable hardships within these walls. The displays are informative and thought-provoking, providing insight into the struggles for independence and the complexities of war. Itâ€™s a sobering reminder of the cost of freedom and the strength of the human spirit. A must-visit for anyone seeking to understand Vietnamâ€™s rich and challenging history.

Há»a LÃ² Prison (Hanoi, Vietnam) â€” Built by the French in 1896 to house Vietnamese political prisoners, this grim colonial jail later became infamous during the Vietnam War when captured U.S. pilots were held here and nicknamed it the â€œHanoi Hilton.â€ Today, only part of the original prison remains, preserved as a museum. Visitors can walk through eerie cells, see escape tunnels, and learn the stories of both Vietnamese revolutionaries and American POWs â€” a stark reminder of the resilience and suffering of those who passed through its gates.

That said, it is still a fascinating and important place to visit. The museum powerfully shows the suffering and resilience of the Vietnamese people during decades of war. I have deep sympathy for what they endured, and itâ€™s a moving reminder of the human cost of conflict â€” on all sides.

As one who needs a shot of cultural education during his travels, this was a must-do for me. HIGHLY RECOMMEND to get the audio guide, itâ€™s easy to use and disinfected when it gets to you. Light and portable. A good mid-day activity to rest in the shade/indoors with a number of good air con spots.

Hoa Lo Prison Museum is a fascinating and at times very intense place to visit. As a first-time tourist in Vietnam, I found it both informative and emotional, giving a deep look into the countryâ€™s history. The museum shows what life was like for Vietnamese prisoners during the French colonial period and later for American soldiers during the Vietnam War.

A large part of the exhibitions focus on communist revolutionary prisoners, their struggles, teaching, escapes, and the revolts that took place inside the prison. The top floor highlights famous revolutionary figures and lists the names of many who were imprisoned here. Personally, I felt this section was a bit too heavy on political propaganda, but it is still an important perspective of the history.

The entry price is reasonable. If you go, I strongly recommend paying extra for the audio guide. Many items are not explained with signs, and the guide really brings context and stories to life. Just note that it uses a wired headset (not AirPods or Bluetooth), so sharing one between two people is not possible.

Visiting on a weekday, it was not very crowded, which made the experience even more engaging and easier to take in.

An outstanding display of the 100 year history of the prison. Very informative displays and artifacts from when the French used the facility to imprison and torture Vietnamese revolutionaries. Also very informative of its use by the Vietnamese as the "Hanoi Hilton" to imprison downed American pilots. (No mention of their torture.) The museum contains a tear jerking memorial to the fallen civilians of the 12 day bombing campaign of Hanoi by Nixon in 1972.

This is a place every American should see and wonder how did our politicians allow this to happen.

Hoa Lo Prison is a must visit if you are in Hanoi.

Hoa Lo Prison â€“ A Place of Profound Historical Significance

Hoa Lo Prison, often referred to as the â€œHanoi Hiltonâ€ during the Vietnam War, holds undeniable historical importance. A visit here offers a sobering and thought-provoking look into Vietnamâ€™s tumultuous past, spanning from its colonial struggles against the French to the Vietnam War. However, the quality of the experience largely depends on how you choose to engage with the museum.

To truly appreciate the depth of this site, I strongly recommend using the audio guide. It allows you to explore the exhibits at your own pace, immersing yourself in the narratives of those who lived, fought, and suffered here. The stories of the Vietnamese revolutionaries who endured brutal conditions under French colonial rule and the American POWs held during the war are presented with a balance of emotional resonance and factual depth. The audio guide adds nuance to the exhibits, enriching your understanding of the prisonâ€™s dual role as a symbol of resilience and propaganda.

That said, the experience can be diminished by large tourist groups with guides. The confined nature of the former cells and hallways becomes overwhelming when crowded, and the noise from these groups can disrupt the solemn atmosphere that this site deserves. For this reason, I recommend planning your visit during off-peak hours or using noise-canceling headphones to stay immersed in the experience.

The museum itself is well-curated, with artifacts such as letters, photographs, and personal items that humanize the historical accounts. The juxtaposition of the harrowing French colonial period and the more politically complex Vietnam War era invites visitors to reflect on the layers of history embedded within this site.

While Hoa Lo Prison may not offer the grandeur of larger historical sites, its emotional and intellectual weight makes it a must-visit for those interested in understanding Vietnamâ€™s history. Approach it with curiosity, sensitivity, and a willingness to delve into the difficult realities of the past, and youâ€™ll find it to be a deeply rewarding experience.
The museum layout is well organised, but it can get pretty crowded esp with big organised tours.
I really enjoyed visiting this museum, it shows us how difficult life could be there during the french colonialists era

It's a great museum, we really get to step into history which is very touching.
Don't hesitate if you pass by!
We paid around â‚¬1.75 for the adult ticket.

Visiting this place is an intense experience. The history is explained quite well with exhibits that give you a good sense of the depravity the (mostly political) prisoners were subjected to. The American POWS (e.g. Shot down in B52 bombers) were also kept here for a short while. They were the ones to give this place its nickname of the Hanoi Hilton.

I learned a lot about the prisonersâ€™ lives, their unfathomably horrible living conditions, along with the prisonâ€™s history dating back from the French Colonialism to the 60s when the American was bombing the Northern Vietnam. There were also many historical specimens and photographs to see, which gave me chills.
You should definitely check this place out when visiting Ha Noi.

A deeply moving and eye-opening experience. The museum is well laid out, with clear explanations in English and Vietnamese, and the audio guide adds powerful personal stories to the history. Walking through the old cells, seeing original artifacts, and learning about both the French colonial era and the Vietnam War was sobering yet fascinating. Highly recommend visiting early in the day for a quieter, more reflective experience. An important stop in Hanoi for anyone wanting to understand the countryâ€™s past.

Hoa Lo Prison is a must-visit if you're in Hanoi and want to understand the country's modern history. The museum is well-curated, with emotional displays about the harsh conditions Vietnamese revolutionaries endured under French colonial rule. The contrast with the American POW section is striking. Itâ€™s not just a museumâ€”itâ€™s a reminder of resilience, struggle, and survival. Give yourself at least an hour to take it all in.

The Há»a LÃ² Prison Museum (â€œHanoi Hiltonâ€) is an important and deeply moving historical site. The exhibits are thoughtfully arranged and give valuable insight into Vietnamâ€™s colonial and wartime history. Visiting this place leaves a strong impression and helps to understand the complexity of that period.

However, it is regrettable that the narrative presented about the treatment of prisoners of war does not fully reflect historical reality. The museum suggests that all captives were treated humanely, yet documented evidence shows otherwise.

A striking example is Monika Schwinn (who is mentioned prominently in the museum), a German nurse working for a humanitarian organization to help the suffering local civilians in South Vietnam. In 1969, she and four colleagues were abducted by Vietcong forces; three of them died within the first weeks of captivity. Despite Schwinnâ€™s clear status as medical personnel protected under the Geneva Conventions, she and the surviving doctor Bernhard Diehl were detained for years in this very prison and held hostageâ€” a measure clearly contrary to international law. The museumâ€™s story on how well she was treated even allowing her to have a cat is a mockery of the inhuman treatment she suffered.

While the museum is well worth visiting, it would gain much in credibility and educational value if it also acknowledged such documented violations and presented a more balanced account of history.
Very moving exhibit.  This museum tells a very important and very sad  history of Vietnam people, the  autrocities of the French and the Vietnam War.

Along the way to different areas of the prison, you can listen to the main points of the historical things, people and places. It  was a very interesting trip back to the past but also it made people feel sad about what happened during the war. At the end of the trip, you should stop at the bang tree to know its message to you and try the tea and milk tea made from bang leaves. The trees are historical and they experienced everything with the prisoners. If you want to see the night show, you should book it in advance. I recommend booking the show at least 2 months before your trip via their facebook page.

If you haven't been to a similar venue, this place might be really interesting for you. As I have seen a couple of these places, I have to say this is not one of the better ones.

Being immersive: Many rooms have mirrors. Even if you are alone in a room, you see yourself a dozen times (mirrors in mirrors), which made me uncomfortable - you are alone but you don't feel so. Mirrors at the ceiling are also quite counter-intuitive when something is dropping/flowing down, as it then flows up. And having different illustrations / timings next to each other is annoying when there's only one audio channel and you are in front of a illustration that is not in sync with audio.

Regarding content: Unfortunately, it's quite off. There's a wall with water / a beach, but the waves behave unnatural. There's a van Gogh room which has not only van Gogh elements but also at least Klimt and maybe some other artist that painted persons more realistically. I could not identify an overall concept of the museum other than "look what fancy scenes we can project to walls".

The one thing I really liked was coloring animals with crayons and then scanning them to be part of an interactive Illustration.

All in all, it was an ok visit, as we had to spend some time before going to the airport, but I would not recommend visiting this place in favor of some other activities.

I-MUSEUM is Vietnam's first "Media & Art Museum" located in Trang TiÃªn Plaza, a high-end commercial facility in the center of Hanoi. It features five themed spaces where you can experience digital video art with light and sound effects. For example, there are participatory exhibits where you can enter the world of Van Gogh's "Starry Night" and create original colorful animals with 3D mapping. In addition, the photo booth where you can take photos wearing traditional Vietnamese and Korean costumes is also popular, so you can enjoy an art experience and commemorative photos at the same time. The museum is open from 9:30 to 21:30, and the admission fee is 230,000 VND for adults and 150,000 VND for children.

If you're looking for couples or parents with children who have nothing better to do in Hanoi on a rainy day like today, this is the place to go. It's not a large area, but there are plenty of photo spots, and you can take photos by rotating through different screens for about 10 minutes per section. It's a great activity for kids, from coloring the final picture to displaying it on the screen.

The museum is located on the 5th floor of Trang Tien Plaza. The exhibition space is not very large, the time I went there were only 6 themed rooms. The ticket price for adults is 180,000 VND/person (everyone should buy tickets directly at the counter, booking on travel apps will be more expensive, especially foreigners will be charged a higher price).

Plus points:
- Creative art space, displaying new 3D images, vivid sound. My favorite is the ocean-themed room, showing a day at sea from dawn to late at night. Sit still for a bit, listen to the sound of waves, dolphins, seagulls... suitable for relaxing, releasing emotions.
- There are some activities such as coloring, taking pictures, transforming into 5 elements... suitable for both children and adults.

Minus points:
- The space is still small, not diverse
- Adults should keep an eye on children, especially in rooms with many mirrors, which can easily cause injury.
- The Van Gogh gallery is impressive with Starry Night, the other paintings are quite confusing.

- I think this ticket price is not expensive, but not cheap either. Personally, I think this experience is worth the money, but I hope the museum should expand the exhibition themes.
Okay, I went during the 20% sale because of Tet, it's nice but if you park your car in the basement, be careful because the price is quite expensive.

Going on a holiday was super crowded and the children were noisy and chaotic so it wasn't very fun. Ticket prices will increase on holidays. Yesterday I had a really bad experience at An Bang beach because of the chair and umbrella rental service here. When soliciting customers, the chair rental lady said 50,000 VND/chair if you don't drink anything. Everyone settled down and she gave me the Menu and said that the free chair is only for drinks from 120,000 VND or more to avoid paying 50,000 VND for the chair. Meanwhile, for a can of Cola/Fanta/... they charged 50,000 VND. Cocktails are 120,000 VND, more expensive than at the airport or a 5-star hotel. It's sad for Hoi An that until now they still tolerate such opportunistic business practices. I went with a group of German friends so I didnâ€™t want to argue too much over a few hundred thousand and ruin everyoneâ€™s fun, because itâ€™s true that converted to Euros itâ€™s not worth much but I feel sad for tourism in our country. I went to My Khe Beach - Da Nang in the summer and was really impressed with the fine white sand, clear blue water, and moderate waves. The coastal area is very clean, with a regular cleaning team and a professionally organized public bathing area.

However, during peak season, there are quite a lot of visitors, especially in the evening, so it is a bit noisy and difficult to find a parking space. 

In return, near the beach there are many cafes, delicious seafood restaurants, reasonable prices, friendly service.

I took a Grab from my accommodation in Da Nang City to My Khe Beach. The best destination is "the beach across from the M Hotel." A surfing school operates on the beach across from the M Hotel, and a long rope marks the safety zone, making swimming only permitted here. Lifeguards are also on duty, which is why so many people flock here. Herbal Pizza is nearby, so you can enjoy pizza or steak with beer while watching the sunset. It's also fascinating to see vacationers from all over the world enjoying themselves in various ways. The beach stretches for 33 kilometers, which is impressive. I happened to spot a gorgeous girl practicing her dance moves on the beach (video available). I wish her a wonderful future.

Danang is home to the stunning My Khe Beach, considered one of the most natural beaches. My Khe is a popular destination among tourists to relax, have fun, and enjoy the seabreeze. Locals flocks to the area as well for their daily exercises and outdoor activities.

I went there every morning during my four-day stay in Da Nang.
This beach is a perfect place to experience the local atmosphere.
It's bustling from 4 a.m.: people exercising, fishing, seniors swimming with plastic bottles in their hands, locals enjoying sand baths and sunbathing, YouTubers filming, couples... The sea is also less hot in the early morning, and the sea of â€‹â€‹Da Nang locals and foreigners mix, creating their own unique waves. I really love this beach, where the waves, sunrises, and the daily lives and travels of the people all intermingle.
It was a light rain, but the beach was beautiful. If I come here again, I'd like to stay at a hotel along the beach.

Since our plans to visit Hoi An were derailed by the approaching typhoon, we decided to stick with indoor activities and visited the Danang Art Museum which we found surprisingly good.

It is clear the Vietnamese artists have absorbed influences from other countries including France, Japan, Indonesia etc. and have applied those forms as well as their own to Vietnamese contexts.

Some of the contemporary works are of a very good quality that I would be happy to display at home.

I just had a very interesting visit to the Da Nang Fine Arts Museum. Located right in the city center, easy to find even though the city is always bustling with traffic. From the moment I entered, I felt the concentrated cultural space, with works of art imbued with Vietnamese identity. 

This museum is not really big, but enough to impress me with its diversity. Sculptures, oil paintings and even some modern graphic works, all truly reflect the life and people in Vietnam. In particular, I love the way they display the works, not too close or too far, enough to be able to feel every smallest detail. 

An interesting point is the enthusiasm of the museum staff. They are not only attentive but also have good knowledge about the works, helping me understand more about the meaning of each work I see. Perhaps a bit of a pity here is that the English information is limited, so if you don't ask the staff, foreign visitors will have a hard time understanding it themselves. 

I was also particularly impressed with the way the museum exploits natural light, making the works always shine in the most natural way. For me, it was a very good experience and worth a visit. Hopefully next time I come back, I can see more new works.
Great place, very serene. A beautiful collection with temporary exhibitions on the first floor.

However, please keep the doors closed when entering in groups and refrain from making loud noises, as if you were talking at home.

The Fine Arts Museum in Da Nang is a wonderful place to explore for anyone who appreciates creativity and culture. The collection is surprisingly rich, with so many art pieces on display â€” ranging from traditional Vietnamese works to modern and contemporary styles. Walking through the galleries, you can feel the diversity of artistic expression, from detailed sculptures to vibrant paintings and unique local crafts.

The museum is well-organized, making it easy to navigate through different sections. Each room offers something new, and I really enjoyed seeing how Vietnamese culture, history, and daily life are reflected in the artworks. Itâ€™s a great balance of heritage and modern imagination.

The staff are polite and helpful, and the space is calm, quiet, and comfortable â€” perfect for taking your time to enjoy each piece. For such an affordable entry, it truly feels like a cultural treasure that many visitors overlook.

If youâ€™re in Da Nang and want to experience something beyond beaches and food, I highly recommend spending an afternoon here. Itâ€™s inspiring, educational, and gives you a deeper appreciation of the cityâ€™s artistic soul.
There are actually many interesting things everyone should visit once.

This art museum in downtown Da Nang primarily exhibits works by local artists. The first thing that surprised me was the incredibly low admission fee of 20,000 VND (approximately 120 yen). That alone made it worth a visit.

The museum has three floors, each with its own unique exhibits. I enjoyed the wide variety of artworks, including oil paintings, sculptures, and lacquerware. The lacquerware paintings in particular were incredibly delicate and beautiful, completely changing my image of Vietnam. There were also silk paintings on display, allowing you to experience Vietnam's history and culture firsthand. Some of the works featured the Vietnam War, and while they deal with the harsh theme of war, some also exude a warm, human touch.

The exhibition space was reasonably well-attended, without being too crowded, allowing for a relaxed viewing experience. The museum is air-conditioned throughout, making it a perfect place to visit on a hot day. There are many impressive works, but the museum is just the right size to take your time and look around in about an hour to an hour and a half.

The reception staff were friendly, and there were lockers available to store your luggage, so it was nice to be able to browse without having to carry anything. It's also within walking distance of Han Market, so it's a great place to stop by while sightseeing.

By the way, tickets can only be purchased with cash at the entrance. Considering the size of the museum, there was no waiting time and entry was smooth. I didn't feel the need to make a reservation in advance. If you're looking for a quiet, affordable cultural experience in Da Nang, this is a hidden gem that I highly recommend.

The Fine Arts Museum surprised me with its collection of modern and traditional Vietnamese art. Itâ€™s quiet, peaceful, and inspiring. You should take time to explore each gallery carefully. I highly recommend this museum for art enthusiastsâ€”itâ€™s a wonderful way to understand Da Nangâ€™s creative spirit.
A nice and not crowded museum, can walk and look at the paintings and exponats without a rush. The staff is very helpful. The entrance fee was 20.000. 3 floors with restrooms on each floor.

Having visited many museums in and outside the country, in terms of scale, the Da Nang Fine Arts Museum is not too large. Normally, when I go to a museum, I will prepare to spend half a day or even a whole day here. But the museums in Da Nang have not, most of them are only about 2-3 hours. 
Speaking specifically about the Da Nang Museum, the day I went was during the exhibition on Hue heritage, many parts were quite interesting and provided useful information, such as sketch collections of artists, Giang A Luoi weaving heritage, Thanh Tien paper flowers, etc. The upper floors also have exhibitions that can be stopped to admire and learn for a long time, because there are QR codes on most of the works so you can scan the code to hear about the author and the work. For me, the lacquer paintings displayed here are quite impressive. In addition, there is also a unique exhibition space for painter Le Ba Dang. 
The downside is that the space is a bit dark, I don't see any management so the protection of the artifacts is probably mainly the self-awareness of the visitors :))) The second downside is the heat and stuffiness. I wanted to stay longer, but in a space that is not bright enough, hot and stuffy, it is very difficult. Most museums have air conditioning, but in Da Nang it seems not. Da Nang Museum has air conditioning in some exhibition rooms, but not in others. Champa Museum has no air conditioning, so fans are on, the day I went was so hot :)))) The fine arts museum doesn't even have fans. Luckily it was just after rain that day so it was cool, otherwise I don't know how long it would last ðŸ˜‚ðŸ˜‚ðŸ˜‚ I hope the managers pay attention to the experience of visitors. I will think again whether to come a second time or not because I don't think it's really wow.

The perfect place to gain a different view of Da Nang and Vietnam. See all sorts of art as well as historical items and antiquities. This museum is a must-visit. 20,000 VND (cash payment only) is very affordable and reasonable for the quality.

Donâ€™t be discouraged by Level 1 â€” the real treasures await on Levels 2 and 3, where you can truly enjoy the art.

Itâ€™s quiet, spacious, and fully air-conditioned, creating the perfect environment for peaceful viewing and appreciation. One of its best features is how uncrowded it is, allowing you to take your time with each piece.

I especially love how close you can get to some of the artworks â€” you can examine the intricate details up close, something rarely possible in most international museums where barriers or red lines keep visitors at a distance.

Come and enjoy this educational and tranquil attraction â€” a welcome escape from the constant buzz of city traffic.

The museum is open every day of the week, from 8am to 5pm, without time restrictions like the Da Nang Museum. Ticket price is 10k/person, no parking fee. The museum has 3 display areas, especially a separate area displaying works by artist Le Ba Dang, one of the famous painters of Vietnam. 

The space is large, however, to ensure no damage, the works are all framed in glass. The light in the museum is a bit dark, the paintings are framed in glass, so sometimes the light is quite bright when you come to see them up close. This also affects the viewer and the works.

Looking at these scenes, I feel the wild, majestic and peaceful beauty of nature here.

a vast space of the ocean. The dark blue water stretches to the horizon, where the high-rise buildings of Da Nang city appear dimly under the mist. The gray-white sky with layered clouds creates a feeling of stillness and silence. The small kayak in the distance further highlights the vastness of the ocean. I can imagine the gentle sound of waves and the gentle sea breeze

The scene becomes closer and more impressive with large gray-brown rocks stacked on top of each other naturally. Two people stand on the cliff, small in the majestic space of mountains and ocean. Behind are lush, green mountains, creating a beautiful background for the photo. The clear blue sky with fluffy white clouds brings a bright and airy feeling. This photo reminds me of the strength and resilience of nature and the smallness of humans in front of that beauty.
The third photo brings a different perspective, more gentle and relaxing. The smooth golden sand embraces the clear blue sea, the small waves gently lapping the shore creating a soothing sound. The green trees along the coast are like a soft silk strip. The blue sky with thin white clouds creates a peaceful space, ideal for relaxing and enjoying the beauty of the ocean.
Overall, the three photos vividly depict the diverse beauty of Bai Da in Son Tra Peninsula. From the vastness and tranquility of the ocean to the majesty of the mountains and the tranquility of the sand, each frame has its own nuances, but all exude the wild and charming beauty of Da Nang's nature. I believe that, when you set foot here, you will feel many more wonderful things that these photos only partially reveal.
A quiet village. Usually local people come. A great place to swim.
