We paid 10,000 VDN to park the motorcycle, but the space itself was very poorly maintained, with plastics and trash everywhere and no cafes or services to relax by the sea. Overall, the space has great potential but is poorly maintained.

**Review of Bai Da - Da Nang**

Bai Da is one of the lesser-known tourist destinations in Da Nang, but it offers a wonderful experience for those who love the wild and peaceful beauty of nature. Located about 20km from the city center, Bai Da is an ideal choice for those who want to explore deserted beaches and enjoy a quiet space, different from other crowded beaches in Da Nang.

### **Scenery and nature**

The first thing that makes a strong impression when coming to Bai Da is its wild and peaceful beauty. Although not too prominent in terms of tourism development, Bai Da still possesses an irresistible natural beauty with fine golden sand, clear blue sea water and large scattered stones creating a unique landscape. If you love taking photos, this is the perfect place to create great photos with the blue sea and natural rocks.

### **Wild and deserted nature**

Unlike crowded beaches like My Khe or Non Nuoc, Bai Da has a quiet and deserted space, a great destination for those who want to find a place to relax and get away from the noise. This is an ideal place for you to swim, walk on the sand or simply enjoy the peaceful space and listen to the sound of the waves.

### **Activities at Bai Da**

Although Bai Da does not have many services like other beaches in Da Nang, this place is very suitable for activities such as swimming, walking on the sand or participating in outdoor games. The large rocks also create an ideal space for you to climb and admire the sea view from above. In addition, this is also an ideal place for picnics or short camping trips if you love to immerse yourself in nature.

### **Location and how to get there**

Bai Da is located about 20km northeast of Da Nang city center, near Son Tra peninsula. To get to Bai Da, you can travel by motorbike or car. Although there are no clear signs, you can easily find your way through the routes near Son Tra peninsula. However, if you are not familiar with the road, you may need support from a map or local people.

### **Things to note**

- **Limited facilities:** Because it is a pristine beach, Bai Da does not have many facilities to serve tourists like other areas. Therefore, if you plan to come here, prepare food, drinks and necessary items.

- **Safety:** Because it is a deserted beach, you need to pay attention to safety when swimming, especially on days with big waves.

### **Summary**

Da Nang Rock Beach is an ideal destination for those who want to find peace and immerse themselves in nature. With its pristine scenery, clear blue water and deserted sand, this place will bring you a relaxing experience that is completely different from other bustling beaches. If you are a lover of tranquility and want to have a relaxing day in the middle of nature, Rock Beach will be a great choice.

Because it's located a bit further from the popular Da Nang Beach, it's less crowded and less crowded. The water is cleaner and quieter. However, the lack of amenities may be a bit inconvenient for Koreans. You'll also see a fair number of monkeys. You can enjoy banana boating, jet skiing, and snorkeling. While Grab is a convenient way to get here from the city, you should be aware that it's difficult to use Grab to hail a motorbike or car on the way back.

Follow the mountain road past the Lady Buddha and then take the road that leads off to the right a couple of kilometres later. The end of that road turns into a track down to this gloriously secluded cove. Yes, you will be pestered for a parking fee; yes, there is a fair bit of rubbish to be found on the beach and in the sea; yes, there are very dangerous sharp rocks and jagged bits of metal sticking out all over the place which could do you serious harm; and yes, it does get horribly crowded at weekends when hoards of â€œmot-hai-baâ€ partygoers descend like a plague of locustsâ€¦.but trust me, despite these irritants, this place is gorgeous. The sea is so much cleaner and clearer than anywhere along the Danang-to-Hoi An beach line, you can snorkel and view pretty coral and a wide range of beautiful fish, it has a less touristy, more serene atmosphere than other beaches in this area, and best of all, there are no lifeguards shouting at you and blowing a whistle to make you move from one arbitrarily designated â€˜safe zoneâ€™ to another one, just so the lifeguard can feel big and powerful.
This is a great place to bring a picnic and some beers and chill out for a whole day, but please, please take your rubbish with you when you leave.

Obama Rock Beach is located on Son Tra Peninsula in Da Nang, near the most sacred Linh Ung Pagoda that every tourist visiting Da Nang must visit. Previously, this rock beach was not a famous destination, only used by local people for fishing. However, after the development of Da Nang tourism, especially in the nearby areas such as Linh Ung Pagoda and Ban Co Peak, Obama Rock Beach also became a part of the tourism development. 

The city has recognized its potential and invested in developing tourism services in this area. As a result, Obama Rock Beach has become a unique and unmissable destination for tourists exploring Da Nang. Despite human intervention and development, it still retains the delicacy and purity of a pristine beach, nestled in the natural beauty of the landscape.
Ok! Nice view!

The guy collecting money for his "parking services" should instead make himself useful and pick up some trash. The coral is 99% dead, the only colorful things you'll see in the water are beer cans. Not suitable to swim for beginners as it's easy to cut yourself on the rocks and coral. It's okay for taking pictures.

Obama Rock Beach is located on Son Tra Peninsula - Da Nang, near the most sacred pagoda that every time tourists visit and experience Da Nang, they must visit Linh Ung Pagoda. Previously, this rock beach was not known to tourists, only people living near this Obama Rock area often came to fish. But later, because Da Nang City has developed tourism, some recent areas such as Linh Ung Pagoda, Ban Co Peak are famous with tourists, this Obama Rock Beach has also "influenced" the investor to exploit and develop some tourism services at this location. Later, it became a new check-in tourist destination in Da Nang that tourists cannot miss and was also voted as one of the places that still retains the wild simplicity of the natural landscape despite the "sculpture" of humans.

Ká»³ Co Beach, located near NhÆ¡n LÃ½ in Quy NhÆ¡n, is often called the â€œMaldives of Vietnamâ€ for its crystal-clear turquoise waters and powdery white sand. Nestled between rugged mountains and the sea, the beach feels like a hidden paradise, offering both dramatic scenery and tranquil beauty.

For photographers, Ká»³ Co is a dream destination. The contrast between the emerald sea, golden sand, and rocky cliffs creates striking compositions. Aerial shots with a drone capture the full curve of the shoreline, while sunrise and sunset provide soft, golden light that enhances the natural colors. The shallow waters near the shore are incredibly clear, perfect for capturing reflections and underwater scenes.

Beyond its beauty, Ká»³ Co offers opportunities for snorkeling, swimming, and exploring nearby coves, adding variety to both travel experiences and photo stories. Local seafood stalls near the beach provide a cultural touch, where visitors can enjoy freshly prepared dishes against the backdrop of the ocean.

Ká»³ Co Beach is more than just a seaside escapeâ€”it is a destination where unspoiled nature meets vibrant coastal life. For travelers and photographers, it remains one of the most captivating beaches in central Vietnam.

Ky Co Beach, located in Nhon Ly Commune, Quy Nhon City, Binh Dinh Province, is truly one of the most beautiful beach paradises I have ever set foot on. This morning I had the opportunity to swim here, and the experience was truly memorable with indescribable emotions about a very pristine, pure and peaceful sea. 

From the moment I set foot in Ky Co, I was overwhelmed by the rare natural beauty. The sea here has a clear emerald green color, you can see all the way to the bottom when standing close to the shore. The white sand beach is smooth, clean and stretches in a crescent shape, embracing the calm sea water, creating a peaceful scene like a painting. Even at noon, the sea water still retains a cool, strangely pleasant temperature. The feeling of soaking in the cool water, amidst the majestic natural scenery, behind the rocky mountains, in front of the immense sea and sky, makes me forget all my fatigue, leaving only pure relaxation. 

A special feature of Ky Co is that the sea is quite shallow, very safe for both adults and children to swim. The waves are gentle, not too strong, so there is no feeling of fear when swimming far from shore. I also took the opportunity to dive to see corals near shallow water areas - without too much technique, I can still see colorful coral reefs and schools of small fish swimming around. 

In addition to swimming, this place also has many extremely "photogenic" photo angles with natural rocky reefs, wooden bridges close to the sea, or small, pretty thatched roofs on the shore. The air in Ky Co is also fresh, no dust, no noise. Even though there are tourists, everything is still kept quiet and clean, rarely. The locals are friendly, always ready to guide visitors with the hospitality typical of the Central coastal region. 

Swimming in Ky Co is not only a recreational activity but also a healing experience - helping me reconnect with nature, with myself. If you are looking for a place to "escape" from the hustle and bustle of life, Ky Co is an option not to be missed.
The sea is so clear that there is no trash, the seals are great.
It's really beautiful, incredibly beautiful, next time I will come and swim in the sea to my heart's content.

Ky Co Beach is one of the outstanding destinations in Quy Nhon. The sea water is clear, clean and you can see the bottom, the sand is fine white, the air is fresh. The scenery is still quite wild, the nature is almost intact, very suitable for swimming, relaxing or taking virtual photos. The way to Ky Co is now easier than before, often combining electric cars and canoes depending on the service package. However, the ticket price to this tourist area is currently quite high compared to the general level, especially if you go with a large family, it will be a bit "painful for the wallet". In addition, some ancillary services such as eating and drinking or renting tents and huts are also quite expensive, so you need to prepare in advance or ask clearly about the cost. However, with such impressive natural beauty, it is still worth visiting at least once.

We recommend that Ky Co tourist area open from 6:00 AM to 6:00 PM, allowing visitors to watch the sunset and sunrise - the two most beautiful times of the day. It opens at 7:00 AM, but in the summer, the sun is scorching hot at 8:00 AM, so how can visitors enjoy themselves? The management of the tourist area does not want to look far ahead, the style is like an autonomous zone, not friendly at all! 

The staff and security guards are rude, not smiling, indifferent like robots, not trained to be suitable for the tourism industry. 

We respectfully propose that Ky Co tourist area adjust its operating hours to open from 6:00 AM to 6:00 PM, allowing visitors to experience both sunrise and sunset - the most beautiful moments of the day. 

Currently, the site opens at 7:00 AM, but during summer months, the sun becomes scorching by 8:00 AM, making it uncomfortable for tourists to enjoy outdoor activities. This lack of flexibility reflects poor foresight from the management. The overall approach feels more like an isolated zone than a welcoming tourist destination.

Moreover, the attitude of staff and security personnel is noticeably unwelcoming. There are no smiles, no hospitality â€“ only robotic, indifferent behavior. This clearly reflects a lack of proper training for the tourism industry and leaves a negative impression on guests.

If Ky Co wishes to elevate its reputation and attract more responsible and appreciative travelers, itâ€™s essential to start by treating guests with respect and kindness â€“ not like a burden.

Located in Nhon Ly commune, about 20km from Quy Nhon city center, Eo Gio is a special arc-shaped strait embraced by two high rocky mountains and always "sucking in strong winds" - that is also the origin of the name. 

What makes Eo Gio attractive is the clear blue sea water and steep cliffs that give a wild, majestic feeling. 

The cliff-side walking path with white-red railings is a "hot" check-in corner loved by many tourists. 

The best time is from March to September, when the weather is sunny, the sea is beautiful, the wind is light, ensuring better photos and experiences. 

Small notes when you visit: 

Although beautiful, Eo Gio is not a beach with large, smooth sand for swimming and playing comfortably like some other places - mainly for sightseeing, taking pictures and relaxing. 

The road has steep sections or close to the cliff, so wear flat shoes, be careful when it rains because it can be slippery.

Prepare a hat, sunglasses, sunscreen because the sun is strong at noon; and if you go in the afternoon to watch the sunset, you should bring a light jacket because the sea breeze can be a bit cold. 

In short: If you want a natural experience that is both wild and beautiful, Eo Gio is a great choice - spending a few hours here in the afternoon until sunset will be very memorable.

Located in Nhon Ly commune, about 25km from Quy Nhon city center, Ky Co is known as the "Maldives of Vietnam" with clear water, fine white sand and rocky outcrops along the shore creating a poetic scene. This place is extremely ideal for swimming, diving to see coral or taking virtual photos amidst the wild and peaceful nature. 
Ky Co beach is under the management of the tourist area of the same name, the entrance fee is 100,000 VND/trip and 40,000 VND/trip for the shuttle bus to the beach. 

Just a few minutes away from Ky Co, Eo Gio Quy Nhon is a prominent destination with a walking path along the mountainside, winding stone steps leading straight to the sea. This place impresses with its natural cliffs that curve around the coast, creating a "windy waist" that is both majestic and romantic. 
Eo Gio entrance ticket is only 25,000 VND/turn, you can freely explore and check-in amidst the vast sea and sky. Especially in the afternoon, standing from Eo Gio, you can look far away, admire the whole view of Nhon Ly sea and Phuong Mai peninsula. 

If you depart from any province with the North - South railway passing through, you can choose the train. You can buy tickets to Dieu Tri Station, about 10km from Quy Nhon center. 

This is a safe, comfortable choice and especially allows visitors to enjoy the scenery along the way. However, traveling by train will take quite a long time (About 22-28 hours if traveling from Hanoi and about 8-10 hours if traveling from Ho Chi Minh City).

Eo Gio is one of the outstanding tourist destinations in Quy Nhon, Binh Dinh, famous for its wild and majestic beauty. This place makes a strong impression with the winding rocky mountains hugging the sea, forming a unique strait, with white waves all year round. A beautiful, long stretch of rocky beach, with many strange shapes, creating a natural scene as vivid as a painting. 

The terraced road along the mountainside is an ideal check-in spot, both admiring the clear blue sea and feeling the cool sea breeze blowing through. Eo Gio is also an ideal place to watch the sunrise or sunset - the scene of the sun dyeing the entire sky and sea red is truly unforgettable. 

The quiet space, fresh air and pristine beauty of Eo Gio make visitors feel relaxed and comfortable. This place is suitable for those who love nature, want to get away from the noisy city to find the sea. Although it is just a rocky beach, Eo Gio brings a feeling of both strength and romance - a destination not to be missed when coming to Quy Nhon.

Eo Gio is one of the most prominent landmarks in Quy Nhon, famous for its wild, majestic beauty and rare natural scenery. Located about 20 km from the city center, Eo Gio is a strait surrounded by winding rocky mountains, creating a beautiful arc embracing the blue sea. 

The most impressive thing here is the clear water, where you can see the bottom, the waves gently lapping against the cliffs creating a relaxing, cool sound. The mountainside walking path with red fences standing out against the blue sky and sea becomes a check-in spot not to be missed. On sunny days, Eo Gio appears like a vivid picture with distinct contrasting colors: turquoise water, white foam, and gray-brown rocks. 

Eo Gio is especially suitable for those who love nature, quietness and fresh air. However, this area has few tourist services, so you should prepare food and drinks carefully if you travel on your own. 

In short, Eo Gio is an ideal destination for tourists who want to enjoy the pristine natural beauty, relax and capture extremely impressive photos.

Eo Gio is one of the most prominent and attractive destinations in Quy Nhon, Binh Dinh province. This place is famous for its wild, majestic beauty of nature with winding rocky mountains embracing the emerald green sea. The name "Eo Gio" comes from the shape of the strait that catches the wind all year round, creating a cool, pleasant atmosphere. When coming here, visitors can walk on the wooden road close to the cliff, admire the panoramic view of the vast sea and take beautiful pictures. In addition, Eo Gio is also an ideal place for diving to see coral, swimming and relaxing in the fresh nature. With both poetic and powerful scenery, Eo Gio not only attracts domestic tourists but is also a famous check-in spot for young people who love to travel and explore.

Eo Gio is one of the most famous and beautiful tourist destinations in Quy Nhon, known as "the most beautiful sunrise viewing place in Vietnam". Located about 20km from the city center, in the Nhon Ly area, Eo Gio possesses a wild beauty with rocky mountains embracing the blue beach, and beautiful winding cliff-side roads. 

The first impression when coming here is the wooden staircase road along the cliff, facing the sea, very famous on social networks with extremely cool "virtual life" photos. Looking down from above, the entire immense sea, jagged rocky shores with clear blue water, rhythmic waves, creating a majestic but also very peaceful natural scene. 

In addition to the beautiful scenery, Eo Gio is also suitable for activities such as watching the sunrise, checking in, gentle trekking, taking wedding photos or combining Ky Co tour, diving to see coral. This area is quite well invested: safe paths, clean restrooms, spacious parking lots, tour guides and full tourist support services. 

A small note: the sun is very harsh and the wind is strong at noon, so you should go early in the morning or in the cool afternoon to enjoy the beautiful scenery and feel more comfortable. The entrance ticket is currently about 25,000 VND/person. 

In short, Eo Gio is a destination not to be missed if you love wild nature, want to admire the beauty of Quy Nhon's sea and sky and find some really "cool" souvenir photos during the trip.

Located in Ly Luong village, Nhon Ly commune, about 20-25km from Quy Nhon city center, Eo Gio is a strait with the shape of a "wind-sucking strait", creating a majestic feeling like a natural paradise ï¿¼. The name "Eo Gio" comes from the mountain top area embracing the strait, where the sea breeze continuously blows through like a natural funnel - this is also the reason for the impressive vertical cliffs and rolling waves hitting the shore ï¿¼. 

The path along the cliff is long, paved with clean stones and has red and white handrails to create a lively highlight. This is an ideal path for walking, watching the deep blue sea, and hunting for sunrise or sunset - the most ideal moment when coming here. From above, visitors can see the whole Nhon Ly fishing village, the peaceful fishing port and the net boats in the middle of the ocean ï¿¼. 

Eo Gio also has a rocky beach with large and small rocks, reminiscent of "dinosaur eggs" scattered across the beach - a unique check-in spot, very popular with tourists. If you love experiencing the sea, you can participate in snorkeling, fishing or even light surfing. For those who are more adventurous, sandboarding on the nearby sand dunes is not a bad choice. 

Note that you should visit Eo Gio from March to September - the dry season, calm sea and blue sky - the best conditions to fully experience the beauty here ï¿¼. 

Some advice: go early in the morning to avoid the harsh sunlight, limit the crowded rush hour. Don't forget to bring a hat, sunglasses and sunscreen; at the same time, keep clean, do not leave trash - something you will find necessary when the locality is focusing on environmental protection. 

In short, Eo Gio is a destination not to be missed in the Quy Nhon journey - where wild nature meets cool sea breeze, a place to go for both virtual photos and gentle backpacking experiences.

ðŸ“ Eo Gio â€“ Nhon Ly, Quy Nhon is still one of the most beautiful check-in spots in Binh Dinh, with the scenery of rocky mountains hugging the sea, the wooden road winding along the cliffs is impressive. However, I visited on a rainy afternoon â€“ and this greatly affected the experience. 

The scenery is still beautiful, there is no denying â€“ low clouds, light gray sea, waves crashing against the rocks creating white foam that is very â€œpoeticâ€. But the rain makes the wooden road slippery, the cold sea wind and fog obscure the distant view. Many sections of the road are quite steep so you have to be careful, especially for the elderly. 

The big minus is the parking area and transportation: it is mandatory to take an electric car or a 16-seat shuttle bus to the tourist area, but the parking lot is quite chaotic, lacking clear instructions. There are no seats or roofs for waiting passengers â€“ a bit inconvenient when it rains or the sun is harsh. 

ðŸ‘‰ If you want to have a complete experience, choose a sunny day and go early to avoid the crowd. For me, although the scenery is still worth it, the rainy afternoon makes Eo Gio lose the brilliance that people often praise.

Hopefully in the future, this area will be better organized to match the existing beauty.

Walking along the winding pathways, I felt like I was in a nature paradiseâ€”perfect for photography, relaxation, and soaking in the raw beauty of Vietnamâ€™s coastline.

The entrance fee is very reasonable, and the area is well-maintained. Early mornings or late afternoons are the best times to visit to avoid crowds and catch the magical sunrise/sunset. Donâ€™t forget to explore the hidden caves and rock formationsâ€”they add an adventurous touch!

Whether you're a nature lover, adventurer, or just looking for a peaceful escape, Eo Gio delivers an unforgettable experience. Highly recommend adding this gem to your Quy Nhon itinerary!

Tip: Wear comfortable shoes for walking and bring waterâ€”it can get sunny!

If you have the opportunity to visit Quy Nhon but do not go to Eo Gio, then the trip is considered to be missing... half of the emotions. Located about 20km from the city center, Eo Gio is a paradise for those who love to travel and love places that are both wild and poetic.

True to its name, the wind here is not just any kind - it blows coolly, blows your hair, even... almost blows your hat off. The winding walking path follows the cliff, overlooking the blue sea, the waves crashing against the rocks sound extremely soothing. The scenery here is like a vivid picture - blue sky, white clouds, clear sea water that can see the bottom, so beautiful it is heartbreaking.

When going to Eo Gio, you must prepare a fully charged camera, a chilled soul and a little bit of "adventure". Remember to combine going to Ky Co, swimming in the sea, diving to see the coral and then having a few plates of fresh seafood in the fishing village next door - guaranteed to fill both your stomach and soul.

Nha Trang, a beautiful coastal city, not only attracts tourists with its smooth white sand beaches and emerald-green waters, but also with its unique cultural, historical and scientific values. During my journey to explore the city, there was a destination that left a deep and unforgettable impression on me, a place where the door to the vast ocean world opened up, full of life and wonder - that is the Nha Trang Institute of Oceanography. 

Located on a large plot of land at No. 1 Cau Da, not far from the city center, the Institute of Oceanography appears with an ancient appearance, bearing the imprint of French architecture since its early days of establishment in 1922. From the moment I stepped through the gate, I felt a completely different atmosphere, a blend of historical nostalgia and the excitement of scientific knowledge. The fresh air, the faint salty taste of the ocean and the murmuring sound of waves from afar were like an attractive invitation.

My journey of discovery began at the large specimen display area. This is probably the place that overwhelms anyone. Before my eyes is a giant humpback whale skeleton, 18 meters long, a great natural creation that has been meticulously and elaborately restored. Standing under that skeleton, I feel so small before the vastness of the ocean and the magic of creation. Just looking at each large vertebra, each long and wide pectoral fin is enough to make my imagination fly far, imagining the image of a gentle giant swimming leisurely in the middle of the ocean. Next to that is the skeleton of a Dugong, also known as a "mermaid", with fascinating legendary stories. Each specimen, from rare fish soaked in formalin to collections of corals, shells, and snail shells of all shapes and colors, is a story about the biodiversity of Vietnam's seas. They are no longer inanimate objects, but seem to be whispering about life, the environment, and even lurking dangers.

Leaving the specimen area, I entered a completely different world - the world of vibrant marine creatures swimming around in glass tanks. The aquarium system here is designed extremely scientifically and beautifully, almost perfectly simulating the natural habitat of each species. The mysterious, dim blue light covers the space, the sound of flowing water and colorful schools of fish gliding before my eyes create a scene like in a National Geographic documentary.

I spent hours going from one glass tank to another, not wanting to miss any moment. The playful clownfish, hiding in the soft sea anemones, are reminiscent of the familiar animated film "Finding Nemo". The lionfish with their fins spread out like feather fans, move gracefully and gracefully. Or the schools of dragon fish, queen fish sparkling as if plated in gold, plated in silver, swimming in schools creating a mesmerizing dance. In particular, the area of â€‹â€‹fierce fish such as sharks and rays always attracts the attention of many tourists. Looking at the black-fin sharks with sharp eyes circling behind the thick glass, I couldn't help but shiver a little but also extremely excited. It was a feeling of approaching the "lord of the ocean" at an incredibly safe distance. 

One of the highlights that cannot be missed is the glass aquarium tunnel, although not too long but enough to bring a realistic experience. Entering the tunnel, I felt like I was immersed in the ocean. Sharks, rays and countless other fish swam right above and around me. The sunlight through the water created sparkling, magical streaks of light. The moment a giant stingray slowly glided right above, with its characteristic friendly "smile", made me and everyone around me gasp with delight. The feeling of being surrounded by the water world, seeing the life under the sea from a completely new perspective was an unforgettable experience.
A local tourist attraction rarely seen by Koreans. It's not fancy, but it's worth a visit for about 30 minutes or an hour for the 2,000 won admission fee.

The Institute of Oceanography was established on September 14, 1922 during the French colonial period with the original name of the Indochina Fisheries Oceanographic Service (Service ocÃ©anographique des pÃªches de l'Indochine). When talking about the Institute of Oceanography, one cannot help but mention an organic part of it, the Oceanographic Museum - which has been very famous since the 30s of the last century with the popular name "Nha Trang Oceanographic Institute Aquarium". Currently, the Oceanographic Museum is focusing on investing in upgrading, expanding and developing into a complete complex including marine aquariums for research, sightseeing as well as community education, and the largest marine biological specimen storage system in the country. Many specimens have been sent to many different laboratories abroad and many museums around the world.

We loved it. For the ridiculous price of 40,000 dong per adult, we spent about half an hour walking around and looking at both living and formalin-preserved exhibits. There are several beautiful photo spots.
Should come when coming to Nha Trang

The Nha Trang Institute of Oceanography is a destination that is both scientifically valuable and a cultural experience worth visiting. ðŸŒŠ

Founded by the French in 1922 as the Institut OcÃ©anographique de lâ€™Indochine (Institute of Oceanography of Indochina), this is the oldest marine research facility in Vietnam and Southeast Asia. After more than a century, the Institute still plays an important role in researching, preserving and displaying marine species.

Currently, the Institute's museum has more than 20,000 specimens and many living creatures, of which the most impressive is a giant whale skeleton nearly 18 meters long. The visiting space is clean, full of useful information, both educational and very interesting for tourists.

ðŸ‘‰ If you have the opportunity to come to Nha Trang, I really recommend everyone to visit the Institute of Oceanography to learn more about the ocean and have a different experience compared to familiar tourist attractions.

Nha Trang Institute of Oceanography is one of the leading marine research centers in Southeast Asia and is also an extremely attractive tourist destination in the coastal city of Nha Trang ðŸŒŠ.

ðŸ§ª Overview
Established: In 1922 under the French colonial period, originally named the Indochina Fisheries Oceanography Department

Location: No. 1 Cau Da, Vinh Nguyen Ward, City. Nha Trang, Khanh Hoa Province

Function: Research on marine life, preserve marine ecosystems, educate the community about the marine environment

ðŸ  Highlights when visiting
Museum of marine life: Displays more than 24,000 specimens of more than 4,000 species of marine and freshwater creatures

Aquarium: A place to raise living marine creatures in glass tanks, allowing visitors to observe directly

Giant specimens: There are giant groupers, sharks, whales... very impressive

High-tech zone: Developing to domesticate marine creatures to serve Vietnam's marine economy

ðŸ“… Visiting information
Ticket type Ticket price (VND)
Adults ~40,000
Students ~20,000 (with card)
Children under 6 years old Free
Opening hours: 6:00 am - 6:00 pm daily, including holidays

I visited from 3pm to 5pm. The institute has many species of marine life and detailed information boards, very suitable for those who like me to watch and read at the same time. Especially, there are turtles and hawksbill turtles in the Vietnam Red Book. Hopefully there will be a pair of turtles laying eggs, it would be great. Currently, the facilities are limited, for example, the turtle pond and shark pond are very small. Hopefully, the institute will have more funds to upgrade this part in the future.

The impressive point is the Marine Biology Museum - which stores more than 24,000 specimens of over 4,000 rare marine species, from fish, corals to crustaceans, with many rare and large specimens such as sharks, whales, giant groupers carefully preserved. In addition, the Living Exhibition Area with glass tanks raising many marine species in a simulated environment helps visitors to directly observe the colorful and rich ocean life.

The two old people who introduce themselves as the island owners do not show any professionalism but take money as if it is right. Eat it all, those two old people. Diep Son Island consists of 3 small islands, with a special feature of having a white sand road that appears when the water recedes, the water is clear, clean and almost free of trash. Van Gia Port is about 60km from Nha Trang, then rent a boat/canoe to the island for about 30-40 minutes. After having a self-sufficient trip, it is highly recommended that you join a tour to optimize costs and experience. At the pier, there will be a woman selling boat tickets to the island, the price is 250-300k/round trip depending on the time. Because we took a shared boat, we had to depend on and wait quite a long time to get there, when we returned, we got on the boat but it turned out that we were on a boat that the tour had booked (like a type of shared boat). Because we went on our own, the boat only dropped off passengers on an uninhabited island, there were only a few people who came out to provide services: renting jet skis, SUP, kayaking, fresh water showers and food and drink. The ticket to the island will include fresh water showers, drinking water, and free resting huts. There is no fixed menu for food, but they will make fresh seafood dishes caught that day, as shown in the picture above, a portion for 2 people, 300K/person. Compared to eating on the mainland, it seems quite expensive, but coming here, I want to support the people on the island. The snails are very big, the shrimp are fresh, the squid is delicious but the ink sac has not been removed yet, so I have to remove it myself while eating, a bit dirty. 
Around 1-2pm, a boat will come to pick you up and take you back to the mainland. 
If you go on a tour, you will be taken to the third island, which has about 100 households. There will be more services and more options to visit there.
Suggest cleaning the bathroom more...

Travel from Van Gia pier to Diep Son island, the price for each person is about 200-250k if there are enough people or join with other groups of tourists around 9:30 am and return at 1 pm, or you can rent a private boat with the price from 2.5 million but the time of entry and exit is free. Note for those who have not been there, you should refer to the tide time to be able to take pictures of the white sand road between the islands. In addition, you can stay overnight on the island but the electricity is only available for a few hours each night.
Beautiful scenery, clear blue water and impressive beach walks, but also a lot of trash due to being "forgotten" by tourists coming here.

A cluster of 3 small islands collectively called Diep Son, where there is a walking path between 2 beautiful small islands, clear sea water and white sand, colorful coral, pristine scenery, tourists will love coming here, note that there is only one restaurant on the island, so you should order food before going in a large group.

Diep Son Island impresses visitors at first sight with its wild and poetic beauty, along with unique virtual living spots such as the one-of-a-kind walking path in the middle of the sea, the love bridge where couples date... Because of that, Diep Son tourism has become a destination that many people tell each other about. Diep Son Island belongs to Van Phong Bay, Khanh Hoa, about 60km from Nha Trang city. It consists of 3 small islands: Hon Bip, Hon Giua, Hon Duoc. The most prominent feature of Diep Son is the nearly 1km long sand road in the middle of the sea, connecting the islands together. Visitors can easily walk from one island to another and take advantage of the opportunity to take more vivid photos in the middle of the immense blue sea.
A very interesting experience. Very beautiful view, not crowded. There are a lot of fish

I drove from Tuy Hoa to Van Gia when it was already noon, there were no more trains. Luckily, my girlfriend called Ms. Long and was able to join the trip with the people of Hon Bip (I got off at Hon O). 
As far as I remember, Hon O was inhabited by only Uncle Dai Anh, which meant that when I arrived, there were only 3 people on the island :3 . It felt like I was on a deserted island. Uncle Dai Anh was very simple and told good stories. Whatever he grew, he offered to tourists. He invested in roads and infrastructure on Hon O. However, probably because there were too many tourists and one person couldn't manage it, the items also deteriorated over time. This is a pity and I also feel sorry for him. 
I had a wonderful experience here. I hope that people who come after will be more conscious of preserving the landscape.

Nha Trang area has many beautiful beaches & islands, some of them popular with visitors. Diep Son Island is more known to locals but as a foreign traveler, here is my experience both good and bad.

Getting to the island is only via speedboat. The jetty at that time was under some kind of upgrading construction, therefore dusty and hard to push your luggage bags through the dirt. Speedboat service has life jackets, but the driver was too fast and when hitting the waves at high speeds, the ride was really bumpy.

As it's a small island, there are limited activities you can do here - probably only swim & kayak. There are a few areas which are nice for those Instagram shots. I'd say, it's more of a relaxed island and you can take this opportunity to disconnect from civilization.

All of the meals are provided by the island operator if you choose to eat here on a day trip or staying overnight. I really love the food as they serve fresh seafood like oysters, snails, lobsters, squid, etc.

The entire island runs on solar power & rainwater. At certain times of the day, power is cut for the solar batteries to recharge. Water for shower is there at the central restaurant or at the chalets. The toilets are basic, don't expect luxury.

If you choose to stay here overnight, I need to prepare you what to expect. The island operator was granted a lease by the government to develop the island and they have done so at their own cost. They have built chalets which run on gasoline generators and at night, power to the lights & fans may be cut. There is no air-conditioning, so you're basically living like how it was before air-conditioning was invented when you get the natural breeze & sounds of the waves.

Diep Son Island has its charms & limitations. I'd say come here with an open mind and soak in the experience without any demanding expectations, you would love to enjoy this place.
Beautiful and wild.
Just lift the camera and take a picture and it will automatically give you a beautiful photo.
The beach is quite clean. Pristine. Good food for lunch. A beautiful spot for check in.
Disappointed! Dirty, no swimming beach here, few facilities, average food at the island and only attraction is you can walk to another island during low tide.
peaceful
The most beautiful place in Nha Trang for me! ðŸ˜ Worth going! ðŸ’™

I went on an island tour for 680k/person including lunch at a local's house on the island. The island is very beautiful, the water is very clear, and the island still retains its natural beauty. The sandbar connecting the two islands will gradually appear after 12 noon. Those who go to the island should be extremely careful because the sun will be very strong, so bring a hat and sunscreen.
Service

Rather disappointing. Dirty, no swimming beach here, few facilities, average food at the island and only attraction is you can walk to another island during low tide - better walk knee deep in another place

I just left on August 1, 2022. Arriving at the Island at 11:00 am, the road between the two islands is not clear yet, it will be clear until around 1:00 pm! Price 350k/person includes canoe to and from!
Hehe
Not everyone knows that Diep Son Island Nha Trang is one of the three important Economic Zones of Vietnam!
Still wild, but there is a very rare sand road connecting the two islands

Very beautiful and unique - the road in the middle of the sea, connecting two small islands of Diep Son island. The sea water is crystal clear. When the tide is low, a small road with white sand is revealed. Everyone should refer to the tide time to avoid waiting for a long time. However, the downside is that there is quite a lot of trash around the island and on the road on the sea. If someone picks it up every day, the amount of trash will be very small. The food is quite fresh but expensive.

The experience of going by canoe to the island was too boring because the island was too wild and there weren't many entertainments. I went to the island because I heard an ad that there was a road across the sea at low tide, but it wasn't available until 6pm, so I had to endure it. It was a waste of time and nothing special.
The house is quite primitive. The bed is a bit lacking in amenities. But beautiful.

The sea is clear and beautiful. The only thing is that the restaurant on the island does business in a haphazard manner. When quoting the price, they charged another. I asked for a bowl of squid porridge and a bowl of fish porridge, the young man quoted 200,000 VND, enough for 2-3 people to eat. I agreed and ordered 1 portion of each. When paying, it was 600,000 VND for the squid porridge (with a few slices of squid) and 700,000 VND for the fish porridge. When arguing, he said that he saw 2 people asking the price and thought it was for 2 people so he quoted the price for 2 people, then saw 6 people so he ordered the portion for 6 people? While I pointed out the table I was sitting at and there were other people in the group sitting there. Even though at first I thought they were full, I should have come out and told the customers, right? They also said that there was nothing to bargain about these things, Vietnamese people who go out to eat don't even have any opinion (I went with 5 foreigners). I know that the prices on the island are definitely higher than on the mainland and other places, but I heard the price and thought it was acceptable so I ordered the dish, but when it came to paying the bill, it was different. Our group didn't lack money, if the price was properly quoted at the beginning, the price would be much more expensive than the market price, but it was because I had considered and accepted it, but with this way of doing business, I can only say that I will not return to this island.
Nice attraction
Great sea island view

You may heard about Diep Son via the image of sand roads connecting 3 islands.

Well, it's not there anymore. Diep Son, at the time I went there, can allow you to see only a small part of sand road, and it connected to no other island. Things were different in the past when we can all see it clear and even walk on it.

Guide said to see full road nowaday, we need to go here around 4-5 AM in the morning, when tides at lowest.
Still wild and beautiful. Went during low tide so there was a path to the island in the middle of the sea.

12/3/2016

I came here when Diep Son had less than 100 households, and only had electricity for a few hours a day

The road was clean, with some sections paved, some still sandy. The houses were simple but solid, and adults and children knew each other

There was a lot of mist, mosquitoes, and cows, and a few scattered houses selling groceries with everything from heaven to earth, like a miniature supermarket on the island

When our group arrived, the island was still very poor, and the children were lacking a lot, but they were very happy.

I only stayed on the island for 24 hours, but I really liked this place. I woke up in the morning by the sea, and on one side was the sunrise over the sea, and on the other side was the road in the middle of the sea that had caused a stir on social networks

If I have the chance, I will definitely come back here again to see how Diep Son has changed in the past 5 years!
Going from Phu Yen to the island...it feels great going through Ca pass...to the island is very beautiful

The pier to go to Diep Son island is about 60km north of Nha Trang city. The island is not too big and there is only one option when going to the island: stop at the restaurant on the island, sightsee, rest, have lunch and wait for the boat to return to the mainland :)) In return, the scenery is very beautiful, white sand + clear water + immense blue sky is an irresistible combo of beautiful scenery
The sea water is very clean, but it's a pity that we can't walk all the way to the opposite island
The island is very beautiful but still wild, there is only a speedboat service to take passengers to the island and a small restaurant on the island, the food is cheap and fresh.
Take a local bus (taxi) for 60km to north Nha Trang to Van Gia boat taxi port

You need to buy a round-trip ticket for 250,000 at the pier. The first boat will depart at 9:30 and arrive at the island in nearly 20 minutes. The island is very windy and the dunes connecting the two islands are often hidden under the sea.  It may be that tourists are forced to eat lunch on the island. The first return boat will not return until 1 pm, which is very unpleasant. There are few recreational facilities on the island, and the sand is mixed with many stones, which is very rough.
So beautiful

This is a very special island and has a wild feeling for those who love quietness and peace of mind. You have to be on time, around 8:00 am to 10:00 am, then there will be a path to go to the other side of the mountain. If you are too late, the water will rise and you will have to wade through the water. But what I like most is the feeling of walking in water up to your knees. It feels a bit scary and extremely relaxing. If you are sad or something, wading through water like this will not be sad anymore because you can see fish and coral! Girls who go this way, especially the timid ones, will feel like they are in an action movie. It's so much fun, laughing and crying while walking.
-Although it's really wild, it's suitable for girls who are dreamy and like to take pictures. Other girls who come here will say "oh, there's nothing there" so you should think about your personality and preferences before coming here ðŸ˜Š
Personally, as a writer, I really like this place because every time I drink water, it feels very exciting and strange.
-sun Ngoc Anh

Air adventure with Fly Nha Trang: The ultimate experience in nature

Fly Nha Trang's pilots turned the flight into a safe and complete masterpiece. Even though the sky changed suddenly with the opposite winds, the pilots still *actively controlled the situation*, landing passengers *smoothly like a light touch to the ground*. This new destination makes the hearts of nature lovers flutter even more - a *colorful* space next to a winding river, where the sky blends with the water to create a *vibrant visual feast*.

Not only stopping at the landscape, Fly Nha Trang also conquers customers with a *state-of-the-art* aircraft system, which is *meticulously* technically checked before each flight. The *friendly, professional* staff are always ready to support with a bright smile, from the reception stage to the most *precise* correction operations.

*Thank you Fly Nha Trang* for turning our journey to explore the sky into a *memorable* memory â€“ where professionalism meets passionate hearts!

--- ðŸ˜€
*The writing is upgraded from some of my feelings with vivid words, metaphors, engaging rhythm and emphasizing emotional experiences, helping to convey positive messages in a more engaging way after I used Deepseek ðŸ˜ŽðŸ˜†

Nhu Tien Beach is very private, suitable for teambuilding activities. The beach is very gentle, the water is clear and blue and the waves are not too strong. Located in the heart of the arc and protected by mountains, the sun is bright but the wind is very cool. I just need to lie under the shade of a coconut tree, drink coconut water and look out at the blue sea to feel completely healed ;p

The sea here is calm and cool, the water is clear enough to see the bottom. The wind blows gently, the waves are not strong so it feels very comfortable. There are no crowds, no noise, just listening to the sound of the sea is comfortable. Sitting for a while makes you forget all your tiredness, just want to stay longer to breathe the sea breeze and watch the waves gently lapping.

The beach is great, the waves aren't too strong, sun loungers are included, there's a swing, plenty of room for photos, and fine sand. The only thing is, by evening, there was a lot of trash in the sea. The food is also expensive; we ordered pancakes, which were very greasy, and they agreed to refund or replace them.

So, my honest opinion about this beach. It's far from the center (okay). The staff at the entrance were very disgruntled and rude (we paid 160,000 dong for two). We arrived at the beach and, lo and behold (we arrived around 11 a.m.), there were no free sun loungers (tourists, oh my!). They leave their towels on the sun loungers and don't lie down, so we had to settle down on the sand. Towels aren't included in the price (60,000 for two). I'd say it's some kind of special beach, but unfortunately, it's not. It would be better if they sold sun loungers instead of entrance to the beach... half of the guests would definitely have left, and there would have been room for tourists with money. Overall, the taxi cost 150,000 dong one way. And we essentially received zero service. So, I don't recommend it! Better go to Marina Beach.

Nhu Tien Beach is a beautiful and tranquil beach located in Phu Yen Province, Vietnam. Known for its clean sand, clear turquoise waters, and peaceful surroundings, it is an ideal destination for visitors seeking relaxation away from crowded tourist spots.

The beach offers a serene environment with gentle waves and soft sandy shores, perfect for swimming, sunbathing, or leisurely walks along the coastline. The natural landscape, framed by rocky outcrops and lush greenery, provides excellent opportunities for photography and enjoying the coastal scenery.

Local seafood vendors nearby offer fresh and authentic dishes, adding a cultural and culinary touch to the visit. The quiet atmosphere and unspoiled beauty make Nhu Tien Beach a great choice for families, couples, and solo travelers looking for a peaceful coastal retreat.

Whether visiting for a day or staying longer to enjoy the surrounding nature, Nhu Tien Beach leaves a lasting impression with its calm waters, scenic views, and relaxing ambiance.

To be fair, this is a beautiful beach, swimmable, with few waves due to the special terrain, a fence to limit access and lifeguards on duty, towels, life jackets and other food and drink rentals, the ticket price includes fresh water showers, and there are quite a few foreigners. However, it is advisable to avoid weekends because it is crowded and there are often group guests going on team building trips, so it is quite noisy. The next minus point is the chairs, and although the beach is quite large, there are not enough chairs for a few dozen guests to swim, and the staff supporting this area is also limited.

After reading rave reviews, I went to check it out, but it wasn't my cup of tea.
It's 11 km from the South of Nya (about 17 minutes).
Entrance is 80K, and a sun lounger is included.

This is a beach area on the hotel grounds. I had no idea where to go, so I chose a "wild" road. I ended up changing in an abandoned building. I even parked my bike haphazardly, which was eventually rolled away to the parking lot. I had to find it again. ðŸ˜†

âž•The sand is beautiful white, there's a swing and a hammock, the view is very beautiful, the entry into the sea is gentle, but I managed to find some rocks when I entered the water. âž–The rock is closed for photos, and there's trash and bags floating in the water that were cleared out in front of us (there hasn't been any rain for a week, so it just carries in from the sea in the evenings), so I can't comment on that. But the city beach closer to the south of NY is much cleaner for me, only the sand is steeper here.
I couldn't find a changing room, and the bar is overpriced.

Next time I'll go to a wild, free beach further away from here; I don't see the point of paying for admission beyond a sunbed. But, as they say, tastes differ ðŸ™ƒ.

The beach is crap, entrance is 80, then another 30 for towels, all the sunbeds are under palm trees, they don't let you move them in the sun, the sea is ordinary, it's better to go to Amiana Beach, there is construction going on nearby, everything is old

There is no privacy or beautiful water here, the rocks in the water are unsafe, this is the very case when expectation is reality, but out of boredom you can go once, and construction nearby during people's vacation is absurd, you either build or do business, and here everything is at once

Gorgeous beach, clear water, secluded, not crowded! There's an entrance fee of 80,000 rubles, but there are sun loungers, umbrellas, and so on, all included in the price, plus clean restrooms and showers! There's a cafe with cold beer. What else could you want? I recommend it.
White sand and clear water

They charge 80,000 rubles per person at the entrance. The grounds are undergoing renovations and are in a state of disrepair; there's no running water in the sinks, no showers (it's impossible to wash up after the sand).
They keep about four bembis, which sit in the heat without water. They have no cooling pools, and it looks sad. The peacocks are sad too.
To get to the women's restroom, you have to pass open men's urinals ðŸ˜‚

There's a small rock with a nice photo spot, but the rock is closed and there's a sign warning against climbing.

Tea at the buffet is 70,000 rubles (20-25,000 rubles in the city). There's no bottled water, and you can't buy drinks from the refrigerator; only their drinks are expensive.

Pros: beautiful! The mountains are a beautiful backdrop. Soft, sticky sand, very fine and pleasant! The beach is cleaned. Sun loungers are free (included in the ticket price).
The water is warm and clear (assuming there wasn't a storm before). There are no rocks, just fine sand. The entry is long and gentle, so it's perfect for families with children.
Along the way, you can also see the river and beautiful mountains.

A nice beach. There aren't many people, everyone is spaced out, and doesn't get in the way. You can't hear traffic, conversations, screams, or anything else. It's quiet and peaceful. I liked the beach. The menu is limited, but you can grab a bite. It's definitely worth getting away from the hustle and bustle; it's quiet and comfortable. You can hear the sea and the rustling palm trees.
Beautiful deserted beach. The water is very clean and clear. You should go and experience it, everyone.

We're Spanish, specifically Catalan, and we come from a land where the beaches are truly spectacular. We have the Costa Brava, with its rocky coves and clear waters; the Costa Dorada, with its extensive beaches of fine sand; and the Costa del Sol, internationally known for its beauty and atmosphere. So, when we visited Nu Thien Beach in Vietnam, we were somewhat excited, hoping to find something exotic, different, but equally attractive. However, the reality was quite disappointing.

We didn't find the beaches at Nu Thien particularly beautiful. The water never completely covers the surface, which may be fine for families with children, but it's not what we were looking for. It was also a bit murky, with a dirty feel that didn't encourage swimming. And the sand... that kind of sand that sticks to you everywhere and is uncomfortable both for walking and for lying down.

We're not saying it's a bad place, or that you can't enjoy it. Simply put, from our perspective and with the references we have at home, Nu Thien Beach fell far short of our expectations. We felt it was not enough.
The beach is inside the resort, ticket 80k/person bought at the beach gate. The sea is cool, super deep, small and pretty but there is team building so it's not noisy....

The beach is beautiful, but very dirty.
I understand that the last couple of days have been strong winds and waves, but everything that washes up on the shore can be cleaned up in an hour. And the entrance fee is 80k/person. Getting there from the city by taxi is another 130k one way.

As a result, you can't go into the water after lunch, there is not a single patch where you can swim without being afraid of being covered in bags, candy wrappers, cups, bottles. Before lunch, you can swim a little, but also in trash - not much fun.

The food is not tasty. Rice with seafood is rice with Hawaiian mix and 3 mini shrimps and a piece of squid. That's it.

There are not many sun loungers and by 11 they are all already taken, but there are wooden chairs, in a huge number. So you will have to sunbathe on a towel (30k/piece - you can rent one at the bar).

While we were relaxing, crowds of people arrived, set up speakers on both sides of us, and started blasting different music in the speakers - it was some kind of mass corporate party there.

In short, you won't find any privacy there, and you won't be able to take a nice photo either.
For trying to get to the rocks to watch the crabs - a whistle from the lifeguard.
WHAT IS THIS? We came to a private beach and there was just a bunch of garbage lying in the sea... it's absolutely not pleasant to swim here
Beautiful beach, with mountains and green coconut trees. Many Russians come here to relax. The sand is very fine.

Anyone can get to the beach for 80,000 dong. There is a mini-zoo with deer and peacocks on the territory, however, the peacocks are cramped, the cage is small.
There are not enough sunbeds, it is better to take them in advance, most guests sit on chairs.
The sea is very polluted, there is a lot of garbage and brown spots on the water. Compared to this beach, the city beach of Nha Trang seems much cleaner.
Almost every day there are events with loud music.
Closes at 5pm. Guard is rude and needs to get a personality.

quiet private beach

Sun loungers, several shops, cafes, SPA. Very civilized. Beautiful territory with many places for good photos. The only downside is a lot of garbage in the sea. The staff cleans it from the shore every half hour, but there is a lot in the water. There is a mini zoo at the entrance to the beach. Peacocks, deer... If you don't count the garbage in the water, this is a wonderful place to relax. You can take an electric car back to the hotel entrance and call a taxi there. I think I'll come here again.

Beautiful and quiet... Enjoy every minute...

Very average beach for a tropical destination. The entrance to the actual beach is 80k VND per adult. The beach itself comprises of smaller part of the entire area. There are more scenic spots along diverging paths that offer picturesque views for free, but the staff aggressively discourages visitors from stopping to take photos or enjoy these areas. We were rudely confronted by an older security guard, cigarette in mouth, riding a rusty scooter, who chased us away from one such spot. His demeanor was hostile and unprofessional, trailing us just 2-3 meters behind as we returned to the main path, as if we were trying to sneak away. At the exit gate, when we paused briefly, he waved his hand and shouted â€œGo!â€â€”the only English word he seemed to know. This level of rudeness was unwarranted and left a sour impression. The management needs to retrain their staff or reconsider who represents their business. Such unprofessional behavior tarnishes Vietnamâ€™s reputation as a welcoming destination. I strongly recommend avoiding this place unless you want a frustrating and unwelcoming experience. There are far better beaches and attractions to explore.
In principle, as a beach, the place is beautiful. There is trash, yes, on the shore, it is cleaned up. But jellyfish! On the first day of staying at the hotel, both my husband and I got a burn
We arrived at 4:15 pm, but they didn't let us in. They told us to come tomorrow.

The beach is very beautiful, picturesque. I did not like that no one warns that there are jellyfish in the sea. My child and me, and I also know other visitors were bitten by jellyfish. The bite is painful. There is a lifeguard on the shore who provided first aid. There is also a lot of garbage floating in the water, seaweed. Many of them take part in organized tours, including music performances and drone shows, which dominate the beach atmosphere. This makes it difficult to truly relax. There was a very large group of tourists from China, a lot of people, music, songs. I left my things on the sunbed, and there was a Chinese man on another sunbed nearby. I won't be back. Pros: they clean up the trash, there's a bar, they even make pizza, but there's not much to choose from. Entrance is 80,000 rubles, children under 1.2m are 40,000 rubles. Cons: there was a horde of Vietnamese schoolchildren screaming and jumping around on Sunday. There were also a lot of Russian tourists. There are few umbrellas, even fewer sun loungers, towels are thrown on everyone, and no one is lying down.

Entering through the gates of the Diamond Bay Hotel, the hotel is either abandoned or looks abandoned; the grounds are vast, but neglected. There is security.

Beautiful picturesque beach. If there were no groups of children (I understand schoolchildren on an excursion), it would be quiet, I advise you to come on weekdays. I take off a star for the garbage in the water and on the sand. Otherwise, everything is fine. Entrance is 80,000, towels are 30,000, food in the restaurant is 2x more expensive than in other places. Much better beach than many city ones. There is also a problem with sun loungers, there are few of them, mostly chairs, I had to lay towels just on the concrete in the shade
This is a very good beach for Nha Trang. Enter through the Diamond Bay Hotel, then go to the beach, pay 80 dong, and you're on the beach. It feels like a resort. I highly recommend it.
Beautiful beach. No strong waves, suitable for children to swim. But the bathroom is a bit dirty.

But there's a huge BUT!
There's trash on the beach and in the water. And it's not the trash that comes with the tide, but locally sourced trash.
If you've made the beach a paid beach, at least keep it clean.

You can enjoy swimming, enjoy the fresh air or experience water sports such as paragliding, canoeing, windsurfing... Nhu Tien beach is also a place often chosen to organize dynamic and youthful Team building activities.

Nhu Tien Beach - is one of the few beaches on the mainland that possesses a rare beauty in Nha Trang. This location is located right on the road connecting Cam Ranh airport and Cam Ranh city. Only about 10 km from the city center, hidden behind the undulating rocky mountains stretching out to the sea. Surrounded by high mountains, the sea here is quite calm. Although this beach was put into tourism exploitation a dozen years ago, its wild, interesting features and especially the quiet space. Perhaps this is the point that attracts tourists to come here.

On September 9, my group of 5 people went and stayed here.

I also wrote a few words about my first experience staying and using the service here.

- Space: Cool, chill, airy afternoon. 10/10 points
If you want to find a place to heal outside the city but don't have time to go far, this is the place to go.

- Service: A bit slow because the area has not been assigned to the staff, but in return, the enthusiasm and joy of the staff, from the security guard to the service staff to the cleaning lady, not to forget the enthusiastic and funny manager. 9/10 points
- Facilities: Personally, I have been camping in many places in the forest, so here provides relatively enough amenities for customers, but for those who are not used to camping, they will feel less than staying in a hotel, but for me, it is not a problem when there is a little lack. 9/10 points
- Food and drinks: I think the food is just okay, the shrimp is a bit greasy, but overall it's okay. Our group paid for our own beer and drinks, and the camp supported us with free service charge, which is a big plus. 8.5/10 points.
On behalf of the group, I would like to thank Duy (I don't know if he remembers the name correctly because he was too drunk at that time, if not, I apologize) for welcoming our group warmly and happily. If we have the chance, my brothers and I will come back because my younger brother only caught 2 sea urchins, and he wasn't satisfied :)))))).
Thank you May and thank you May's team very much.
Very good service well worth it

The staff was also enthusiastic, but if I needed anything, I had to wait a long time, there was no one on duty, the tent was hot and sunny... I ordered coffee but waited all day and still didn't see it, it was only 8:00-8:30, my group had to go home immediately. We were there during the holidays, on Independence Day. There weren't many people. There were enough SUPs, tables and everything. You need to buy a ticket at the entrance. We took 200,000, SUPs, catamarans are included. You need to figure out where to go and other questions yourself. It's a bit disorienting. No one will show you anything. There is no administrator on the territory itself. There are waiters. Wi-Fi works. We communicated through a translator. The SUPs were poorly inflated, but they were changed later. Overall, we liked it. Nature, lake, we had a great rest. You can rent a tent and stay overnight. The territory is very interesting. Gorgeous views.

Arrived at 1pm, waited 45 minutes for the tram to take us up. When we got there, it was raining and we were not allowed to check in. There were not enough chairs to sit and wait. The rain was pouring and we were soaked. At 3pm, we were still not allowed to check in. We asked to check out at 10am tomorrow morning. The staff at the counter just said they didn't know. There were women and children wandering around, not a single staff member was there except the staff at the counter who said they didn't know.

ZCamp in Nha Trang is a great place for outdoor recreation and sports. It has a modern and comfortable infrastructure: clean territory, comfortable training areas, a swimming pool and a recreation area by the sea. The atmosphere is very friendly, there are many active and positive people.

The staff is friendly and always ready to help, the trainers are professional and motivate you to do sports. I especially liked the combination of fitness, yoga and relaxation on the beach - all in one place.

ZCamp is ideal for those who want to combine relaxation, an active lifestyle and new acquaintances in Nha Trang. ðŸ’ªðŸŒ´â˜€ï¸

My boyfriend and I arrived with good expectations, but unfortunately, the reality turned out to be far from the photos. The room we got looked completely different: it was uncleaned, sloppy, there was a plant lying on the balcony, the door did not close well. The first impression was a complete disappointment.
The territory itself is pleasant: spacious, with beautiful nature, which somewhat saves the overall impression. But the service leaves much to be desired. The staff did not even try to inform us: no one told us what time the restaurant was open until, what activities and entertainment there were on the territory. In fact, we were simply left to figure it out ourselves.
Another thing - they gave us food, but asked us to cook it ourselves. At the same time, no information or help was provided. For a place that positions itself as cozy and hospitable, the level of service is frankly poor.
Overall: the nature and location are good, but the organization and service need to be urgently improved.

A great place for barbecue! Barbecue, coal, everything is provided and lit. All you have to do is grill your meat or order dishes and ready-made BBQ sets from the menu.

It is better to arrive in the morning. From 8 to 10, to take the best places for a picnic. But usually there are enough places, usually cafes come here, order a dish and leave soon. But nothing prevents you from spending the whole day here.

We got there by taxi Indrive for 115,000 DNG / 460 rubles, back in the evening - 150,000 DNG.

We chose the option "1 day of picnic with BBQ". It includes: barbecue, coal, kindling, grate, dishes; SUPs and catamarans; on the common area there is a pool with small slides and mattresses, a dinosaur world, an airplane and other objects. The price for such a combo: 200,000 DNG / 800 RUB for adults, 100,000 DNG / 400 RUB for children, from 8 to 16. Just an entrance ticket without a barbecue, SUPs and catamarans - 100,000 DNG / 400 RUB. After 16:00 you can fish on the territory from the shore, the places are equipped.

There is tent rental - 50,000 DNG / 200 RUB for 2 hours; rooms - 100,000 DNG for 2 hours. There are different combo options. You can request a full list in the Hall.

The prices are affordable. Very good service, if something is missing, you can ask through a translator (tongs, water, drinks, menu).

I took my own spinning rod. I bought it in a fishing store in the center. You can rent a fishing rod here in Z-camp for 50,000 DNG (Â±200 RUB) with bait. But it doesn't look serious from the outside. I didn't catch it myself, but I saw how small fish were pulled out on the other side. And I saw a bite. You can take a SUP and swim across the lake, fish on the other side.

We made the shashlik ourselves. We ordered pork neck, onions, vinegar and vegetables the day before the trip in the morning at the Go! supermarket through the app. They brought it after lunch, I paid in cash.

This was our route through Z camp. Watch more about vacations in Vietnam on the channel SUMMER IN GOA letovgoa in the search on YouTube.

There are underwater games that need bathrooms and change. Hopefully the services of the tourist area will be more complete for visitors to have the best experience.

+Booking: You should book via Zalo or call directly, I chose the Glamtrip website, when filling in the information, someone will text you via Zalo, this website is not very good because it sent me the wrong email, when booking a room, the email said there were no rooms, making me a bit distrustful of the sales person. 
+Parking: There is a parking lot for those who are afraid to enter because the terrain is difficult, narrow and very steep, anyone who buys a ticket is not encouraged to go straight in. 
+Games: There are statue painting, SUP and duck pedaling, there are some sightseeing spots but they are not yet completed, this place seems to have been a state-owned game area. 
+Room: At first, I chose a room with a view of the lake but luckily that direction was the direction of the sunset, entering the room at 3pm was like a dry sauna, even though the staff turned on the air conditioner but the room was still very hot, so hot that the bottle of cold water I brought in a while later became warm water, luckily I was able to change rooms. At night it's completely different, the air conditioner is 24 degrees but it's freezing cold omggg. The blankets and pillows are not clean and soft, when changing rooms, some people forget to put the pillowcases in, they don't scrub the bathroom (the bathroom is the place I'm most bored with) and there's no doormat. 450/person/night is too expensive, the interior has a lot of design ideas but the products used are all low quality. 
+ Food and drink: You can bring your own food but there will be an additional charge for charcoal, spoons, chopsticks, bowls, ice for 150k, and if you don't bring your own, ZCamp has a BBQ set (calculated per person). When you sit down to eat, remember to bring mosquito repellent or spray, otherwise they will kill you. 
+ Staff: Friendly and enthusiastic, but there should be more people to clean the room. 
=> Conclusion: Those are my opinions, I'm saying them so that ZCamp can accept them and change for the better, not to criticize. I tried this place once, but if I come back I'll say no.

ðŸ‡»ðŸ‡³ðŸŒŠ Con Dao â€“ Epic in the middle of the ocean ðŸŒŠðŸ‡»ðŸ‡³

In the middle of the Southern sea and sky, Con Dao is as beautiful as a green gem, but it is also a place filled with the pain and loss of the nation. From 1862, that is, just 4 years after the French colonialists opened fire to attack Da Nang port until April 1975, the French colonialists and then the American imperialists built the notorious prison system: Phu Hai, Phu Tuong, Chuong Cop, Chuong Boâ€¦ â€“ â€œhell on earthâ€ with all kinds of brutal torture.

However, the darkest place shines with immortal will. The communist soldiers, the patriots wrote an epic with their steadfast will and indomitable spirit, so that today the Fatherland is independent and the people are free, prosperous and happy.

More than 20,000 people have fallen on this beautiful island, but currently Hang Duong cemetery has only collected nearly 2,000 graves, many of which are: "Unknown martyrs". 

Before each incense stick, each tombstone, we feel so small and our hearts suddenly rise with infinite gratitude. 

During the days when the whole country joyfully celebrates the 80th anniversary of National Day (1945â€“2025), visiting Con Dao Special Zone, known as the â€œAltar of the Fatherlandâ€, bowing to commemorate and pay tribute to generations of ancestors, we can see that peace is truly beautiful and precious - living, studying, working, and contributing in an independent and free environment is truly happy...

Let me borrow the words of the poem â€œSinging on Con Dao Hellâ€ by Phung Quan to conclude my feelings:

â€œIs there any place on this earth
Where when you step foot there
We suddenly become small
Before the great soul of the peopleâ€¦â€

ðŸ™ Paying tribute to generations of ancestors - those who have fallen for the eternal existence of the Fatherland.

Con Dao Prison is a special historical relic, a "hell on earth" that witnessed the brutal torture and the indomitable spirit of thousands of Vietnamese revolutionary soldiers. When entering here, a creepy, heavy feeling enveloped me. The narrow cells, the dark cells, the tiger cages, the cow cages... all recreated in the most realistic way the hellish life that prisoners had to go through. Each story, each artifact here is a powerful testament to the brutality of the colonial regime and at the same time a praise for the indomitable will of the patriotic Vietnamese people. Con Dao Prison is not only a historical evidence but also a valuable lesson about sacrifice, patriotism and the desire for freedom. This is a place that must be visited to feel more deeply the values â€‹â€‹that we have.

Notes when visiting Con Dao Prison:
1. Buy tickets at the Museum, there are 2 forms of buying directly at the counter or scanning the code to buy online
2. When there is a tour guide, learning and exploring will be much more meaningful. If anyone goes for the first time, it is highly recommended to choose a time with a tour guide, or arrive 15-20 minutes earlier than that time to thoroughly visit the museum, because the tour guide will not be able to talk in detail about every small detail at the museum
3. The points/clusters including the museum, tiger cage, and prison are quite far from each other. It is recommended to travel by private means (limit taking taxis because they are not proactive). After the tour guide finishes narrating at one point, they will also travel by motorbike to another point to continue guiding and telling stories to everyone.
4. It is highly recommended to bring water, wear shoes, wear a hat and wear sunscreen. If you listen to the tour guide from beginning to end, it will be about 2 hours. Outdoor sightseeing time also takes up about half, so everyone should prepare the above items.

The Island Lord's Palace is one of the typical historical structures still preserved in Con Dao, located right in the center of Con Son town. Built in the late 19th century, the palace was once the residence and workplace of 53 generations of Island Lords - representatives of the colonial and imperial governments that ruled the notorious prison system in Con Dao. 

With its classic French architecture, airy space and large grounds, the Island Lord's Palace is both a symbol of power at one time and a living testament to the brutal prison regime. Today, this place is preserved as a special historical relic, displaying many valuable documents and artifacts to help visitors better understand the painful but heroic past of the nation. 

Visiting the Island Lord's Palace, visitors not only admire the ancient architecture but also have the opportunity to rediscover historical traces, paying tribute to the generations of ancestors who died for the independence and freedom of the Fatherland.

The Island Lord's Palace is one of the most prominent and impressive historical sites in Con Dao. It not only preserves important vestiges of a dark period in the nation's history, but also has profound cultural and spiritual values. 

The architecture of the palace is still quite intact, in an ancient French style, creating a solemn and majestic feeling. When coming here, visitors will learn about the lives of the Island Lords - those who once ran the notorious prison system in Con Dao. Inside the palace, there are valuable artifacts, images and documents that help viewers visualize more clearly the past of this land. 

The atmosphere at the Island Lord's Palace is very peaceful and fresh, suitable for both those who love to learn about history and those who want to find a quiet place to contemplate. The tour guides here are very enthusiastic and have extensive knowledge, making the tour more lively and meaningful. 

If you are planning to travel to Con Dao, Dinh Chua Dao is definitely a destination not to be missed to learn more about the historical depth and quiet beauty of this island.
