Visiting the Island Chief Palace in Con Dao wasn't just a sightseeing trip for me; it felt like stepping into a place thick with history and emotion. Even though it's a beautiful building in a serene setting, there's an undeniable weight to the air.

Walking through the rooms, I could almost feel the presence of the people who lived and worked there. It made me think deeply about the island's past and the lives that were touched by this place. The exhibits are presented in a way that's easy to understand, and they really helped me connect with the human stories behind the history books.

What struck me most wasn't just the facts and figures, but the quiet dignity of the palace itself. It stands as a silent witness to a significant period, and being there evoked a sense of both sadness and respect.

It's hard to put into words exactly how this place made me feel. It wasn't just about seeing old furniture or reading information panels. It was more about the atmosphere, the sense of history hanging in the air, and the quiet reminder of the human experiences that shaped this island.

If you visit Con Dao, please make time for the Island Chief Palace. It's more than just a historical site; it's a place that will stay with you long after you leave. It's a chance to connect with the past on a personal level and truly understand a piece of this island's soul. I left feeling moved and with a deeper appreciation for the stories Con Dao holds.

1. General introduction

Con Dao Museum is a place to preserve and display thousands of valuable artifacts and documents about the history of formation, struggle and development of Con Dao. This place realistically recreates the fierce period of Con Dao prison - "hell on earth" - along with tragic stories about the indomitable spirit of revolutionary soldiers.

â¸»

2. Brief and concise introduction

Con Dao Museum is a red address marking the heroic history of the nation's struggle, where visitors can learn about "hell on earth" and the steadfastness of tens of thousands of political prisoners. This is a meaningful destination for the journey back to the source.

â¸»

3. Introduction for tourism - experience

Coming to Con Dao Museum, visitors will experience a modern exhibition space, admire artifacts, vivid images of Con Dao prison, the life of island residents and heroic feats. This is a place not only to pay tribute to history but also to understand more deeply the value of peace and freedom today.

You must definitely go when you come to Con Dao. To know the history of 113 years of enemy rule that took the blood and bones of our ancestors and not our homeland. We integrate internationally and are friends with other countries, but don't forget history.

Remember to ask for the tour guide's schedule to buy tickets for the 5-location tour. The tour will start from Con Dao Museum and will move to the remaining 4 locations. The ticket price in September 2025 is about 50k/person. Go by motorbike to move between locations for convenience. The day I went from 9am to 10:30am.

Worth checking in, visiting, and learning. There are many valuable historical images and relics that help you understand, appreciate, and respect history and Con Dao more. My daughter KVy and I arrived on the occasion of September 2, 2025, near the end of the afternoon. The staff were very friendly and cheerful.
Will come back when I have the opportunity to visit more.

A place I think is really worth visiting when coming to Con Dao. The museum condenses all the information about the geography and history of Con Dao, as well as the stories of the political prisoners' resilience against the brutal rule of the colonial governments. The ticket price of 50,000 includes an explanation (according to a fixed schedule) for the cluster of 5 relics including the Museum, the cluster of 3 prisons and the Island Lord's House.

Con Dao Museum started construction on December 6, 2009 and was completed on October 10, 2010, as one of the key projects to celebrate the 1000th anniversary of Thang Long - Hanoi. In 2013, the museum officially opened to visitors, meeting the expectations of the people of the whole country as well as the people of Con Dao district. At the same time, this place is also a space to preserve sacred relics associated with former political prisoners of Con Dao during the period of fighting against colonialism and imperialism in the land once known as "hell on earth". 

Located on Nguyen Hue Street, near the French Tiger Cage relic, Con Dao Museum is located on a campus of more than 2 hectares, with a total construction area of 3,570mÂ² and an exhibition space of 1,700mÂ². 

Currently, the museum preserves and displays more than 2,000 valuable documents and artifacts. When visiting, visitors will have the opportunity to learn deeply about the nature and people of Con Dao from prehistoric and early historical times to the current development stage. At the same time, the museum also authentically recreates the history of the resilient struggle of revolutionary soldiers in the Con Dao prison system - a place once known as "hell on earth" due to brutal torture and harsh detention conditions.
A very good sized museum where I learnt a lot about Con Dao. Was lacking a bit on the natural history side. Would definitely recommend.

When I came here, I was able to delve into each historical period, from the process of exploring Con Dao, to the period when Con Dao became a "hell on earth" under the colonial and imperial regimes, and finally the process of revival and development of the heroic island. Con Dao Museum is not only a treasure trove of knowledge but also a profound reminder of the painful but also heroic past of the nation. Con Dao prison relic area is a special national relic site, a place marking the indomitable tradition of struggle of Vietnamese heroes, soldiers and patriots during 113 years of fighting against French colonialism and American imperialism by the Vietnamese people.
Construction of Con Dao Museum began on December 6, 2009, with support from the Party Committee, government, and people of Hanoi city along with the People's Committee of Ba Ria - Vung Tau province, completed on October 10, 2010 as one of the works to celebrate the 1000th anniversary of Thang Long - Hanoi.
The museum is located on Nguyen Hue Street, near the French Tiger Cage relic, on a campus of more than 2 hectares, construction area 3,570 m2, display area 1,700 m2.

Con Dao Museum is a place to store, display, preserve and introduce historical and cultural artifacts of the land and people of Con Dao through historical periods.
With 2000 documents and artifacts on display. Coming to Con Dao Museum, visitors will have a deeper understanding of the nature and people of Con Dao from prehistoric times, early history to the present stage of development and learn about the history of the Con Dao prison struggle, which is known as "Hell on Earth". Images, portraits of patriotic scholars, images of prisoners being imprisoned, tortured, and exiled in the harshest prison regime in Indochina. The examples of steadfast and indomitable fighting of heroes, revolutionary soldiers and patriots who lived, fought and sacrificed for the independence and freedom of the Fatherland.

Visiting the CÃ´n Äáº£o Museum wasn't just looking at old things in glass cases. It was a deeply moving experience that really touched my heart. Even now, thinking about it brings back a wave of emotions.

This island has a heavy history, and the museum does an incredible job of telling the stories of the people who suffered here. It's not always easy to see, but it's so important. As I walked through the exhibits, I felt a real connection to the past. I saw photos and read accounts of the prisoners, their struggles, and their resilience. It wasn't just facts and dates; it felt like I was getting a glimpse into their lives, their hopes, and their pain.

There were moments that genuinely made me feel sad and even a bit angry at the injustice they faced. But there were also stories of incredible strength and the human spirit that shone through even in the darkest times. I left feeling a profound sense of respect for those who endured so much on this island.

The museum itself is well-organized and easy to follow. The information is presented clearly, and there are enough visuals to help you understand the context. It's not overwhelming, and you can take your time to absorb everything.

For me, visiting the CÃ´n Äáº£o Museum wasn't just a tourist activity. It was a powerful and personal journey into a significant part of history. It helped me understand the weight of the past and appreciate the sacrifices made. If you come to CÃ´n Äáº£o, please make time for this museum. It's an essential experience that will stay with you long after you leave. It's a place that makes you think, feel, and remember.

This was one of the prison guards' thousands of tricks to deal with public opinion. In reality, behind this vegetable garden was a tiger cage-style prison system with extremely brutal detention cells and torture chambers.

Tiger Cages is the name given by prisoners to the disciplinary area, built in 1940. Area: 5,477m2, including 2 areas, each area has 60 rooms, above is a solid iron bar and a corridor for guards to control the prisoners. Opposite are 60 roofless rooms arranged in 4 rows, interspersed with 2 rows of Tiger Cages called "Sunbathing Rooms". Tiger Cages has no main gate, only a small path leading to Banh III (Phu Tuong camp) and Banh III (Phu Tho camp). These paths are often promptly hidden when there is news of a group of strange visitors coming to Con Dao. In 1962-1963, the US puppet built an additional Camp 5 to shield the front and also had a small path leading to Tiger Cages. Often, prisoners were beaten unconscious when being brought into the Tiger Cage, or when transferring prisoners from one prison to another, the prison guards used batons to press on the prisoners' heads, forcing them to walk silently without looking back or looking elsewhere. This made the prisoners disoriented, not knowing which prison they were being held in.

At the Tiger Cage, prisoners were never at peace, at any time there were prying eyes of the prison guards, at any time they could be beaten, sprayed with lime powder... However, the Tiger Cage was the soul in the struggle to protect the integrity of Con Dao political prisoners, associated with the feats of the anti-secession and anti-flag salute movements, associated with the name "Old Man of the Tiger Cage". Cao Van Ngoc, Luu Chi Hieu, and the five victorious stars Nguyen Duc Thuan, Phan Trong Binh, Pham Quoc Sac, Nguyen Minh, Le Van Mot and many other steadfast and indomitable examples of protecting the integrity at the Tiger Cage.

In 1969, the Saigon puppet government exiled 342 female prisoners and 2 children to Con Dao Tiger Cages. Taking advantage of the physiological characteristics of women to exile them, the prison guards repeatedly used lime powder and sharp copper-covered poles... The worst punishment was not being given water to bathe, not being given a toilet... Despite the internal regulations, female prisoners fought continuously from low to high...
It can be said that from the end of 1969 to the beginning of 1970, the female prisoners of Con Dao Tiger Cages were the bravest and most determined flag, making the enemy afraid, contributing to the encouragement of the whole island.
In 1970, from the Tiger Cages, 5 students were returned to Saigon, they denounced the Con Dao Tiger Cages regime. In July 1970, a delegation of American congressmen led by TomHarsKins and journalist Donlux went to Con Dao, discovered the Tiger Cages and witnessed with their own eyes the torture and torture of prisoners there. Among them were women, very young students, even monks and a 60-year-old woman who was blind in both eyes... In mid-July 1970, the news: "The Con Son Tiger Cages have been exposed..." was published in newspapers at home and abroad. In response to that public opinion, the Saigon puppet government was forced to demolish the Con Dao Tiger Cages.
The Tiger Cages were built by the French colonialists, but the Tiger Cages were a fierce and horrifying battlefield that made the world angry, only really starting from the tactics of denouncing communism during the US-puppet era.

On April 29, 1979, the French Tiger Cage relic was specially recognized as a National Special Monument by the Ministry of Culture and Information under Decision No. 54-VHTT.QD. On May 10, 2012, the Prime Minister signed Decision No. 548/QD-TTg to rank it as a Special National Monument.

Visiting Tráº¡i PhÃº TÆ°á»ng, also known as the French Tiger Cages, in Con Dao was an experience that went far beyond just seeing a historical site. It wasn't easy, and it definitely stirred up a lot of emotions, but it's a place I believe everyone should try to understand.

Walking through those narrow, dark corridors and seeing the small, airless cells where so many Vietnamese people were unjustly imprisoned and suffered unimaginable cruelty hit me hard. You can feel the weight of history in the very air. It's impossible to imagine the physical and mental anguish endured within those stone walls.

What struck me most wasn't just the harshness of the conditions, but the resilience of the human spirit that must have existed within those confines. Knowing that people fought for their beliefs and for the freedom of their country within those terrible cages is both heartbreaking and deeply inspiring.

It wasn't a cheerful visit, of course. There were moments I felt a knot in my stomach and tears welling up. It's a stark reminder of the darkness that humans are capable of, but also a testament to the strength and sacrifice of those who fought for a better future.

The way the site is preserved allows you to connect with the past in a very real way. You can almost hear the echoes of voices and feel the desperation. It's a powerful and sobering experience that stays with you long after you leave.

For me, visiting Phu Tuong wasn't just about learning history; it was about connecting with a profound human story of suffering, resilience, and the fight for freedom. It left a deep impression on my heart and gave me a greater appreciation for the peace and liberty we have today.

If you visit Con Dao, please make time for this important place. It's a difficult but necessary experience that offers a powerful and unforgettable glimpse into the past. It's a 5/5 for its historical significance and the profound emotional impact it had on me.

Thu Le Lake is one of the beautiful lakes in Hanoi, bordering Kim Ma and Nguyen Van Ngoc streets, next to Deawoo Hotel and in Thu Le Park.: Inside the park there is a large lake, in the middle of the lake is a large oval strip of land shaped like a teardrop. From there comes the name Thu Le, meaning to keep the teardrop inside. This lake originally belonged to the ancient Thu Le village, also known as Linh Lang Lake, the name of the god worshiped at Voi Phuc Temple. Legend has it that Linh Lang god had the merit of fighting foreign invaders during the Ly Dynasty, so he was worshiped by the villagers here. The lake is 6 hectares wide, the water is clear, and there is a peninsula.

Located more than 30km from the center of Hanoi, Dong Quan Lake (Quang Tien Commune, Soc Son District) is an ideal place for families and groups of friends to camp for the day. As the largest lake in Soc Son, Dong Quan Lake is surrounded by 3 hills and forests, so the air is fresh, airy, the scenery is charming and quite wild. Coming to Dong Quan Lake, away from the dust and noise of the city, you will "live slower" when enjoying the quiet, peaceful atmosphere with relatives and friends. There are large lawns for groups to organize collective games and exercise. Bring bicycles, camping tents, snacks, cameras... to record relaxing moments together. If you do not have the conditions to bring a lot of things, you can be completely assured because here we provide full services at affordable prices. A tent for a group of 4 to 6 people costs 130,000 VND/day and 160,000 VND/night; a tent for a group of 15 people costs from 220,000 to 260,000 VND/night.

In addition, you do not have to worry about preparing food because there are pre-marinated foods for sale here such as: Hill chicken, pork: 130,000 VND/kg, chicken thighs: 90,000 VND/kg, and bread, potatoes, corn for you to grill on the stove. In addition to the cost of renting a tent and buying food, you only have to spend 45,000 - 55,000 VND/person for a day's entrance ticket or staying overnight. In addition, you do not have to pay any other costs.

One small note when coming to Dong Quan Lake is that there are many trees here, so remember to bring insect repellent and especially need to fully comply with regulations on environmental hygiene and disease prevention. 
If you have planned to go to Dong Quan Lake, you should go for 2 days and 1 night because the night is the most interesting time. What could be more wonderful than when a group of friends or families go into the forest together to collect firewood, make a fire, set up tents and cook their favorite dishes. When night falls, everyone gathers together in the flickering firelight, watching the lake sparkling under the moonlight and chatting and singing together. 
The most memorable experience is sleeping overnight in a tent in the middle of a wild natural landscape. Waking up early in the morning, a sparkling scene appears before your eyes. The gentle sunlight of dawn shines down on the lake, making everything seem to come to life. Take the opportunity to walk or run a few laps, take deep breaths of the fresh morning air, and you will welcome a day full of positive energy.

If you are looking for a place to both **breathe fresh air** and **have a bit of Vietnamese spirituality and history**, then **Saint Giong Monument on Soc Son Mountain** is a destination worth trying at least once

- Location & Directions

About 40km from the center of Hanoi, about 1 hour by motorbike. The road to Soc Son Mountain is quite easy to go, only the last part is a bit steep. You can park your car at the foot of the mountain and **climb about 400 stone steps** to the top - a bit tiring but the scenery is very beautiful, cool and quiet.

- First impressions

Upon reaching the top, **a giant bronze statue of Saint Giong appears extremely majestic**. Giong rides an iron horse, stretching his body to fly up to the sky - looking closely, you can see every delicate, strong and proud detail. Standing close to the statue feels like being "transmitted with energy" of the national spirit.

- Landscape & atmosphere

The space on the top of the mountain is airy, cool wind, panoramic view of Soc Son. If you go early in the morning or late in the afternoon, the sunlight shining on the statue is extremely beautiful, looking through the camera will make the picture "artistic". In addition, there are **Non Nuoc Pagoda** and **Soc Temple** nearby - you can combine sightseeing, worshiping Buddha, praying for peace.

- Personal feelings

What I like most is **the feeling of climbing the mountain while enjoying the scenery**, the higher you go, the more peaceful you feel. The statue of Saint Giong is not only beautiful but also makes me feel **national pride**, remembering the story of the hero of the village of Giong who defeated the An invaders and then flew to heaven.

- Small suggestion

* You should bring drinking water and sneakers because you have to climb quite a lot.
* If you go to the temple, remember to dress politely.
* The best time is **January - March of the lunar calendar**, when there is a very exciting **Giong Soc Son festival**

The Saint Giong Monument is a monumental cultural and historical work, symbolizing the patriotism, indomitable will and aspiration for independence and freedom of the Vietnamese people. This is one of the largest and most impressive monuments in the country.

The Saint Giong Monument at the top of Soc Son Mountain is a majestic architectural work with profound historical significance. Located in a high position, the monument stands tall in the middle of the majestic mountains and forests, recreating the image of Saint Giong riding an iron horse, pulling bamboo to fight off the An invaders. From the foot of the mountain, visitors will have a journey to the top to admire the monument up close, and when arriving, you will feel the majesty along with a panoramic view of the green Soc Son. This is not only a work of sculptural art but also a symbol of patriotism and the indomitable strength of the Vietnamese people, bringing a sense of pride and sacredness to every Vietnamese person when admiring it.

Saint Giong Monument is a sculpture located on the top of Soc Mountain, Phu Linh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi[1]. The monument was built to commemorate the merits of Phu Dong Thien Vuong - a saint in Vietnamese legend. This is one of the key cultural works to celebrate the 1000th Anniversary of Thang Long - Hanoi

The monument is cast in pure bronze, has a height to the top of 11.07 m with an extension of 16 m, and an estimated weight of 85 tons. The statue is placed on Ve Linh peak - the highest peak of Soc mountain, with the absolute height of the place where the statue is placed after completing the renovation is 297 m[3].
The statue simulates the image of a young saint carrying bamboo and ivory, spurring his horse toward the blue sky. The statue's base is shaped from the stylization of clouds and halos, clearly demonstrating the "dynamic" nature of the statue. The statue is placed facing the South, said to show that Saint Giong is heading to his motherland in the South (Phu Dong, Gia Lam), and at the same time is looking after the territory of the entire country of Vietnam.

Thanh Giong monument area is located on the top of Soc mountain at an altitude of about 300 m, including a 1500 mÂ² ceremony yard, communal house and a number of auxiliary buildings such as management house, parking lot, rest hut... There are 3 paths leading to the monument area, including 1 large paved road for motor vehicles and 2 small paths with paved stairs, allowing visitors to climb from Soc temple or Non Nuoc pagoda.

Hoan Kiem Lake, the heart of Hanoi, was originally a branch of the Red River. After many ups and downs, the branches of the Red River that brought water to the city were buried, so Hoan Kiem Lake became the "horseshoe lake" as it is today. The lake's water surface is always green, so the lake is also called Luc Thuy. Hoan Kiem Lake is associated with the legend of the Divine Turtle who offered a precious sword to King Le Loi and when peace came, received the sword back. That legendary story is based on the true detail that Hoan Kiem Lake has a special species of Turtle, very large in size, soft shell and currently there are only a few in the world. During the Tran Dynasty, the lake was used for the purpose of training warships, at that time the area was still very large and connected to the Red River. Currently, the lake is planned to be the center of the capital, and around the lake are some famous landmarks such as Turtle Tower, The Huc Bridge, Ngoc Son Temple. On weekends, the area around the lake becomes a walking street and public playground for thousands of people. In 2025, the areas: Shark's Jaw, the power plant area will be cleared to create a square, playground, and subway station for this very busy area full of historical and legendary relics.
âœ¨

Turtle Tower is a cultural and historical symbol, built on a small mound in the middle of Hoan Kiem Lake, Hanoi. The name Turtle Tower comes from the fact that the tower was built on the mound where the turtles of Hoan Kiem Lake often sunbathe. 
Symbolic meaning: Turtle Tower has many meanings, associated with the legend of King Le Loi returning the magic sword to the Golden Turtle and symbolizing the patriotism and studiousness of the nation. 
- The tower was built in 1884, after the French occupied Hanoi, by the wealthy tycoon Ba Ho Kim. Initially, he intended to bury the remains of his parents here, then built the tower. 
- On top of the tower there used to be a miniature Statue of Liberty, but it was demolished.

ðŸHanoi Hoan Kiem Lake ðŸ“–Wikipedia: Hoan Kiem Lake (Vietnamese: Há»“ HoÃ n Kiáº¿m) is a natural freshwater lake in the heart of Hanoi, Vietnam, located in the eponymous Hoan Kiem District. It is a famous landmark and tourist attraction in Hanoi, and an important place for residents to relax and have fun. During the Ly and Tran dynasties, it was called Green Water Lake. Later, due to its use as a venue for naval training and inspections, it was renamed Water Army Lake. It was also known as Zuo Wang Lake. Legend has it that Le Loi, the founding emperor of the Later Le Dynasty, once found an ancient sword in the lake and returned it to a sacred turtle in the lake, hence the name Hoan Kiem Lake. Hoan Kiem Lake is a tributary of the Red River. After its formation, it still connected to the Red River a short distance to the east, but was later separated by a levee. The lake is oval in shape, narrow from north to south, with an area of â€‹â€‹approximately 12 hectares and an average depth of approximately 1.2 meters. The lake contains two small islands. The smaller one, Turtle Hill Island, is located in the center. It has no access to the shore and is inaccessible to tourists. A turtle tower stands on the island. The larger one, Ngoc Son Island, is located in the north of the lake. The Ngoc Son Shrine is built on the island. In front of the shrine, a wooden arch bridge called Qixu Bridge connects to the eastern shore.

Hoan Kiem Lake once housed one of the world's few remaining populations of Yangtze giant softshell turtles. Some Vietnamese biologists believe they are a distinct species, called the Hoan Kiem softshell turtle. On January 19, 2016, the last Yangtze giant softshell turtle in Hoan Kiem Lake was found dead, shocking the Vietnamese public. (October 14, 2025)

Hoan Kiem Lake is truly one of the most beautiful and worth-chilling places in Hanoi. Not only because of the scenery but also because of its very own â€œsoulâ€ â€“ both ancient and modern, both peaceful and bustling.

During the day, the sunlight reflects on the clear blue lake surface, the wind blows coolly, sitting on the stone bench by the lake you can watch the streets, watch pedestrians, tourists take pictures, or simply let your soul drift to the rustling sound of leaves. The air is much fresher and cleaner than other central areas â€“ the feeling is right in the heart of the city but still has its own peaceful corner.

When the sun sets, the lake lights up, Turtle Tower, The Huc Bridge, Ngoc Son Temple light up brilliantly, shimmering extremely romantically. Walking around the lake at night is an experience that never gets boring â€“ both cool and has a gentle, pleasant vibe. On weekends, the walking street opens, there is music, street artists, children playing, the elderly exercising... creating a very "Hanoi" atmosphere, both modern and still imbued with identity. 

Hoan Kiem Lake is now very clean, the trees are well cared for, there are many stone benches, and comfortable seats. Sitting here all day is not boring - chilling coffee in the morning, eating around the old town at noon, walking around the lake in the afternoon, watching the lights in the evening... One lap is enough to live for the whole day.

Ham Lon Lake is located at the foot of Ham Lon Mountain, the highest mountain in the Doc Ton range in Soc Son. The lake is about 40km from Hanoi City Center in the direction of the North Thang Long - Noi Bai Expressway. Because it is quite easy to go, it is not too difficult for you to travel here to visit and enjoy the beautiful scenery. Ham Lon Mountain is 462m above sea level. At the foot of Ham Lon Mountain is the large Nui Bau Lake, the water surface is immense, green, calm and peaceful. Although the surrounding scenery is a bit wild, thanks to this, Ham Lon Mountain has become a favorite place for many young people who love backpacking and camping overnight in the middle of majestic nature. 
Come here in the summer or autumn to check in and trek, it is very enjoyable

Only 40 minutes from the capital, a very suitable place for sightseeing, camping, trekking, and hiking. Vast mountains and lakes, majestic views, airy space. I went up during the dry season so the lake didn't have much water, and the pine hills were also controlled burning so there weren't many beautiful pictures.
The population around here is sparse but the amenities are complete, with many diverse and comfortable homestays; Families going on a weekend vacation don't have to worry too much. Visiting Ham Lon Mountain, you also have many more spots such as Giong lantern and Viet Phu Thanh Chuong to check in and take photos.

ðŸ’¥ There are many ways to go up the mountain, around the lake are homestays, all the campsites have trails up the mountain.
If you want to climb gently, just follow the big road. If you like to take shortcuts, take the smaller, steeper trails, you should have a walking stick, there are colored ropes on the road.
If you want to climb all the way to the top, search the map for the top of the mountain, choose the home with the nearest way up and follow it.

ðŸ’¥ Our criteria for going is to heal, but not to tear up our wallets ðŸ¤£ At first, we wanted to go to Huong Pagoda for the romantic scenery, but it was crowded and we couldn't book a car, so we changed direction. Who would have thought it would be so convenient and cheap.

The purpose of my trip was to climb the mountain, not to camp, so the things I brought were limited, neat, mostly water, snacks available at home (eating a lot when climbing the mountain will be heavy on the stomach, causing discomfort, you can have breakfast and leave it for a delicious snack when returning to the city center)

At first, getting off the bus and walking in made me feel a bit tired. But it was very good to warm up, when climbing, my legs were less sore, and when returning, walking also helped stretch my muscles after climbing the mountain. If you don't stretch your muscles, you will have a sore groin the next day.

I didn't climb to the top, but climbed until 12 o'clock, because sometimes, in the city, I feel dusty and have difficulty breathing, and my mind is foggy. I wanted to go and sweat to wake up. Huhu, the smell of pine wood is cool and soothing, making me want to cry.

I just left and there were lychee, musk, grapefruit, jun... flowers all over the road planted by the homestay.

Before going, my friend bought lemon and salt water, and I brewed a pot of plum tea, licorice with a little salt. The conclusion is that the other tea is too sweet, if you buy it later, buy mineral water or medicine in the pharmacy. It's worse than my tea. The best thing is that it doesn't sting ðŸ¤£ðŸ¤£ðŸ¤£ Oh my gosh, if it stings, it'll itch like hell. The peak of the 462m Flagpole Mountain was formerly called the roof of Hanoi. Now, many people who go to Ham Lon Dam like to climb to the top. It takes about 120 minutes to get to the top from Ham Lon Lake (depending on the climbing and resting speed and depending on the climbing route). Be sure to prepare good climbing shoes. When going down, tie your shoes firmly because the toes are pushed down when going downhill. This is a pine forest, so the pine leaves fall all over the road. If it rains, it is very slippery. You should prepare a walking stick from home or take a small wooden tree around the house to park your car by the lake. Climb the mountain with as little gear as possible, but you must have a water bottle. The phone signal is sometimes there and sometimes not. Climbing to the top of Ham Lon, besides the road that people often take, there is a more difficult road along the dry stream bed. If it is the rainy season, you should not go because the flood water will rise and be very dangerous. When going down from the top of the Flagpole, there are many ways down: straight towards the stone slab marking the high point, go down the wide and moderately steep road. You will pass several broadcasting towers. Go down to the left of the landmark stone slab, the steep road is vertical but shorter than the above road. The landing point of these two roads is near the Ham Lon lake dam. The road behind the landmark stone slab will go down the other side of the mountain, a few kilometers away from the lake. This road is relatively steep but has more trees, in the rainy season, many trees fall. This road has many slippery rocks... In addition, there are many other roads, please explore ......
If you go all day, you should bring a phone charger, you can charge it at the parking lots, eat and drink next to Ham Lon lake. The food here is reasonably priced. A chicken costs about 300k (8/2024) A group of about 10 people eating lunch splits about 150k/person. In the long term, to ensure environmental hygiene, food vendors, parachute rental shops... next to the lake must have their own kitchen wastewater discharge lines, not discharge directly into the lake as it is now...

Non Nuoc Pagoda is an ancient pagoda with a history of thousands of years from the Le Dynasty, located in the special national relic complex of Soc Temple, below is the Vietnam Buddhist Academy. This is a pagoda associated with many names of famous Zen masters in Buddhism. Today, the pagoda has been invested in extremely beautiful renovation with ancient architecture made entirely of wood, standing out with a tall bronze Buddha statue in the main hall, very majestic and solemn. The space in the pagoda is very quiet, suitable for those who want to find a deep place.

Non Nuoc Soc Son Pagoda is a famous spiritual destination, associated with the story of Saint Giong defeating the An invaders that has been passed down for generations. This place is not only famous for its unique architectural beauty, but also a place to preserve the historical, cultural and artistic values of our country. 

A few words about Non Nuoc Soc Son Pagoda, Hanoi. 
Non Nuoc Soc Son Pagoda, also known as Soc Son Vuong Thien Tu, is located in Phu Linh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi city. The ancient pagoda is located in the famous Soc Temple relic complex, at an altitude of more than 110m above the foot of the mountain. Non Nuoc Pagoda is a place to worship Buddha according to the Northern Buddhist sect - one of the largest Buddhist sects in our country.
Big, beautiful, quiet temple

Non Nuoc Pagoda - first time visitingðŸ¥°

The first time visiting, I was really surprised. It's been a long time since I had such a "Wow" feeling about a pagoda with majestic but somewhat mysterious architecture on the mountain. The pagoda is isolated on a high mountain, the architecture is harmonious, the roof is softly curved between the clouds of Soc Son. The air is quiet, fresh, each step seems lighter.
The pagoda was quite deserted when I visited, there were only a few soldiers, nuns and novices sweeping the outside of the pagoda. I stood still for a while, not because my feet were tired, but because of the atmosphere...
I didn't expect there to be a place with such a strange architecture.

It is known that the ancient pagoda dates back to the Tien Le Dynasty, where Zen Master Ngo Chan Luu, who was given the title Khuong Viet Dai Su by King Dinh, used to preside over it.

The history of Non Nuoc Pagoda dates back a long time. The temple's documents record that, based on the book Thien Uyen Tap Anh and the book Dai Viet Su Ky Toan Thu, the abbot of the temple was Ngo Chan Luu (933 - 1011), a member of the 4th generation of the Vo Ngon Thong Zen sect. In 971, he was given the title Khuong Viet Dai Su by King Dinh Tien Hoang. By the end of the Ly Dynasty, the temple had two eminent abbots, Zen Master Truong Nguyen (1110 - 1165) and Zen Master Nguyen Hoc (? - 1181), both of whom belonged to the 10th generation of the Vo Ngon Thong Zen sect.

I will definitely come back. Not necessarily because of my beliefs, but because of the rare feeling of standing in the middle of mountains and rivers, and feeling at peace.

P/s: For those who like to take souvenir photos, there are also many beautiful ancient-style photo angles hereðŸ¥°

Non Nuoc Pagoda, also known as Soc Thien Vuong Thien Tu, is located in the Soc Temple relic area, at an altitude of more than 110m above the foot of the mountain. The pagoda is located in the middle of a mountain range in the shape of an arc, reminiscent of a person sitting on a throne. From here, one can see the clear blue lake and prosperous villages of Ve Linh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi city. 

The pagoda has now gone through a period of disrepair. In 2000, Venerable Thich Thanh Quyet carried out the work of rebuilding the pagoda and in particular, he cast a bronze statue of Buddha Shakyamuni. This statue became the largest bronze Buddha statue in Vietnam at that time.

The pagoda is often called Non Nuoc Pagoda, located in Phu Linh Commune, Soc Son District, on the outskirts of Hanoi, at an altitude of 110m above the foot of the mountain. The pagoda belongs to the Northern sect. The pagoda is located in the Soc Temple relic area. According to legend, after defeating the An invaders, on the way back to Soc Mountain, Saint Giong stopped here and went down to bathe in West Lake. On the way, Saint Giong forgot his iron whip that was broken in the battle. Therefore, the people built a temple to worship him. 

The pagoda was established a long time ago. According to the pagoda's documents, according to the book Thien Uyen Tap Anh and the book Dai Viet Su Ky Toan Thu, the Zen master who presided over the pagoda was Ngo Chan Luu (933 - 1011) of the 4th generation of the Vo Ngon Thong Zen sect. In 971, he was given the title Khuong Viet Dai Su by King Dinh Tien Hoang. By the end of the Ly Dynasty, the pagoda had two eminent monks as abbots, Zen Master Truong Nguyen (1110 â€“ 1165) and Zen Master Nguyen Hoc (? â€“ 1181) of the 10th generation of the Vo Ngon Thong Zen sect.

Non Nuoc Pagoda (literally Soc Thien Vuong Thien Tu) is located in the Soc Temple relic complex at an altitude of more than 110 m above the foot of the mountain. The pagoda is located right in the middle of a mountain range in the shape of an arc, like a person sitting on a throne, looking down at the clear lake and the prosperous villages of Ve Linh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi.

The pagoda is now in disrepair. In 2000, Venerable Thich Thanh Quyet organized the reconstruction of the pagoda and cast the largest bronze statue of Buddha Shakyamuni in our country at that time.
The pagoda is located on the back of Soc mountain, at the foot of the second slope. The architecture is beautiful and majestic. You can climb or take a motorbike taxi to get there.

Non Nuoc Pagoda Hanoi is located about 35km from the center of Hanoi. The pagoda also has another name, Soc Thien Vuong Thien Tu, located in Phu Linh commune, Soc Son district, on the outskirts of Hanoi. Non Nuoc Pagoda belongs to the Soc Temple Relic Complex. Non Nuoc Pagoda Hanoi was rebuilt on the slope of Non mountain, south of Nha Bia mountain. The pagoda stands out with its main hall covering an area of â€‹â€‹260m2, 14m high, using up to 80 lim wood columns with a length of 14m and a diameter of 35cm. Non Nuoc Pagoda is the pagoda with the largest number of lim wood columns in the main hall in Vietnam today. In total, the pagoda used up to 30 tons of bronze to cast Buddha statues, 600m3 of lim wood, 30m3 of green stone... for construction.

The road up to the pagoda is quite steep, so be careful when moving. The pagoda's scenery is beautiful, peaceful and quiet. The pagoda is close to Giong Temple, going to the top where there is a statue of Saint Giong to see the view down is also very cool.
This is a great temple to visit. The view from the top is peaceful.
The temple was built during the Dinh Dynasty, with the great monk Khuong Viet as the first abbot. Through the ups and downs of time and history, the temple is still majestic! Sacred and ancientâ€¦

Non Nuoc Pagoda (literally Soc Thien Vuong Thien Tu) is located in the Soc Temple relic complex at an altitude of more than 110 m above the foot of the mountain. The pagoda is located right in the middle of the arc-shaped mountain range, like a person sitting on a throne, looking down at the clear blue lake and the prosperous villages of Ve Linh village, Phu Linh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi city. According to Thien Uyen Tap Anh and Dai Viet Su Ky Toan Thu, the first Zen master to preside over this pagoda was Ngo Chan Luu (933-1011), a descendant of Ngo Quyen. In 971, he was given the title Khuong Viet Quoc Su by King Dinh Tien Hoang. He was the first Zen master to be awarded the title Quoc Su by the feudal state of Vietnam. History records that this Quoc Su and Van Hanh Zen Master assisted Ly Cong Uan in ascending the throne. In 1010, Ly Cong Uan moved the capital from Hoa Lu (Ninh Binh) to Thang Long, opening the most prosperous period in Vietnamese history. Khuong Viet National Master became the National Master of Vietnam three dynasties (spanning three dynasties Dinh - Le - Ly).

The ancient pagoda has a history of more than 1,000 years. The pagoda was built on the old pagoda land from the Tien Le Dynasty, in the ancient pagoda architectural style of 7 compartments and 2 wings, decorated with motifs and patterns also following the original model of the Tien Le Dynasty. 

Because it is at an altitude of 110m above the foot of the mountain, the pagoda is very cool and has a peaceful space

VIET PHU THANH CHUONG - A SPRING VISIT DESTINATION AT THE BEGINNING OF THE YEAR ðŸŒ¸âœ¨

Located in the mountainous area of â€‹â€‹Soc Son, Viet Phu Thanh Chuong is not only a cultural attraction but also preserves the quintessence of Vietnamese architecture and art. Located in Hien Ninh commune, Soc Son district, Hanoi, about 40km from the city center, this place is easy to travel by motorbike, car or taxi.

Viet Phu has a campus of more than 8,000mÂ², recreating traditional architectural space with typical works such as Northern traditional houses, ethnic stilt houses, communal houses, pagodas, ancient village gates. The impressive highlight is the Tho Ha village gate (restored from Duong Lam ancient village), banyan trees, wells, and jars that evoke memories of the old countryside. The Bat Trang brick-paved road leading to the palace, the mossy walls, the wooden porch, the stone steps... all create a nostalgic, poetic space. 

This is an ideal place to take photos with a space full of cultural features. The ancient houses with yin-yang tiled roofs, square brick courtyards and red parallel sentences bring the atmosphere of the old Tet. The lake in the palace reflects the cool green trees, suitable for traditional Ao Dai photos. 

â° Opening hours: 9:00 - 17:00 daily
ðŸŽŸ Ticket price: 150,000 VND/adult, 120,000 VND/student, children under 110cm are free
ðŸ›µ Transportation: Follow the direction of Thang Long highway, turn to Soc Son on the way to Vinh Phuc, there will be signs on the side of the road to guide you. 

If you love nostalgic space and want to enjoy a peaceful spring day, Viet Phu Thanh Chuong is definitely a destination not to be missed!

The place preserves the thousand-year-old cultural architecture of the Vietnamese people with a massive amount of works such as stilt houses, wells, temples, communal houses, Buddha statues, water puppet lakes... Artist Thanh Chuong has excelled in designing these classical and purely Vietnamese works on a land area of â€‹â€‹about 1 hectare. The land has many different heights, but the artist has cleverly arranged the works in the most suitable positions, while this work honors the beauty of the adjacent work. The entire Viet Palace is covered by many types of ancient trees, so on hot summer days, the air and temperature are always cooler than the surrounding areas. The ancient wells were built from dozens of stone mortars, the well walls are made of stone, and there are still many worn traces from rope marks hundreds of years ago. A stilt house is firmly preserved at the original level with a thatched roof, wooden pillars and probably only used mortise and tenon joints. The thatched house was newly built but still retained the structure and materials from the past, this type of house only remains in childhood memories.

This place has a rich collection, not easy to absorb in 1 day without being equipped with knowledge about Vietnamese culture and history. Many beautiful angles to take photos in the style of Northern countryside.

A small stone church, probably nearly a hundred years old, is nestled in the primeval forest halfway up Tan Vien mountain. Although the roof has completely collapsed, some stone walls are still standing, some windows and arched doors are still intact, the cross symbol is still on the wall, the slender bell tower is tall. After many events of time and war, the materials to build the roof, the furniture and the doors are no longer there, instead many types of natural forest trees grow interspersed inside and around the church, vines and moss cover the corners of the walls, making the church magically beautiful, especially when the sunlight shines through the leaves. The summer weather here is very cool because the church is located in a large forest with very few constructions. The road up is quite steep, curved and small, so traveling by car is very difficult and dangerous. Highland tourist areas with similar terrain to Ba Vi such as Sapa and Tam Dao all have ancient churches built of stone and are still relatively intact to this day.

Ham Long Church, with its full name of Saint Anthony Church, is located on the peaceful Ham Long Street in the center of Hanoi. Different from the ancient and massive appearance of the Great Church, Ham Long has its own beauty, both solemn and close, warm, attracting all eyes with its unique architecture and peaceful space. 

Ham Long Church was built in 1934, designed and supervised by French priest Antoine Depaulis. The architecture of the church is a harmonious combination of classical Gothic style and local materials, creating an impressive and unique work. 

At first sight, the church makes a strong impression with three facades opening to the main streets of Ham Long, Ngo Thi Nham and Phan Chu Trinh. This creates an airy space, attracting natural light and bringing a sense of spaciousness. The main construction materials are boulders, terracotta bricks and lime mortar, creating a rustic, intimate but still solid and sturdy beauty. 

Inside the church, the space becomes even more splendid and magical. With a system of soaring domes, large pillars and exquisite stained glass windows, the light from the outside shines in, creating a sacred, pure space. The most prominent is the elaborately carved altar, along with solemnly placed statues of saints. All details show the meticulousness and ingenuity of the craftsmen, bringing a unique artistic beauty. 

Not only an architectural work, Ham Long Church is also a space of peace and faith. Located in a crowded area, the church brings a strange sense of tranquility. When entering the campus, you will feel separated from the noise of the streets. 

For parishioners, Ham Long Church is a common home where they pray together, share their faith and find comfort in their souls. Especially, on major holidays such as Christmas or Easter, the church is splendidly decorated, attracting not only parishioners but also tourists to visit and admire. 

In addition, the church also plays an important role in preserving and promoting cultural and religious values. Community activities, catechism classes and hymn concerts are regularly held, helping to strengthen solidarity and spread good values. 

Ham Long Church is an architectural and cultural highlight of Hanoi. This place is not only a religious building but also an artistic space, a peaceful place for people to find peace of mind. With its unique beauty and important role in the community, Ham Long Church deserves to be a destination not to be missed when exploring the beauty of the capital.

Ham Long Church is located in the central area of â€‹â€‹Hanoi and is also known as St. Anton Church. St. Anton is a Portuguese priest with a profound knowledge of theology and the Bible, and is said to have performed miracles. The church was completed in 1939 and designed by Vietnamese architect Ly Duc Than. Although not as large as Hanoi Cathedral, the design is also beautiful and impressive. Due to the use of domes with traditional materials such as lime, straw, and paper, the sound resonates in the church space, so there is no need for modern sound equipment and the speeches still have clear sound. Due to the small area of â€‹â€‹the campus, the church rooms, statues, and miniatures are quite small, but they are carefully crafted, meticulous, and very beautiful. Thai Ha Church is one of the important religious centers of the Archdiocese of Hanoi, closely associated with the history of formation, development and memorable events of Vietnamese Catholicism. This place is not only a sacred pilgrimage site but also a symbol of the steadfastness and steadfast faith of the community of believers. 

1. History of formation and development

Thai Ha Church belongs to the Redemptorist Order, founded in 1928 by Redemptorist priests from Canada. With the mission of spreading the Gospel and serving the poor, the monks here have played an important role in developing the faith life of the parishioners in the Hanoi area. 

Over many historical periods, the church has continuously expanded in scale and influence, becoming a place where a large number of parishioners gather to attend mass, learn catechism and practice charitable activities. 

2. Architecture and sacred space

Thai Ha Church has a strong European architectural style, with a typical Gothic style. The church is designed with a high dome, creating a solemn and sacred space. Inside, the altars are elaborately decorated, highlighted by the statue of Our Lady of Perpetual Help - the patron saint of the Redemptorists.

The church grounds are spacious, with many spaces for pastoral activities, helping parishioners have a place to meditate and pray. In particular, the statue of Our Lady of Perpetual Help right in front of the church yard is an important highlight, where believers come to offer prayers in difficult times.

3. Important events

Thai Ha Church is not only a place of worship but also a witness to many historical events. One of the most prominent events is the land dispute between the Catholic Church and the local government, which has been going on since 2008. Thai Ha Parish has been persistently fighting to reclaim land that belonged to the Church but was confiscated in the past. 

The prayer marches of parishioners here have attracted great attention, becoming a symbol of steadfastness in faith and justice. Despite many difficulties, the parish still maintains its mission of serving parishioners and continues important pastoral activities. 

4. Religious and pastoral activities 

Thai Ha Church is one of the most dynamic Catholic centers in Hanoi, with many religious and charitable activities. Every week, the mass here attracts a large number of parishioners. In particular, the prayer sessions with Our Lady of Perpetual Help every Wednesday are of interest to many believers, becoming a special spiritual tradition of the parish. 

In addition, the church also organizes programs to support the poor, care for the sick and educate the faith for young people. These activities clearly demonstrate the spirit of love and service of the Redemptorists.

5. Conclusion

Thai Ha Church is not only a beautiful architectural work but also an important center of faith of Hanoi Catholicism. With its long history, sacred space and profound historical imprints, this place has become an indispensable destination for believers as well as tourists who want to learn about Vietnamese Catholicism.

Despite many events, Thai Ha parish has maintained its perseverance and loyalty to the faith, continuing to be a bright spot in the religious life of the Vietnamese Catholic community.

The St. Joseph's Cathedral, Hanoi (official name: St. Joseph's Cathedral, Hanoi) is a magnificent Catholic church built during the French colonial period, located near Hanoi's Old Quarter. It appears to be a very popular tourist attraction (just a few minutes' walk from Hoan Kiem Lake).
Constructed in 1886 (during the French colonial period) in the Neo-Gothic style, it is said to have been modeled after Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris. Its impressive stonework features twin towers approximately 64 meters high.

Hanoi Cathedral: St. Joseph's Cathedral is a must-see destination in Hanoi. Whether you are attracted by its historical significance, architectural beauty or spiritual atmosphere. 
St. Joseph's Cathedral, located in Hanoi's Old Quarter, is a stunning architectural work that is a testament to the city's rich history and architectural heritage. Built during the French colonial period, the church is reminiscent of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, with its towering spires and intricate stained glass windows. The church bells ring out in the heart of the Old Quarterâ€¦. 
Outside, its ancient facade exudes timeless beauty, while inside it offers a serene and spiritual atmosphere. Visitors can admire the ornate altars, traditional carvings and brilliant stained glass windows that add color to the solemn space. The church remains an active place of worship, regularly hosting services that attract both locals and tourists. 
The Cathedral Street surrounding the church is a vibrant area with many cafes, boutiques and restaurants, making it the perfect place to explore after visiting the landmark.

It's an interesting place, however, there are no guided tours or audio guides. What little I know about it is thanks to Google and Chat GPT. Also, don't expect to see a cathedral like those in Europe or Latin America; it's quite modest.

Hanoi Cathedral was built from 1882 to 1886 in European Gothic architecture, with a mix of Vietnamese architecture and materials at that time such as: elaborately carved wooden screens in the sanctuary, gilded altars, terracotta tiled roofs. The church was built from the location of Bao Thien Pagoda, this large pagoda was built during the Ly Dynasty, and was destroyed many times through years of war. The Cathedral was built with bell towers on both sides, in the middle is a stone cross. Some important materials were imported from France such as 5 bells and 1 clock on the facade. In front is a statue of the Virgin Mary holding the Child Jesus, standing on a fierce beast with bared teeth, but the faces of the Virgin Mary and the Child Jesus are very peaceful, without any anxiety. Inside the church is a terracotta statue of Saint Joseph. After more than 100 years, the Church is still majestically beautiful in the capital.

Quietly nestled in the heart of Vietnam's capital, Hanoi, the Imperial Citadel of Thang Long is a relatively recent historical site, having been inscribed as Vietnam's sixth World Heritage Site in 2010. This site is more than just an ancient city wall; it's a "living layer of history," a record of the rise and fall of Vietnamese dynasties spanning over a thousand years, layer upon layer.

The name of the site, Thang Long, means "rising dragon." It is the ancient name of Hanoi, which served as the administrative center of various dynasties from 1010, when Ly Taizu, founder of the Ly Dynasty, established the capital here, until the Nguyen Dynasty moved its capital to Hue in 1804.

Walking through this vast site is a grand historical pilgrimage, reliving how power was exercised in Vietnam from the 7th to the 19th centuries. The fact that it opened to the public to commemorate the 1,000th anniversary of the founding of Hanoi speaks volumes about its importance to Vietnam's national identity.

The most interesting feature of Thang Long Citadel is the fact that ruins from different eras have been discovered layered on top of each other. This shows the continuity of history, with successive dynasties building new administrative centers on the foundations of the previous dynasty.

In particular, the fact that full-scale excavations began in 2003 means that the site represents an ongoing history, rather than a "complete history." The Hoang Dieu 18 Archaeological Site, where investigations and excavations are still ongoing, is at the forefront of this research, exuding the romantic archaeological romance of unearthing the past buried underground (however, access may be restricted due to re-examinations, so it's essential to check in advance).


Though its simple exterior belies its simplicity, Thang Long Citadel is a place densely packed with Hanoi's long history and Vietnam's roots. The reasonable admission fee of 30,000 VND for adults is also very reasonable considering its historical value.
Visiting this ruins will be more than just a look at the city walls; it will be a valuable experience that allows you to feel firsthand the indomitable spirit and dynastic history of Vietnam, as embodied in the name "Rising Dragon.

Nghinh Luong Dinh is a water pavilion for the king to rest and enjoy the cool air during the hot summer. This building was built in the 5th year of Tu Duc (1852) on the North bank of the Huong River, opposite Phu Van Lau. 
In the 15th year of Thanh Thai (1903), Nghinh Luong Dinh was restored, and in the 3rd year of Khai Dinh (1918), it was renovated once again to serve the king's frequent vacations. 
Nghinh Luong Dinh has a square-style architecture with 1 main room and 4 wings. In the front and back, there are crab-shell houses extending. The wooden frame on the upper part, especially the crab-shell rafters, and the three-way system are elaborately carved. The main roof is covered with yellow glazed tiles, while the two shell houses are covered with yellow glazed tiles. The ground is 90cm high, with brick and stone curbs, and 13 steps leading down to a corridor built close to the water. The landscape around the Communal House is airy and poetic.
Beautiful located on the main road next to the river. It was too sunny at noon when I went, but the building is very ancient and beautiful.

Nghenh Luong Dinh is a pavilion (pavilion/pavilion) located on the north bank of the Perfume River, located on the axis connecting Ky Dai to Phu Van Lau in the Hue Citadel complex.
The building was built under the reign of King Tu Duc, usually dated 1852, with the purpose of providing a place for the king and his courtiers to rest, enjoy the cool air and receive the river breeze before boarding the royal boat.
In terms of architecture, Nghenh Luong Dinh has a pavilion layout (pavilion) in the style of the Nguyen Dynasty palace, placed partly on a stone pedestal close to the water's edge, tiled roof in the traditional palace style, with carvings, columns and railings decorated in ancient Hue motifs. Some professional descriptions emphasize the symmetry and the surrounding wings creating an open space facing the river.
The relic is considered a landscape highlight of the ancient capital, closely associated with royal court rituals and the life of the Nguyen Dynasty; it is currently part of the Hue Citadel relic tour and appears in many travel guides to Hue.
Beautiful with bold Royal architecture
The design is so beautiful. On sunny days, go around to the side of the building where there are many trees providing cool shade, and the wind blowing from the river makes for a great view.
The monument is so beautiful

ðŸ›ï¸ 1. Location & role

Address: Located on LeDuan Street, Phu Xuan Ward (on the North bank of the Huong River), in front of Phu Van Lau - the main axis of Hue Citadel.

Function: Initially a place for the king to rest and cool off before boarding the dragon boat, later used as a stage for opera performances on major holidays.

---

ðŸ•°ï¸ 2. Development history

Initial construction: In 1852, under the reign of King Tu Duc (also known as Luong Ta).

**Renovated & renamed Nghenh Luong Dinh:**

1903 (Thanh Thai), repaired after a storm.

1918 (Khai Dinh), renovated, added a boat dock and officially renamed.

New function: Became a place for public art performances under the reign of Khai Dinh and later.

Current status: The communal house is intact, restored many times such as 1974 and 1994 to its current shape.

---

ðŸ§± 3. Architecture & characteristics

Architectural style: 1-room, 4-wing square communal house, front and back have two extended "crab shell" houses, the wooden frame is elaborately carved.

Tiled roof: Covered with yellow glazed tiles on the main roof, yellow glazed tiles on the 2 crab shell parts.

High platform & steps down to the river: The platform is ~0.8m high, with railings and 13 steps down to the corridor close to the water surface.

Exquisite decoration: Carved dragons and phoenixes, eight treasures, dragon scales "two dragons facing the sun", umbrellas, stone clouds... on the roof and rafters).

Feng Shui: View of the Huong River, connecting with Ky Dai - Phu Van Lau - expanding the view, airy space.

---

ðŸŒ³ 4. Value & experience

Culture & history: Symbol of the royal spirit - the leisure and authority of the Nguyen Dynasty kings.

Artistic architecture: A unique relic that still exists, demonstrating the ancient water pavilion construction techniques of the Nguyen Dynasty.

Scenery: An ideal place to watch the Perfume River, especially at dawn, dusk or on a moonlit night.

International: Part of the World Cultural Heritage Complex - Hue Ancient Capital.

---

ðŸ“ 5. Notes when visiting

Respect the relics: do not draw graffiti, carve names, smoke, or litter.

Ideal time: dry season (Marchâ€“August), spring (Januaryâ€“February) and autumn (Septemberâ€“November). Avoid the rainy season.

Combine visiting Phu Van Lau, Ky Dai, Hoang Thanh and walking along the river to fully enjoy the ancient capital.

Nghinh Luong Dinh, located on the axis from Ky Dai to Phu Van Lau, was a peaceful stop for the king before going down to the river, boarding a dragon boat or simply relaxing in the shade. Nghinh Luong Dinh has a square-style architecture with a four-wing room, simple but elegant. The front and back have small arches extending out, creating an open, airy space. Nghinh Luong Dinh is a prominent historical and cultural relic in Hue, built during the Nguyen Dynasty and having an important significance in the royal court ceremonies of this dynasty. This is an architectural work bearing the cultural imprint of the Hue royal court, not only having architectural value but also being a place associated with traditional festival activities of the Nguyen Dynasty. Nghinh Luong Dinh is located on the bank of the Huong River, in the Hue Imperial Citadel area. This work was built in 1823 under the reign of King Minh Mang, with the main purpose of welcoming delegations of envoys, distinguished guests or important events in the royal court. This is also the place to hold solemn ceremonies and events, creating a majestic and peaceful space, in accordance with the feng shui rituals of the royal court at that time.

Nghenh Luong pavilion or Nghenh Luong pavilion is a structure located on the vertical axis from Ky Dai to Phu Van Lau, built under the Nguyen Dynasty to be used as a resting place for the king before going down to the river to board a dragon boat or as a place to cool off. This is a relic in the complex of Hue ancient capital relics. 

Nghenh Luong pavilion was built under the reign of King Tu Duc 5 (1852), in the 15th year of Thanh Thai (1903) it was carefully restored and in the 3rd year of Khai Dinh (1918) it was embellished once again to serve the king who often came to cool off, from the time of Khai Dinh onwards it was called Nghenh Luong pavilion - the word Nghenh Luong pavilion means a water pavilion for cooling off[1]. Previously, the court blocked the road from The Nhon gate (ie Ngan gate) to Nghenh Luong pavilion, not allowing anyone to pass or see the king. 

Nghenh Luong pavilion has a square-style structure with 1 room and 4 wings, with crab-shell houses extending in the front and back. The wooden frame on the upper part, especially the crab-shell rafters and the three-way system are elaborately carved. The main roof is covered with yellow glazed tiles, the two crab-shell houses are covered with yellow glazed tiles. The Nghenh Luong pavilion's foundation is 90 cm high, with brick and stone pavements, and on the river bank there are 13 steps leading down to a corridor built close to the surface of the Huong River. The landscape around the pavilion is airy and very lyrical.

Nghenh Luong pavilion
Considering the spatial structure on the axis in front of the Citadel, Nghenh Luong pavilion is the connecting point between Ky Dai - Phu Van Lau - Huong Giang - Ngu Binh. And this is also a beautiful location to admire and feel the romantic beauty of the Huong River at dawn, at dusk or on a moonlit night.

Originally, Nghenh Luong Ta was a part of the Huong Giang Palace built in the 5th year of Tu Duc on the north bank of the Huong River, in front of Phu Van Lau. In addition to this palace, in the Hue area, the Nguyen kings also had many other palaces such as Than Phu Palace, Thuan Truc Palace, Thuan An Palace, Thuy Van Palace... All of these palaces had pavilions to serve the king, however, to this day, only Nghenh Luong Ta of Huong Giang Palace still exists.

Hue is one of the most tranquil yet majestic cities in Vietnam. As the capital of the Nguyen Dynasty, the palace complex is surprisingly large and well-preserved, reflecting the passage of time. It's a great place to stroll and imagine the atmosphere of the time.

While the temperatures are high and the sun is strong, once you pass through the main gate and enter the palace grounds, you'll find tranquil gardens, ponds, and pavilions, perfect for a brief respite. Each building features intricate carvings and unique colors, and the blend of traditional Vietnamese and Chinese architecture is a delight to behold.

It's a wonderful photo opportunity, and the historical context makes it even more engaging. Be sure to bring a hat and water on hot days.

If you're planning a trip to Hue, this is a must-visit. It truly embodies the phrase "where Vietnam's past and present meet," as it reflects the passage of time.

Hue Imperial Palace was the capital of Vietnam's last dynasty, the Nguyen Dynasty (1802-1945), and is Vietnam's first World Heritage Site (Hue Historic Monuments).
ðŸ° Overview of Hue Imperial Palace
Historical Background:
Construction began in 1804 under Emperor Gia Long, the first emperor of the Nguyen Dynasty.
Until the end of the monarchy in 1945, 13 emperors reigned over the palace and it served as the political and cultural center of Vietnam.
While influenced by the Forbidden City in Beijing, China, it reflects Vietnam's unique imperial culture.
Size and Structure:
Spread over a vast area (approximately 50 hectares), the palace is surrounded by city walls and a moat.
The interior of the Royal Palace consisted of areas such as the Imperial City (HoÃ ng ThÃ nh), where the emperor worked and performed ceremonies, and the Forbidden City (Tá»­ Cáº¥m ThÃ nh), where the emperor and his family lived.

Current Status:

Although much of the palace was destroyed during the Vietnam War (particularly the Tet Offensive of 1968), extensive restoration work is currently underway, and it is gradually being restored to its former glory.

âœ¨Major Attractions

Winter Gate (Ngá» MÃ´n)

This is the Royal Palace's symbolic main gate. It is an imposing structure measuring approximately 17 meters high and 58 meters wide, and the central gate was reserved for the emperor. "Winter" refers to the south.

Tai Wa Hall (Äiá»‡n ThÃ¡i HÃ²a)

This is the main hall where important ceremonies, such as the emperor's coronation, were held. It features a lavish interior and houses the emperor's throne.

Hiá»ƒn LÃ¢m CÃ¡c (Hien Lam CÃ¡c) and Tháº¿ Tá»• Miáº¿u (Tháº¿ Miáº¿u)

Hiá»ƒn LÃ¢m CÃ¡c is a monumental building approximately 17 meters tall, standing at the entrance to the Tháº¿ Tá»• Miáº¿u Temple, which enshrines the emperors of the Nguyen dynasty. The temple houses the memorial tablets of the Nguyen dynasty's successive emperors.

Duyá»‡t Thá»‹ ÄÆ°á»ng (Duyet Thi Duong)

One of Vietnam's oldest theaters, this was once used by emperors and members of the royal family to watch court music performances. Today, you can enjoy court music performances, which are registered as a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.
Dien Kien Trung (Äiá»‡n Kiáº¿n Trung)
This building served as the residence and workplace of the last emperor, Bao Dai, and was built in a colonial style incorporating French influences. It was once destroyed, but has recently been rebuilt and is now open to the public.

Bao Quoc Pagoda is one of the oldest pagodas in the capital. It is located on a high hill. When you visit, the pagoda is deserted. The pagoda has a school that teaches intermediate Buddhist studies for Buddhists.

Located on Ham Long hill in Duc Ward, Hue City, there is an ancient spiritual destination, imbued with the Zen character of the ancient capital, Bao Quoc Pagoda. This pagoda belongs to the Northern sect, founded by Zen master Giac Phong in the 17th century, with a serene beauty and long history. Passing through the mossy gate, built in 1808 and rebuilt in 1873, you will immediately feel the peaceful space with a cool green garden, shaded by ancient trees. The pagoda grounds are quite large and are also designed in the traditional "Khau" style, including the main hall, the monks' dormitory, the guest house and the back house, creating a harmonious and airy layout. The main hall is built in the style of "chong luong trung thiem", the pillars and walls are beautifully inlaid with ceramic pieces, with sophisticated dragon motifs, exuding the solemnity of ancient Vietnamese architecture. In the temple grounds, there are many octagonal tower tombs, which are the resting place of high monks. The lotus symbol is always placed on top of the tower, symbolizing the spirit of Buddhism. In addition, there is also a well called Ham Long well, with a clear, sweet stream of water associated with the legend of Lord Nguyen suppressing the dragon vein, which is the mystery that attracts everyone's curiosity. The temple is not only a place of worship but also a training center for monks and nuns. Buddhist schools have been held here since the 1930s. Under the abbotship of the monks over many years, Bao Quoc Pagoda still retains its sacredness, a destination to find peace, explore Hue culture and architecture. In addition, there are two longan trees full of fruit, which still linger when leaving. We invite you to visit the temple to feel the quiet space and immerse yourself in beautiful photos, especially for those who are passionate about feng shui.

Not only a historical and artistic relic, the pagoda is also a leading Buddhist training center in the Central region at one time, associated with many famous monks.

Bao Quoc Pagoda

Bao Quoc Pagoda is a Buddhist temple in the historic city of Hue in central Vietnam. It was one of the three national temples of the city during the Nguyen Dynasty.

The temple is located on Bao Quoc Street, Phuong Duc Ward in Hue. It is located south of the Perfume River and about one kilometer west of the city center. The temple is located on a small hill called Ham Long and a stream flows from the top of the hill down to the temple grounds.

Bao Quoc Pagoda was built in 1670 by the Chinese Buddhist monk Thich Giac Phong, and was originally named Ham Long Son Thien Tho Tu during the reign of Nguyen Phuc Tan, one of the Nguyen who ruled central Vietnam during any period. In 1747, Nguyen Phuc Khoat gave the temple a section with the name Sac Tu Bao Quoc Tu.

During the Nguyen Dynasty, founded by Emperor Gia Long in 1802, the temple was frequently renovated and expanded. In 1808, Empress Hieu Khuong, wife of Gia Long, sponsored various construction projects, including the construction of a triple gate and the casting of a large bell and gong. Thien Tho Pagoda was renamed Thien Tho Pagoda. The abbot who oversaw these changes was Zen master Thich Pho Tinh. In 1824, Emperor Minh Mang, son of Gia Long, visited the temple and changed the name to its current title. He held a 40th birthday celebration at the temple in 1830.

Over the years, the temple began to decline, and in 1858 a series of renovation efforts began under Emperor Tu Duc, Minh Mang's grandson, funded directly by the royal family. These continued until the end of the century.

In the 1930s, Bao Quoc was the scene of a revival in Vietnamese Buddhist education. In 1935, a Buddhist school was opened, and in 1940, a monastery for training monks was established, which is still in operation today. In 1957, the latest phase of construction and renovation took place with the support of the Provincial Buddhist Association, and under the supervision of the temple's abbot and director of Buddhist studies in the region, Thich Tri Thu. 

The temple is built on a 2ha plot. Entering the temple through three gates, there is a spacious courtyard with a lot of plant life, surrounded by balcony buildings. On the left are the tombs dedicated to Buddhist patriarchs, the oldest of which is Thich Giac Phong, built in 1714 and standing 3.30m high. The main temple building has four pillars with dragon figures built on them. 

The largest statue in the temple is the statue of the three Buddhas with two sets of Mahayana sutras. In front of the statue is a small altar, in which some relics of Gautama Buddha are displayed. Another altar has a statue of Gautama Buddha, flanked by Ananda and Mahakassapa, who were his personal attendants and the first patriarchs of Buddhism after his death. Another altar has a copy of the Lotus Sutra, flanked by a ceremonial bell and a wooden gong.

Thien Mu Pagoda (ChÃ¹a ThiÃªn Má»¥, Tian MÃ² Pagoda) is one of the oldest and most beautiful temples in Hue, the ancient capital of central Vietnam.

Key Features and Attractions:

History and Origin:

It was built in 1601 by Nguyen Hoang, the first ruler of the Cantonment Dynasty (ancestor of the later Nguyen Dynasty).

It is the only monumental structure in Hue that predates the Nguyen Dynasty.

The name comes from a legend that when Nguyen Hoang visited the site, he heard an old woman (a celestial maiden) appear on a hill and prophesy that "the true master will come and build a temple to strengthen the country." "Tian Mu" means "celestial maiden" or "celestial maiden."
Phuoc Duyen Tower (PhÆ°á»›c DuyÃªn Tower) / Tá»« NhÃ¢n Tower (Tá»« NhÃ¢n Tower):
This 21-meter-tall, seven-story octagonal pagoda is the symbol of Thien Mu Pagoda.

It was built in 1844 by Emperor Thieu Tri, the third emperor of the Nguyen dynasty.

A Buddha statue is enshrined on each floor, making it a beloved symbol of Hue.

Hexagonal Bell Tower and Hexagonal Stele Pavilion:

Located to the left and right rear of the tower.

The Hexagonal Bell Tower houses the largest bell in Hue (weighing approximately 2 tons), cast in 1710.

The Hexagonal Stele Pavilion houses a stone stele made in 1715, resting on the back of a giant marble turtle, a symbol of longevity.

Dai HÃ¹ng Hall (Äáº¡i HÃ¹ng Hall):

This is the main hall of the temple, housing a triad of Buddhas.
Location and View:

Perched on a hill overlooking the romantic Perfume River, the temple's beautiful scenery is one of its attractions.

Historical Role:

During the Vietnam War, this temple served as a base for protests against the Ngo Dinh Diem regime's oppression of Buddhism. In particular, the car used by monk Thich Quang Duc, who set himself on fire in Saigon in 1963, during his protests is on display within the temple grounds.

This temple is an essential stop on any visit to Hue, offering a chance to experience its historical significance, beautiful architecture, and tranquil atmosphere. Admission is free.

The ThiÃªn Má»¥ Pagoda (meaning "Pagoda of the Celestial Lady"), also known as Linh Má»¥ in some historical periods, is perhaps the most iconic and spiritual symbol of the city of Hue, Vietnam.
Here is the most relevant information about this historic pagoda:
1. History and Legend
* Foundation: It was founded in 1601 by Nguyá»…n HoÃ ng, the first Nguyá»…n lord of the ÄÃ ng Trong region (South Vietnam), making it the oldest pagoda in the former imperial capital.
* The Legend: Its name is based on a folk legend. It is said that Nguyá»…n HoÃ ng rode a horse along the Perfume River in search of a place to establish his dynasty. Upon arriving at Ha KhÃª Hill, the locals told him the story of an old woman dressed in red (the Celestial Lady) who appeared and prophesied that a great lord would build a temple there, where the spirit of the nation would be concentrated. Upon hearing this, Nguyá»…n HoÃ ng ordered the construction of the pagoda and named it ThiÃªn Má»¥ (Heavenly Lady).
2. Architecture and Features
* Location: Located on Ha KhÃª Hill, on the left bank of the Perfume River, about 5 km from downtown Hue. Its location by the river is very poetic and contributes to its serene atmosphere.
* PhÆ°á»›c DuyÃªn Tower (Fountain of Happiness): This is the pagoda's most iconic structure.
* It was built in 1844 by Emperor Thiá»‡u Trá»‹.
* It has seven levels (floors), each dedicated to a different Buddha.
* It is 21 meters tall and has an octagonal floor plan.
* Building Complex: The pagoda is a complex that includes:
* The Tam Quan entrance gate (triple gate).
* The Dai Hung Hall, the main hall that houses Buddha statues (including Maitreya Buddha).
* A stele (engraved stone slab) atop a large marble turtle, a symbol of longevity.
3. Historical and Cultural Significance
* Royal Patronage: Over the centuries, the pagoda was sponsored and expanded by various emperors of the Nguyen Dynasty, solidifying its status as an important Buddhist center and architectural treasure.
* Political Significance: In modern history, the pagoda gained international prominence by housing the car (a turquoise Austin) used by monk Thich Quang Duc to travel to Saigon, where he set himself on fire in 1963 in protest against the South Vietnamese regime. This event brought worldwide attention to the plight of Buddhists.
Today, ThiÃªn Má»¥ Pagoda remains an active Buddhist monastery, attracting thousands of pilgrims and tourists for its nostalgic beauty, peaceful space, and profound cultural significance.
