Along with the Perfume River, Ngu Binh Mountain is a wonderful symbol of Hue. Therefore, Ngu Binh is gradually becoming an ideal destination for tourists who love nature and want to enjoy the fresh air. Ngu Binh Mountain is located about 3km from the south bank of the Perfume River, in the former location of Tu Tay Hamlet, An Cuu Village; then Thuy An Commune, Hue City; now An Cuu Ward of the city. Although this mountain is only 104m high, because it rises suddenly in the middle of flat land, in a special position, since the 17th century, it has been in the sights and caught the eye of Hue urban planners and builders. Indeed, in its history and geography books, the National History Institute of the Nguyen Dynasty clearly recorded that in 1687, when Lord Nguyen Phuc Thai moved the capital from Kim Long to Phu Xuan Village, the architects at that time used this special mountain as a screen, a feng shui element in ancient architecture. At that time, it was called Hon Mo or Bang Son. Bang is a very large bird, like an eagle for example. The reason for the name Bang Son is because the mountain looks like an eagle spreading its wings to fly. This is a natural mountain, but from the north, it looks balanced, the two wings on the east and west sides are symmetrical to each other evenly as if they were built and shaped by human hands. Moreover, the two slopes on both sides of the mountain slightly protrude forward, looking like two arms spreading forward to welcome someone. The beauty of Ngu mountain is not in the feng shui aspect of protecting Hue citadel, the beauty of Ngu mountain is that it is close to the people of Hue, it becomes a platform, a towering building and going up there on artificial steps, people can stretch their eyes to admire the gentle beauty of Hue citadel, listen to the echoes from far below, and feel like they are in some other world, otherworldly.

Tu Dam Pagoda has a very tall stupa. Let's go at noon because the main hall is closed.

The most ancient and sacred pagoda in the ancient capital of Hue is Tu Dam Pagoda. Founded by Zen Master Minh Hoang Tu Dung in the late 17th century with the original name An Ton, the pagoda was renamed Tu Dam by King Thieu Tri in 1841, meaning "good clouds", symbolizing purity and compassion. With more than 300 years of history, this place is not only a Buddhist center but also a valuable cultural heritage of Vietnam. The architecture of Tu Dam Pagoda delicately blends classical and modern features. The tiled gate with sturdy stone steps opens the way to the airy campus, where there is an ancient Bodhi tree, grafted from the Bodhi tree in India in 1936, providing peaceful shade. Here is the 27m high An Ton Stupa with 7 floors, it is said that inside each floor is a bronze Buddha statue, creating a solemn and unique beauty. The main hall was rebuilt in 2006 in the style of the Hue royal palace, the surrounding space is filled with the scent of incense, very pleasant, inside is a statue of Buddha Shakyamuni and two statues of Bodhisattva Manjushri and Samantabhadra. Behind the main hall is the Ancestor's house, where the 28th Zen master Bodhidharma, the Zen master Minh Hoang Tu Dung and his successors are worshiped, showing respect for Buddhist traditions. Next to it is a souvenir room like a small museum, displaying historical relics, helping people understand more about the development of the pagoda. This is one of the pagodas to visit when coming to Hue because of the long history of Buddhist development, and the value of the historical stories it brings.

Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda in Huáº¿ is one of the most peaceful and spiritually significant places Iâ€™ve ever visited. Nestled in the heart of the ancient imperial city, this pagoda is not only a place of worship but also a cultural and historical landmark that reflects the deep roots of Vietnamese Buddhism.

What makes Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda especially meaningful to me is the legacy of one of its most revered monks: Venerable ThÃ­ch TrÃ­ Quang. I have long admired him for his intellect, his dedication to Buddhism, and especially his work translating and interpreting many important Buddhist texts into Vietnamese. His influence on Vietnamese Buddhism, both in spiritual and cultural terms, is profound. Though he has passed away, his spirit and teachings are very much alive in this sacred space. It was incredibly moving to walk through the grounds and know that this was a place he once walked, taught, and meditated.

The pagoda itself is beautiful â€” quiet, clean, and filled with the scent of incense. The architecture is traditional yet timeless, with a large main hall, well-tended gardens, and statues that inspire a deep sense of calm and reverence. The monks and caretakers are kind and respectful, and there is a genuine atmosphere of compassion and wisdom here.

If you are in Huáº¿ and seeking a meaningful spiritual experience â€” or simply want a quiet space to reflect â€” I highly recommend visiting Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda. For me, it was more than a visit; it was a moment of connection with history, faith, and the legacy of a great teacher.

Tu Dam Pagoda is a famous ancient pagoda in Hue, currently located at 1 Su Lieu Quan Street, Truong An Ward, Thuan Hoa District, Hue City, Vietnam.

History
The pagoda was founded by Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung[1] around the end of the 17th century, and was later named An Ton Pagoda (å°å®—å¯º, or Tong), meaning "taking the transmission of the mind as the main principle"[2].

In 1702, monk Lieu Quan (later also a high monk) came to the pagoda, asking to study with Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung[3]

In 1703, Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung restored the pagoda. Also in this year, Lord Nguyen Phuc Chu granted the pagoda the Sac Tu An Ton Tu plaque. After the Master passed away, according to his will, his student Zen Master Thiet Vinh - Buu Hanh became the abbot of the pagoda.

In 1802, the Tay Son dynasty was overthrown. At that time, due to time and war, An Ton Pagoda was severely damaged like many other pagodas in the region [4]. However, it was not until the 12th year of Gia Long (1813) that Zen Master Dao Trung - Trong Nghia was able to organize the restoration of the pagoda [5]. 

In 1841, King Thieu Tri changed the name of An Ton Pagoda to Tu Dam-æ…ˆæ›‡å¯º (to avoid the taboo of the king's name Mien Tong) [5], meaning "the auspicious cloud of Buddhism" [6]. 

In the 9th year of Thanh Thai (1897), the king ordered the road to Nam Giao altar to be opened. Because this road passed through the grounds of Tu Dam Pagoda, the king ordered the abbot, Zen Master Thanh Hiep - Tuong Van, to move the 5 stupas containing the remains of the ancestors to the grounds of Bao Quoc Pagoda nearby. Perhaps on this occasion, the abbot had the pagoda restored again [7]. 

From the 1920s onwards, the Vietnamese Buddhist revival movement developed in all three regions. During that time, Tu Dam Pagoda was the center of the Central Buddhist Revival Movement[8].

In 1932, the An Nam Buddhist Association (later renamed the Central Vietnamese Buddhist Association) was established in Hue... In 1936, the Lam Te sect agreed to hand over Tu Dam Pagoda to the association as a place of worship and as the association's headquarters.

On December 18, 1938, the Thua Thien Provincial Buddhist Association had Tu Dam Pagoda extensively renovated, and at the same time cast a statue of Buddha Shakyamuni and other Dharma instruments to enshrine in the main hall, which was completed in 1940. Other items such as lecture halls, monks' quarters and some offices of the Provincial Association were also built during that time[9].

In 1943, the Gia Dinh Phat Hoa Pho was established; In 1951, it was renamed the Buddhist Family, and its headquarters was located at Tu Dam Pagoda[10].

In 1951, the Congress to establish the Vietnam Buddhist Sangha took place at the pagoda.

In 1951, the Conference to establish the Vietnam Buddhist Sangha (including 51 delegates from 6 groups of monks and lay people in the three regions) was also held here. At that time, the Association also approved the Most Venerable To Lien to sign on behalf of the Association to join the World Buddhist Association.

In the 1960s, Tu Dam Pagoda was the center of activities to fight against the religious policy under President Ngo Dinh Diem.

Currently, the pagoda has the office of the Hue City Buddhist Executive Committee.

As one of the three remaining national temples from the Nguyen Dynasty, it bears the historical and spiritual cultural imprints of the ancient capital. Dieu De Pagoda is located in a prime location, surrounded by four roads, with the most prominent being the front facing Ho Thanh River, creating a peaceful and airy scene. The temple space is spacious, surrounded by lush green trees, bringing a cool feeling. The continuous chanting of sutras, mixed with incense smoke, makes people's hearts calm down, finding a rare peace. Built in 1844 under the reign of King Thieu Tri, the pagoda was originally the king's palace when he was still a prince. According to the Nguyen Dynasty's records, King Thieu Tri built the pagoda on the old palace foundation to pray for the people, and conferred the title of National Pagoda, naming it "Dieu De" meaning the wonder of culture and Buddhism. Through the ups and downs of history, especially after the fall of the capital in 1885, the pagoda was occupied and many structures were damaged. However, thanks to several restorations, most notably the major restoration in 1953 supported by Lady Tu Cung (mother of King Bao Dai), the pagoda still retains its ancient features and profound spiritual values. The pagoda played an important role in the Buddhist movement of the 1930s and the struggle for religious equality in 1963. Every year, the pagoda often organizes a Buddha procession on the occasion of Buddha's birthday, attracting thousands of monks, nuns and Buddhists. The architecture of Dieu De pagoda bears the strong style of the Nguyen Dynasty's royal court, although it has changed over time. Initially, the pagoda had a surrounding wall, four symmetrical doors symbolizing the Four Holy Emperors, along with structures such as Dai Giac palace, Dao Nguyen pavilion, communal house, and bi dinh. Today, the main hall has been rebuilt in the style of a wooden house, with 18 precious wooden statues of Arhats on both sides. Inside, the ceiling painting "Long Van Khe Hoi" is preserved, the largest masterpiece in Vietnam, depicting five dragons hidden in the clouds, made by the royal artist Phan Van Tanh. The four pillars in the hall are carved with elaborate dragons and clouds, showing the fusion between royal and folk art. Outside, there are two Dai Hong Chung bells cast in 1846, the pride of the pagoda. One is placed in Chung Dinh near Tam Quan gate, the other in the bell tower to the right of Dai Giac hall, used in major ceremonies. The two-story Tam Quan gate, Ho Phap tower, and the hundred-year-old Bodhi tree are also highlights not to be missed when visiting the pagoda.

Dieu De Pagoda in Hue is an ancient and solemn pagoda, located on the banks of the Perfume River, in Phu Cat Ward. Built under the reign of King Thieu Tri and conferred the title of "Quoc Tu", the pagoda bears the mark of royal Buddhism.

Dieu De Pagoda is one of three national pagodas still existing in Hue city, maintaining precious cultural and spiritual values. Located on the banks of Ho Thanh River, near Gia Hoi Bridge, the pagoda is located at 100B Bach Dang Street, Phu Cat Ward. The space around the pagoda is spacious and peaceful, creating a sense of relaxation for those who come to visit and pray. With elegant architecture and poetic landscape, Dieu De Pagoda is considered one of the most sacred places in Hue. Dieu De Pagoda was originally the place where King Thieu Tri's palace was located and was also the king's birthplace in 1907. In 1844, the king mobilized 600 soldiers to build a pagoda on the old palace's foundation on a large scale, using the Dao Dong Ba River as the main hall and establishing the national pagoda. When the capital fell in 1885, King Ham Nghi moved the Buddha statues from Giac Hoang Pagoda to worship at Dieu De Pagoda. Later, the Southern Dynasty used the temple buildings as the headquarters of the Thua Thien government. Many rows of buildings in the temple were destroyed in 1887. In 1889, King Thanh Thai gave the monk Thanh Minh - Tam Truyen 3,000 quan of money to restore the temple, but it could not be completely restored as before. 

The architecture of Dieu De Pagoda clearly reflects the traditional Vietnamese style with curved tiled roofs and intricately carved wooden pillars. The temple was built in the style of an ancient house, creating a feeling of closeness and warmth for visitors. Inside the temple, the meditation rooms and worship spaces are meticulously designed, bringing serenity and peace. The decorative motifs on the walls and ceilings show the ingenuity and creativity of the artisans of that period. 
The temple grounds are spacious, including many different areas such as meditation gardens, small lakes and winding paths. Each small structure in the campus has its own meaning, contributing to the overall harmony and elegance. The windows and main doors are made of high-quality wood, allowing natural light to enter, creating a warm and pleasant space. 

The National Temple of Dieu De Pagoda today still retains its ancient and sacred beauty as the first day of construction. The National Temple was built of bricks and stones, with delicate carvings on the pillars and roof. This place is often used to organize important festivals and religious ceremonies, attracting a large number of believers and tourists. The space inside the National Temple is simply but fully decorated, creating a solemn and peaceful feeling. 

When coming to Dieu De Pagoda, you definitely cannot miss visiting the outstanding structures inside the temple grounds. First is the large Buddha statue located in the center of the temple, with impressive size and sophisticated sculptural details. The Buddha statue is placed on a high stone pedestal, creating solemnity and majesty, attracting the eyes of all visitors. The presence of the large Buddha statue brings a sense of serenity and peace to all visitors.

Diá»‡u Äáº¿ Pagoda is one of the national pagodas with a long history and unique architecture in Hue. Based on the information I found, my impression of this pagoda is as follows:

Regarding history and culture: Diá»‡u Äáº¿ Pagoda holds an important position in the history of Buddhism in Hue, being one of the three pagodas that were declared "national pagodas" by Emperor Thiá»‡u Trá»‹ and directly patronized by the Nguyá»…n Dynasty. This demonstrates the pagoda's rich history and profound cultural value. Coming here, you can feel the solemnity and sacredness of an ancient pagoda that has witnessed many ups and downs of the history of the Citadel.

Regarding architecture: Diá»‡u Äáº¿ Pagoda impresses with its unique architecture, different from many other pagodas in Hue. It is famous for the "Nine Dragons Hidden in Clouds" painting, the largest of its kind in Vietnam. The pagoda's campus is spacious, shaded by green trees, creating a cool and peaceful feeling. Structures such as the Great Awakening Hall (Ä‘iá»‡n Äáº¡i GiÃ¡c), Äáº¡o NguyÃªn Pavilion (Äáº¡o NguyÃªn cÃ¡c), Wisdom Room (phÃ²ng TrÃ­ Tuá»‡), and Auspicious House (nhÃ  CÃ¡t TÆ°á»ng) are harmoniously arranged, bearing the imprint of ancient imperial architecture. In particular, the pagoda also has four low towers at the main gate and two on either side of the main hall, creating a distinctive beauty.

Regarding experience: When you set foot in Diá»‡u Äáº¿ Pagoda, you will feel the serene and peaceful atmosphere. This is not only a place of spiritual activities for monks and nuns but also a destination attracting tourists who want to learn about the Buddhist culture, history, and architecture of Hue. Strolling through the pagoda grounds, admiring the ancient buildings, and listening to the sound of the pagoda bell, you can find peace in your soul.

In summary, Diá»‡u Äáº¿ Pagoda is a worthwhile destination to experience in Hue, where you can discover distinctive historical and cultural values and find tranquility in the peaceful space of an ancient temple.

Dieu De Pagoda is not as "magnificent" as Bai Dinh or Tam Chuc Pagoda or modern pagodas across the country later, but there is "Buddha" in the pagoda. Dieu De is considered one of the three national pagodas of the ancient capital of Hue. They are Thien Mu Pagoda, Dieu De Pagoda and Thanh Duyen Pagoda.
Dieu De Pagoda was built by King Thieu Tri in the 4th year in 1844. The pagoda is located on the bank of Ho Thanh River, which Hue people call Gia Hoi River, or Dong Ba River. In the main hall, there is a worship of Tam The Buddha, and on both sides are statues of Maitreya, originally from the reign of King Thieu Tri. The Buddha and Arhat statues here all have simple, symbolic lines, few colors or elaborate lines, although Hue is the cradle of fine arts, music and cuisine. Dieu De is an ancient and sacred pagoda, so all year round there are always people from the North and the South making pilgrimages to burn incense.

I donâ€™t have a bike license but he made me feel at ease and was always there in front checking on us throughout. The seafood restaurant we went to was soooo good as well! Such a good amount of stops along the way like the waterfalls, ducks, sugarcane juice and rice fields!

The ride was amazing. The drivers are experienced, funny and really kind. It was my first time doing something like this and I couldn't hope for something better. We went to the waterfall to have lunch and it was the perfect break.
We felt really safe (we are 2 girls 22 and 25 years old) and welcomed. Definitely suggest it!!!

Amazing experience with our riders! They picked us up in front of our homestay, they secured our luggage and then we hopped on the motorbikes. Since we are not experienced drivers we let them drive for us. The drivers were super safe and kind, they stopped multiple times to let us take wonderful pictures. The bike was large and comfortable. We also stopped by a waterfall and they offered us a delicious lunch. I could not ask for more!

Ps: I went with a friend of mine and we both felt super safe as female travelers.

10/10 company to use for the Hai Van Pass!! We got recommended this company from a previous hostel - so glad we did! The company were happy to accommodate all my friends (we were a group of 10) with some using easy riders and others riding solo. The easy riders were very good and we felt safe, and the bikes for those going solo were in really good condition. The team took us to a waterfall and some viewpoints. They also took us to a really nice seafood restaurant by the beach for lunch and also treated us all to a beer at the end. The day was really well organised and was one of the highlights of Vietnam!!

Duyen is the best!! I did a three day, two night trip from Phong Nha to Hoi An, along the Ho Chi Minh Trail and through the Hai Van Pass. Duyen is an amazing driver and as a solo female traveller, I felt safe the entire time. He always took the more scenic route which added to the experience and he had excellent local recommendations for food. My luggage was also delivered to my accomodation on time with no issue. Highly recommend â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸

We went from hue to hoi an with the motorbikes - our suitcases were pocked up from our hotel in hue and brought directly to our hotel in hoi an, which was amazing! we did a nice trip, started a bit earlier (8am) because we needed to be in hoi an at 14:30. this was good, as we were on the stops before many others - for example swam in the waterfall with just 2 other people and saq the wonderful pass. all in all a great experience and an amazing lunch which was vegetarian for us! :)  drivers are experienced and drive safely, motorbikes are bigger than the normal scooters, so you have something to lean on, which is comfy.

We had the best time with Duyen, he went above and beyond making us feel safe and have a great day being our guide through the Hai Van pass, the bikes provided were great, he showed us the best spots, including the waterfall, beach and best viewpoint stops, we canâ€™t thank him enough, he made the whole experience so enjoyable, I would 100% recommend amazing easy riders as itâ€™s a smaller business, with the nicest owner!!
The best day Iâ€™ve had in a long time!! I tell you book this now, you will not regret it. Stunning views, vibes and magic tricks. What an experience
I recommend, did the Hai Van Pass from HuÃ© to Hoi An and we had a wonderful day. Duyen is a super nice guy and make everything for you to have it perfect.

This was such amazing trip. Had such a good time for Hai van Pass trip Top Gear  in Vietnam. He was very professional and also safe,I highly recommend if you are not feeling so comfortable riding in Vietnam because of the traffic.
The food and tickets also included in the price

Advice:you should book online and not on the street as it may not be an easy rider contacting you. Because when I walked in HuÃ© city some people tried to make me hire them as an easy rider and they were not.
They also said that they was brother to John DuyÃªn and they are not.
I was so happy to do the Easy rider with him,i never forgot the trip, i will tell to my friends that, Thank you so much John Duyen

My motorbike tour with Duyen was absolutely incredible. A friend recommended him and he was wonderful. Duyen was kind, supportive and made me feel very safe at all times. He was informative and we stopped many times to have breaks, photos and to show me the sights. I had a lot of fun seeing the Hai Van Pass, the countryside and the beautiful rice fields with Duyen. I highly recommend this trip to everyone ðŸ™‚

I had an amazing time with Duyen, I was recommended to go with him by a friend who took the tour with him a couple of years ago, and Iâ€™m very glad that I did.

I am a solo female traveller, and he made me feel very comfortable and was great company along the way. He told me lots of interesting information at our stops and made sure to remind me to top up my suncream (Iâ€™m very pale!). He made sure that I got lots of photos, including with me in them. We had a lovely lunch at a seafood place, the food was really fresh and he picked out some dishes for me that he thought I would like - and they were delicious.

Before I even arrived he was really kind and helpful, sending me advice about Hue and safety tips.

I donâ€™t have much experience on a motorbike but he was a very good and safe driver so I felt totally comfortable and had a lot of fun. The ride was great, I really enjoyed the views and I would really recommend this tour to anyone.

I am a solo female traveler and couldnâ€™t have asked for better company to do that Hai Van pass with.

I felt safe all while having fun with Duyen as he showed me multiple different spots along the way as well as being a great personal photographer which means a lot when you are by yourself.

Great communication through WhatsApp and even advice before I arrived in Hue about safety in the busy areas, it was greatly appreciated and shows Duyen goes above and beyond for his clients.

Delicious food is included in the tour with Duyen giving you the option of what you would like and then taking you to a great restaurant for that food.

Very safe driving and it is an incredibly convenient way of transporting your bag to your destination in Hoi An in their private van.

It was a great day that I would recommend to any other solo traveller or group. I thoroughly enjoyed myself and hope this review convinces others to have a brilliant day in Vietnam on the Hai Van pass.

Nice little trip form hoi an to hue! Duyen drove my mother and then my sister while I was driving behind. We did some very nice stops and had a very good meel. And of course the driving was very safe:)! Thanks a lot!
Me and my friends had the most amazing day with Duyen! He really took care of all of us and made sure we were safe and having a good time! Highly recommend!
We had an amazing day going from Hue to Hoi An! Stopped at Beach, Waterfall und beautiful viewpoints. We felt so safe and our leader Duyen took such good care of us!! Would 100% recommend!
I had a great experience today with amazing easy riders! Duyen really looked after us and made sure everything went well and we were all safe!

Had a wonderful day with brothers Duyen and Hu going from Da Nang to Hue. Felt absolutely safe and comfortable with them. They are complete professionals at driving and rest assured they made no blind passes or any other dangerous moves. We were treated to a delicious lunch and plenty of stops to rest and take photos. Plus, many other easy riders after the Hai Van pass just take you straight down the highway, but Duyen and Hue took us down side roads to see the beautiful rice fields and Vietnamese countryside. Absolutely recommend these guys, you will have an amazing time!!

I had the best just the best day with Duyen and Huu riding from Da Nang to Hue! It was my first trip with an easy rider but I felt so safe and comfortable (even with my giant rucksack strapped to the back of the bike)!

Driving down the Hai Van Pass was so much fun and so beautiful! There were so many great stops along the way - I think my favourites were the marble mountain and waterfall - and Duyen and Huu acted as both driver, tour guide and photographer. We also had the most fabulous lunch.

I could not recommend them though!

Great tour with many highlights (waterfall, food on the beach, Cloud Pass, Monkey Island) and stops during the tour!
John is 100% reliable and punctual and he and his people are very safe drivers. An absolute recommendation!!

We had an amazing ride from Hue to Hoi an with Duyen, Ky and Rone. They were so friendly and Duyen had lots of knowledge of the local area- even recommended a great tailor in Hoi an.
Was easy to book and reliable, also had our luggage transferred by van with no issues. Definitely recommend. Thank you!

What a wonderful day trip (Hoi An - Hue) this was. A stunningly beautiful route. My easyrider, Duyen, stopped at several locations so I could fully enjoy it. For example, at the Marple Mountains, waterfalls, and a beautiful beach. My backpack was securely strapped to the back, but I could have chosen to have it transported by car. But that worked out perfectly. Duyen is a lovely, calm man. He also drove calmly and safely. The lunch was delicious and in a truly beautiful location. The last stretch we rode through the rice paddies with the sunset. I thoroughly enjoyed it.
In a word: RECOMMENDED!

We rented motorbikes from these guys and self drove from Hue to Hoi An. It was the best and the craziest time of our Vietnam trip so far! Would recommend to everyone! :)

Motorbikes collection went all smooth and quick and the motorbikes themselves were in great condition.

Great experience, the bike worked a dream and was perfect for navigating the Hai Van Pass from Hue to Hoi An, full tank handled all the driving and sight seeing along the way. John and his family were so welcoming and friendly. Thoroughly recommend!
Motorbike was nice, no issues
Very fun day seeing the countryside with a great lunch and swim at the waterfalls.  Ky is very outgoing and knowledgeable, with very good English

Recommend Amazing Easy Riders without reserve. Showed up early. Safe motorcycles and drivers. Very professional and courteous. Our oldest rider was in her 70s so donâ€™t let your age stop you. Highlight of our trip so far!
It was super fun and beautiful. The drivers are very friendly!
We had a really great day! The drivers were very friendly and it was a beautiful route.
A great ride with incredibly fun and sweet riders! We stopped at the nicest places, got good food and drove through the local streets for the best experience

Amazing day!! So worth the money instead of getting the bus or train. Very experienced and so friendly making sure we were safe and well fed / watered throughout the day!! Great stops too in authentic villages, waterfalls, sightseeing stops etc. thank you!!!!
Very Nice tour! Was amazing with the guides

Amazing experience driving the Hai Van Pass with our tour guide! We made a stop at all the nice places and views in between and it was very nice to have someone lead us the way and make us feel safe in traffic. Very kind and funny tour guide, would definitely recommend!
Huu and Trang were absolutely amazing, we had such a good time with them and saw some amazing things on the bikes. Would 100% recommend to anyone wanting to do this, you wonâ€™t regret it!!

Super good experience with Duyen. The day before we had a local meal with him and some friends and had a nice drink and the next day we did the Hai van pas. Super hospitable and a nice experience richer!

The tour was great. We didn't follow the main route, so we saw some beautiful scenery and animals. The pass itself offers a beautiful view and is definitely recommended!
We had a wonderful day with Johnny. He's very knowledgeable, and you can tell it's important to him that you see a lot and have a great and safe tour.

Duyen was extremely patient and helpful throughout. We had dinner with him at a place he recommended the night before, and got to taste the local cuisine. He was flexible to our needs, and fun to hang out with.
Ok

We drove from Hue to Hoi An, 2 adults and 2 kids.Both brothers are the most friendly, big hearted guys with lots of knowledge and jokes!! Where do I startâ€¦ The lovely John was our guide for the Hai Van pass and boy did he deliver! Beautiful experience! Duyen took me on a journey to discover the real Vietnam through rice paddies, lagoons and enchanting landscapes. Several stops along the way, excellent lunch, safe and careful driving. Highly recommended!
An amazing day !
It was a fantastic day! Everything was taken care of for us, and it's a wonderful way to explore the area when traveling from Hue to Hoi An. Highly recommended :))
It was a really nice day, the trip was great, and the guide was super friendly. He mapped out a lovely, scenic route.
It was a fantastic ride! We thoroughly enjoyed the beautiful scenery, delicious food, and a friendly tour guide! Swimming at the waterfall was a lot of fun!
A really nice ride with an enthusiastic guide. He brought us safely to Hoi An, and I really enjoyed driving myself!
The best Experience: best tourguide, amazing views, Good food! Nothing to complain, 10/10!

Great experience with Ky and Hoa!!
We highly recommend this day trip: waterfall, great food, and beautiful scenery! The guides were very friendly!!

Had an amazing tour! Really good drivers, lots of stops, enough drinks and nice lunch at a waterfall. And the best is they donâ€™t take the main roads, so you get to see a lot of the countryside. Can highly recommend!

We found this amazing man who has let us enjoy the most amazing trip. He was super helpful and went above and beyond what he was providing for us (including taking me to the eye doctors). This man is so lovely and chooses the best route for the Hi Van Pass with scenic views and amazing stop offs on beaches with no tourists. Would 100% recommend booking with him ðŸ«¶

Brilliant experience, we went to the most magical beach and got shown the most extraordinary views, our easy riders were very safe, but what we really loved was how friendly and kind they all were.

We had the best day ever !!! John took us on paths that not many people know about so we got to see rural parts of the Vietnamese countryside and rice fields! We had an amazing experience with Amazing Easy Riders, riding from Hoi An to Hue.

A really incredible experience with the nicest guides, thank you to Duyen and Thuy. Couldnâ€™t recommend them more!

Such a great experience for the Hai Van Pass. After the pass we were taken through amazing back roads, rice paddies and villages with plenty of stops to take photos. The lunch stop at the waterfall was great too.
The guide was very friendly. We had great food. Beautiful trip through nature. Highly recommend!

I had an incredible time doing the Hai Van Pass from Hue to Hoi An with Johnny and Ky! I booked on WhatsApp with Ky, who has great English, and had super quick responses. We started with a lovely drive through rice fields to a waterfall where we swam, jumped & slid in! The highlight of this section of the road was the super cute ducklings!!! After going in the waterfall they provided us with plastic bags for our wet stuff which was very thoughtful. We then had a very good lunch - mountain chicken, morning glory, omelette and rice! We then continued driving and stopped at the beach for a wander and Johnnyâ€™s very funny magic card trick!!! The Hai Van Pass itself was beautiful and we stopped at lots of viewpoints for amazing photos!!! We also saw monkeys and stopped at a pagoda with a huge Buddha before continuing through Da Nang to Hoi An. I am so glad I was recommended these amazing guys from friends I met during my travels as it was an amazing day! Special shoutout to my easy rider Johnny who had incredible English and was so funny and chatty!!! I will remember this day for a long time - it definitely stands out as one of my favourite days in over 6 months travelling!!!
attractions" is NO advertising-site â€¼ï¸
Really nice guy, speaks really good english and while my bike was getting repaired he brought me to his friends house to play game and then he brought me to have a nice bbq dinner!

We had a fantastic day with the amazing Easy Riders! Everything was very smooth and seemed very organized. We never rode for longer than 40 minutes and made plenty of stops for sightseeing and taking pictures. We were only a small group of four, which was very pleasant. The Easy Riders went out of their way to give us a great day. We'll especially remember the lunch! We've never eaten such good seafood. Thank you for the fantastic day; we can definitely recommend the tour without reservation :))
Really good day on the ha van pass Duyen/John was brilliant easy rider and absolutely made our trip!

We had an amazing day with the easy riders. Stopped off for multiple nice viewpoints, saw the family farm within the rice fields, played bowls with the locals and then football with some local students. Very worth it and much better than getting a bus or grab from each location. Our riders made us feel very safe and comfortable on the back of the bikes. Was one of the best days in vietnam we have had!
Amazing drivers, played games at their house, and football with local kids, highly recommend

Very fun day riding from Hue to Hoi An. Felt very safe with our riders, they took us though back roads rather than the highway out of Hue which was really interesting. It was raining but that didn't matter as they were well prepared with ponchos, trousers and shoe covers. Lunch was very tasty. Pick up and drop off at accommodation also very smooth. Would recommend!
Great tour! Our guides Ky and his brother were really accomodating and kind. Beautiful ride not just the hai can pass but also through the country side of Hue. Highly recommend this tour!

This was a great experience. Biked through some villages which was really nice. Ky was a good driver.

Very full and friendly day with this team! An incredible experience with this warm, welcoming, cheerful, funny, and accommodating team!
Breathtaking scenery in the heart of Vietnam!
Go there with your eyes closed, I recommend it 100%.

It was a wonderful day with this team! We made many stops: beaches, temples, rice paddies... very careful driving!
I recommend it 100%

A wonderful experience! A must-do during our trip to Vietnam.
The motorbike drivers were very professional and friendly.
A smooth and safe ride!
Faster than a taxi ride and much more unforgettable.

Breathtaking scenery and delicious food!

We had a fantastic experience with three friends and our easy riders, John and Ky.

I would highly recommend it to everyone. The trip is fantastic, and the drivers make it even more enjoyable.

A wonderful day of motorcycling between Hue and Hoi An. Perfectly organized. We had a great day with Duyen and Huu. We were able to visit fishing villages, swim in a waterfall and a heavenly beach, without forgetting the multiple viewpoints. The driving team was very friendly and took great care of us. I highly recommend!

Highly recommended!

An incredible motorcycle trip between Hue and Hoi An!

amazing guide, helpful and attentive
Great trip on Hai Van pass organised the night before. Small group size and very friendly easy riders. Lots of stops for views, temples and waterfalls.
It was a beautiful drive from Hue to Hoi An. John was very talkative and picked out quiet spots. A great recommendation, and very affordable if you're planning to do the Haivan Pass.

We met John at the train station exit to head to our hotel, and that was the start of two excellent days. We took advantage of his advice to visit Hue easily and quickly, and at unbeatable prices. He shared his experiences as a former tour guide in very understandable English.
We shared a meal at his home, prepared by his wife, which was delicious.
And we chose to tour Hue and Hoi An with him by motorbike, which wasn't our first choice.
But what a discovery! The team of drivers is professional and friendly. The route is magnificent, with a magnificent view, a beautiful beach, a temple, explanations all along the way, and a clean waterfall. We always felt safe, confident, and well received thanks to him.

Best experience ever! 100% recommend! John and kye are very kind and helpfull!

I nearly didnt do a tour but so glad i did! I drove myself but two people i met took the easy rider option and we all had a great time. We were taken on some small roads through the countryside which was lovely and the Hai Van pass itself has incredible views.

We stopped at a waterfall for a refreshing swim, a beach for a seafood lunch, the big lady buddha statue in da nang and a couple of viewpoints for photos.

Kai and John were both great guys and very funny which made the trip even more enjoyable. Would definitely recommend this to anyone thinking about doing the Hai Van pass!

Our trip with Duyen and his partner was fantastic. We felt safe at all times, and it was a very enjoyable trip with lots of laughter and good vibes. They continually adapted to our needs and preferences regarding schedules and locations. Highly recommended. It was an experience where you can enjoy the scenery. All the stops were great. They even gave us a gift.

What an unforgettable experience! We spent a great day with Duyen (John) and his team, who were very friendly. The visit to the waterfall was perfect for cooling off. The bikes were comfortable, and we felt very safe and relaxed throughout the trip. The views from Hai Van Pass were stunning, and we enjoyed the freshest seafood at a phenomenal restaurant right by the ocean. It's definitely the best way to travel between Hue and Hoi An. We highly recommend this tour with Amazing Easy Riders!

The whole experience was amazing Duyen was very safe and stop to take lots of photo and all keep points. This isn't just transport but a high quality day trip. We even added on a stop at the abandoned water park.

We had the most amazing day driving  the Hai VÄƒn Pass with John and Ky as well as the other funny east riders :) they were so attentive and made sure to get us lots of cold beer and ice creams ! Couldnâ€™t recommend enough, felt so safe and just overall had a really brilliant time whilst enjoying amazing views ! John is the best so lovely :)

Incredible tour. Easy riders/tour guide spoke really good English and were so helpful. Great value for money, stunning scenery, and a unique and unmissable way to travel between Hue and Hoi an. Highly recommend this tour to any traveller! John is the bes
What an incredible tour! The scenery was majestic and the drivers were brilliant and good fun. I would definitely recommend this tour!

An amazing tour round the Hai Van Pass!! John was very hospitable and ensured that we were all enjoying ourselves throughout the day. They also very kindly offered water and cold beers. Always felt very safe on the back of the bike and took us to different roads which other tours do not offer. Overall, an amazing experience! Definitely the best experience so far of our trip!

his was the most incredible tour over the Hai Van Pass.

Best tour of our trip!

My fiancÃ©e and I had an incredible day with John. He took us on the back roads from Hoi An to Hue. We made many stops along the way. We viewed the marble cliffs, crossed the impressive Cloud Pass (Hai Van), and went swimming at a waterfall. After swimming, we also had dinner together there. It was fantastic!
We drove the rest of the way to Hue along the edge of the lagoon. The traffic was very quiet there, and the lagoon was truly beautiful.
Our luggage was safely transported to our destination.
This tour is highly recommended for anyone traveling here!

Was a very awesome Trip. Ky and Huu were really friendly guides. First we went to the top of the Mountain in danang and then to a very nice waterfall for a swim. Followed by an awesome tour through the montains and really delicious Food. At the end we drive through the Rice fields and then got droppen Off at the hotel. Would definetly recommend this tour!

Incredible experience! A super-comprehensive route from Hoi An to Hue. The guide was very friendly and attentive at all times. He was always flexible and tailored the route to our needs. He took us to spots without tourists and all along beautiful roads. An experience I recommend to everyone.

We had a great day with Johnny (Duyen) and Chan!! For anyone who isnâ€™t as confident about jumping on a motorbike and attempting the Hai Van Pass, this is the perfect trip for you. The trip is very well paced and Duyen and Chan are both excellent drivers. The scenery is stunning, lunch is fantastic and the swim at the waterfall is the perfect refreshing afternoon dip. What a great way to get from Hoi An to Hue!

We had the pleasure of being guided by John over the Hai Van Pass during our recent trip to Vietnam, and we cannot recommend him enough. John's emotional investment in his work is evident from the moment you meet him.

He took the time to get to know each of us personally, asking about our interests and preferences to ensure that our experience on the Hai Van Pass was tailored to our needs. John's attention to detail and genuine care for his clients made us feel like we were traveling with a close friend rather than a tour guide.

Furthermore, John's ability to anticipate our needs and concerns was truly remarkable. He went above and beyond to ensure that we were comfortable and safe throughout our journey, and he even went out of his way to help us with some unexpected challenges we encountered.

Overall, we cannot thank John enough for his exceptional guidance and care during our trip to the Hai Van Pass. He truly embodies the spirit of hospitality and service, and we would recommend him without hesitation to anyone looking for an unforgettable experience in Vietnam.

The tour was awesome. I was picked up at 8am. First we drove through the country side and to a small market as we were waiting for two others. My driver Trang was super nice. He made sure that I felt comfortable and showed me a lot. I highly recommend a tour with the Amazing Easyriders. It was definitely a highlight of my Vietnam trip.
Great company! They picked us up from the train station in Hue and brought us to Hoi An with their motorbikes. Beautiful trip, with nice stops. Definitely recommended.

Huu was an amazing rider and felt safe and comfortable. He made sure I was safe and ready. Took me to some awesome views. Unfortunately the weather was cloudy but still enjoyable. I highly recommend him.
no problem, even with a change of return date. The manager is super nice.
Excellent day tour from Hue to Hoi An, Via the waterfall, high van pass. Amazing drivers and very nice stopping places along the way.
Most amazing day on the Hai Van Pass, such lovely drivers so friendly and happy. Would recommend to everyone so much fun if you drive yourself or have an easy rider!!

Had such a lovely experience doing the Hai Van Pass with brother John & Kyle. Brother John was super helpful, friendly & told us lots of information along the way. The waterfalls were amazing & the lunch included delicious. Book with these if you want a guaranteed good experience that you wonâ€™t forget!
Best experience ever! Brother John was the best. Couldnâ€™t have asked for a better tour guide. Canâ€™t recommend enough!!!

I enjoyed the tour.
The guide speaks a little English and is friendly.

As a couple in our late 50â€™s with no experience of motorbikes we were quite nervous about the 90mile trip from Hue to Hoi an. We were picked up on time at 8am from our hotel in Hue, our large holdalls that weighed about 22Kg were sent separately to our chosen hotel in Hoi an and once weâ€™d met up with the two others in our party we were off. We did not take the highway but instead weaved through the labyrinth of paddyfields, stopping every 30mins or so for tea, coffee, water or just an photo opportunity. Duyen and his team were thoughtful and considerate of our needs.
We stopped at waterfalls to swim and lunch just before the Hai Van pass. The pass itself was not as busy as we were expecting with few lorries, mainly bikes and cars so in no way did we feel in any danger on the tight corners. We rode through Da Nang and onto our destination via the Marble mountains. We arrived around 6pm which seems long but we had so many stops it did not seem as though we had been riding all day.
I cannot recommend this tour highly enough. Our pre trip nerves were totally unfounded
Great experience and is a must for anyone doing the Hai long pass. Peace and love BP out
Great experience! The tour brought us to a lot of cool places, and the tour guide was awesome! Good value for money

Had a great trip with amazing easy riders, made our transfer from Hue to Hoi An very memorable and a true highlight of our trip to Vietnam! The drivers were all very kind and funny, we felt completely safe despite not having ridden on motorbikes before. We made lots of stops along the way for photos and experiences, and for the price it included SO MANY things, the lunch was huge and filling, and the marble mountain tour was very interesting! Would highly recommend to anyone (P.S our luggage was safely transported to hoi an for us also!)

We were a group of five and did the Hai van pass tour from Hoi An to Hue. We got one jeep and two easy rider motorbikes. This way everyone could change between sitting in the jeep or on the bikes. We felt very safe with our drivers the whole trip. They stopped at great viewpoints and the time we spent at each stop was enough. The lunch was also great. Really recommend doing this tour with Amazing easy riders!

A very nice biker tour. I ride a motorcycle myself and I have to say that I felt very comfortable and safe as a passenger. The drivers arrived at the hotel on time and packed our luggage securely with protective film, which I thought was very nice. We were able to take beautiful photos during the photo stop. We also had good stops for coffee and lunch at the waterfall. I really enjoyed the Vietnamese food. The drivers were always polite and helpful. I'm glad I wasn't driving myself, so I could relax and enjoy the beautiful route from the back.

I would like to thank my driver Duyen again; he was wonderful.

Thank you, thank you. I will never forget this motorcycle trip.

Bao Vinh ancient town is located in Huong Vinh commune (Huong Tra town, Thua Thien Hue province), about 5km from Hue city center. This ancient town is located in the Thanh Ha - Bao Vinh port chain, one of the two largest ancient trading ports in Dang Trong in the 17th - 19th centuries, along with Hoi An port (Quang Nam). In 1636, after moving the Lord's palace from Phuc An to Kim Long, Lord Nguyen Phuc Lan chose the Sinh intersection overlooking Thuan An border gate to open Thanh Ha port. Formed on the land of two villages Minh Huong and Dia Linh due to the migration and settlement of Chinese people, Thanh Ha port quickly became a bustling trading port, bustling with boats on the wharf and under the boat. Merchant ships from China, Japan, India and some European countries often docked at the port to buy and sell goods.

Bao Vinh ancient town is located next to Hue citadel, formerly the economic center of Phu Xuan citadel. Chinese merchant ships used to come here to trade and exchange goods. Later, the Nguyen lords moved the economic center to Hoi An, so commercial activities in Bao Vinh ancient town gradually decreased over time. However, here still preserves and maintains cultural values â€‹â€‹over hundreds of years. If you have the opportunity to visit Hue, you should visit Bao Vinh once to feel the soul of the ancient town that was once famous.

The Garden Estates are a fascinating blend of beautiful scenery and traditional architecture unique to Hue. This particular site, a prime example of this, was originally the residence of the daughter of Emperor Duc Duc, the fifth emperor of the Vietnam War. Learning this history, just stepping inside created a special atmosphere.

The vast 5,000-square-meter grounds are filled with tropical fruits like jackfruit, and just walking around soothes the soul. The highlight of the estate is the "pillar house" (nhÃ  rÆ°á»ng), built in the traditional Hue style. It features detached buildings on both sides of the main building, meticulously carved in detail, and its traditional interior has been preserved. I found myself lost in time, gazing at the house, imagining what life was like for the princesses of the time.

While the garden itself is free to visit, entering the house costs 20,000 VND. If you're interested in Hue culture and architecture, I highly recommend taking a tour inside.
View ok

This garden house began to appear in the late 19th century when the 18th princess of King Duc Duc built the house. After that, the house was passed through the hands of many noble people, most notably Mrs. Dao Thi Xuan Yen, wife of the Governor Nguyen Dinh Chi, who preserved this heritage until 1997. Currently, her descendants continue to preserve it, turning An Hien into a living symbol of the aristocratic lifestyle of the Nguyen Dynasty, through many events of war and revolution. The architecture of the house consists of three main rooms and two wings with pillars made from rare jackfruit wood. The roof is tiled in layers, the climax is decorated with lotus flowers symbolizing purity. Passing through the ancient brick archway hidden under the shade of the trees is a "Tho" shaped screen that helps block evil spirits according to feng shui, then the brick-paved path leads straight to the central worship space, where there is a gilded red-lacquered horizontal lacquered board with the four words "Van Vo Trung Hieu", given by King Bao Dai in 1937. Around the garden, fruit trees bloom all year round including jackfruit, guava, durian, dragon fruit, mixed with roses, jasmine, and brilliant camellias. Everything blends together to create a harmonious natural picture. Sitting and sipping a cup of delicious jasmine tea feels so relaxing. The tour guide is cute, enthusiastic, easy to understand, and has a captivating voice.
I visited many old garden houses in Hue, I must say that An Hien garden house is the most beautiful original house and is the most carefully preserved by the new owner. It is worth visiting.

Located on the north bank of the Perfume River, on the way to Thien Mu Pagoda, An Hien Garden House has existed for more than a century, still preserving almost intact the beauty of the landscape and ancient Hue garden house architecture, bearing the quintessence of the aristocracy and traditional folk colors. 
The garden house's campus is almost square, 7000 m2 wide, planned and built according to traditional architectural principles. 
The path from the gate to the house is more than 30m long and covered with two rows of white apricot trees; 
In front of the house is a very large shallow pond and a fairly large brick screen; 
In the middle of the garden is a three-room, two-wing house with exemplary structure and carvings. Inside the house are mahogany beds, tea cabinets, horizontal lacquered boards, parallel sentences, and furniture arranged in a harmonious and reasonable manner, giving the house a distinct spirit. 
An Hien Garden House owns many valuable relics of the Nguyen Dynasty's royal court. that is the horizontal plaque â€œliterary and martial loyalty and filial pietyâ€ given by King Bao Dai in 1937, along with many poems by King Thanh Thai hung in the reception area.
In the garden, there are many types of high-class perennial plants taken from three regions and hundreds of precious flowers, taking turns blooming and bearing fruit in all four seasons.
An Hien garden house is a typical representative of Hue garden house, showing the harmony between human life and plants, between spiritual and material life, complementing each other to create balance in life.

With nearly 7k m2 of land, there are 2 old jackfruit wood houses and a brick house located next to each other. The house was raised higher than the original to prevent termites from eating the pillars, now it is raised with stone pillars. The house is roofed with 5 layers of tiles, the floor has been replaced with bricks now. In front of the house is a small pond with water lilies, there are brick paths in the garden. In total, there are about 300 trees from the North, South and Central regions. Some trees are probably 100 years old. The garden house is located right on the bank of the Huong River, formerly the residence of the princess, after a period of buying and selling, the garden house is now owned by a Hanoian who is the owner of Silkpath Hotel. There is a security guard outside watching the car without a ticket, the entrance fee is 50k. Hue City, famous for its quiet and ancient features, has a completely different color in the Western Quarter - where the hustle and bustle, fun and modernity in tourism converge. Located on routes such as Chu Van An, Pham Ngu Lao, Vo Thi Sau, the Western Quarter becomes an attractive destination for both international tourists and domestic youth. 
At night, the quarter lights up with sparkling lights from bars, pubs, restaurants, and international-style cafes. Lively music resounds, mixed with bustling laughter, creating a lively atmosphere. Activities such as street music performances, night markets, street food, etc. take place regularly, bringing diverse experiences to visitors. 
The flexibility in organizing events and promoting tourism associated with local culture is also a strength of Hue. Despite its modernity, the Western Quarter still retains the "Hue quality" through friendly, gentle service style, and dishes rich in the flavors of the ancient capital. 
The Western Quarter is a testament to the dynamic transformation in Hue's tourism approach â€“ both youthful and retaining the old spirit.

The Thuong Bac Palace is located on the north bank of the Perfume River and is a relic belonging to the Hue Monuments Complex. It was built in 1875 during the reign of King Tu Duc.

Originally, in 1875 under the reign of King Tu Duc, a building called Thuong Bac Institute (TÃ²a ThÆ°Æ¡ng Báº¡c) was constructed near the current park's location to welcome imperial envoys. In front of it, a pavilion near the riverbank was built to receive merchants; this was the Thuong Bac Pavilion (ÄÃ¬nh ThÆ°Æ¡ng Báº¡c).
In 1921, King Khai Dinh rebuilt the pavilion into an octagonal structure using new materials. Over time, the Thuong Bac Institute was repurposed and no longer exists. However, the Thuong Bac Pavilion remained and the surrounding area eventually developed into the Thuong Bac Park we see today, a scenic spot by the Perfume River.
The central area specializes in organizing culinary events of Hue Citadel, focusing on fairs and is worth being an interesting destination when exploring Hue for tourists and locals.
Amazing park with great electric ride ons for kids. There every night!

In 1875, King Tu Duc did not want to welcome foreign envoys in the capital, so he built a silver trading post outside the upper gate. On the opposite side, he built a communal house near the river bank to receive merchants.
After the fall of the capital (July 5, 1885), the trading house was abandoned and collapsed.
In 1936, the king ordered the rebuilding of the silver hospital (silver trading house) on the left bank of the Huong River, about 100m from the old location to remember that relic.
The silver communal house was built in the old style with new materials, including two roof floors, built on a 1.30m high square foundation. The lower floor plan is octagonal, the upper floor is reduced to a square, with the word "silver trade" inlaid in blue porcelain on all four sides. The pillars are made of concrete and the roof is covered with lapis lazuli tiles. The floor is paved with square tiles, surrounded by low flower walls, and there are steps on all four sides.
On the top of the roof are two dragons flanking the sun, and the roof corners are stylized with decorations. In front of the communal house is a large yard, facing the street are 4 square pillars, on top of which is a lotus flower, on each pillar is a parallel sentence made of porcelain, recording the rich beauty of the capital.
Thuong Bac Park starts from Phu Xuan Bridge to Trang Tien Bridge, along the banks of the Huong River and Tran Hung Dao Street, and is also where Hue City holds the spring flower festival every year.

Hien Lam Cac is a special architectural work located in the The Mieu area of Hue Imperial City, part of the Complex of Hue Monuments - World Cultural Heritage.

â¸»

ðŸ” Main information about Hien Lam Cac:
â€¢ ðŸ“ Location: Located in front of The To Mieu, in the Hue Imperial City area.
â€¢ ðŸ›ï¸ Function:
â€¢ Built in 1821 under the reign of King Minh Mang,
â€¢ A memorial to honor the meritorious mandarins, civil and military mandarins and kings of the Nguyen Dynasty.
â€¢ A place to offer incense and commemorate ancestors who have contributed to the country and the court.
â€¢ ðŸ—ï¸ Architecture:
â€¢ The tallest 3-storey wooden building in the Imperial City (about 17m high),
â€¢ Considered the maximum height limit in the Imperial City - no building is allowed to be higher to maintain its solemnity.
â€¢ The floors are covered with glazed tiles, intricately carved with dragons, phoenixes, and royal motifs.

â¸»

ðŸ”¸ Meaning of the name â€œHien Lam Cacâ€:
â€¢ â€œHienâ€ means glory, â€œLamâ€ means forest â€“ that is, the forest of talented people and famous officials.
â€¢ The name shows respect and gratitude for the great achievements of our ancestors.
Great

Hien Lam Cac was built in 1821, considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings. 
is a 3-storey wooden building with harmonious proportions on a high foundation. 
The first floor has 3 rooms, 2 wings, and three brick exteriors. Above the middle door hangs a large horizontal lacquered board with three words "Hien Lam Cac", a frame carved with 9 dragons playing with clouds, painted red and gilded. 
The second floor has 3 rooms, the front and back sides are built with shutter doors, and the outside is a meticulously crafted wooden railing system. 
The third floor has 1 room, the front and back sides are built with shutter doors. The roof is covered with yellow glazed tiles, and in the middle of the top is a wine gourd made of yellow enamel placed on a five-color cloud table. 
Hien Lam Cac is sturdy thanks to 24 wooden pillars, 4 of which are 3-storey high, serving as the backbone of the building. The triple-link systems, panels, and rafters are embossed with stylized dragon motifs. 
Hien Lam Pavilion is one of the few buildings in the imperial citadel that survived the war.

Hien Lam Cac was built from 1821 to 1822 under the reign of King Minh Mang, to honor the founding fathers of the Nguyen Dynasty. This work not only has architectural value but is also an important memorial in Vietnamese history. Hien Lam Cac is 17m high, the tallest building in the Hue Imperial Citadel area. Its architecture is designed with high-rise wood, with a rectangular high ground, paved with Bat Trang tiles. The work is divided into three floors, each floor has its own beauty and artistic value. The first floor stands out with sophisticated sculptures, while the second and third floors bring a solemn and peaceful space.

Hien Lam Cac is an architectural work located right in front of The Mieu inside the grounds of Hue Imperial City, built together with The Mieu (1821-1822 under King Minh Mang). This work is considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings worshiped at The Mieu and the mandarins who had merit worshiped at the two houses Ta Tung Tu and Huu Tung Tu.

Hien Lam The 3-storey architectural works have high aesthetic value, built mainly of wood on a high rectangular foundation, the floor is paved with Bat Trang bricks, built with bricks, lime mortar and embossed ceramic pieces for decoration. From the yard, step up to the ground by two systems of stone steps in the front and back, each system has 9 steps. The two sides of the steps are carved with dragon shapes in the middle, which is the limit of the path reserved for the King.
Very well maintained
Lovely well restored place to visit.

This structure is the tallest in the Imperial City and also the tallest in the Capital. According to construction law, no structure in the Capital is allowed to be higher than Hien Lam Cac. Thanks to that, the Capital still has open space and maintains the solemnity of the Imperial City.

At 17 meters, it is the tallest structure in the Citadel. It has three floors, and the emperor prohibited any building in the citadel from exceeding the height of Hiá»ƒn LÃ¢m CÃ¡c.
It was built in 1821 by Emperor Minh Mang to honor all those who made the Nguyen dynasty reach its greatest splendor.
It has a pyramidal shape. The ground floor is built of stone and consists of five rooms. The second floor is built of wood and consists of three rooms. The upper floor is also built of wood and consists of a single room.
Inside, we find an exhibition with information about the site and magnificent views of the central courtyard.

This place attracts tourists inside the Hue Imperial City.

Hien Lam Cac - an ancient architectural work located inside the grounds of the Hue Imperial City. This relic was built in 1821 and is one of the places with important historical significance during the reign of King Minh Mang.

In the itinerary to explore the Hue tourist map, Hien Lam Cac is an extremely interesting destination that should not be missed. With a prime location near the shrine area with a height of more than 17m, Hien Lam Cac is considered one of the tallest and most beautiful works in the Imperial City.

Hien Lam Cac is located inside the Hue Citadel, located on Hai Muoi Ba Thang Tam Street, Thuan Thanh Ward, Hue City. This work is a monument commemorating the contributions of the Nguyen Dynasty kings and mandarins who were loyal and built a prosperous country.

Ancient Hue Hien Lam Cac architecture, unique beauty
The Hien Lam Cac is made of high-quality wood, 3-storey high architecture, built on a rectangular ground, the entire floor is paved with Bat Trang tiles. From the front yard moving up to the ground, visitors will have to go through a system of stone steps in the front and back, each side has 9 steps. The steps are shaped like dragons, the middle path is reserved for the king.

In the third row of columns from the front, a row of panels is erected, between each room is an arched door. The types of rafters, triple-layer panels, panels on this floor are all carved with super impressive flying dragons. Above the main entrance is a large horizontal lacquered board with three Chinese characters "Hien Lam Cac", the frame is carved with 9 dragons painted in red and gilded.

Entering Hien Lam Cac, on the right side there is a staircase to the 2nd floor, the railing is divided into decorative compartments in the shape of "thá»•" and "váº¡n" characters with geometric lines carved with dragons at the beginning and end. 

Above the 2nd floor there are three compartments with the front and back of the shutter doors, surrounded by rows of meticulously crafted balusters. Supporting the roof truss of this floor are 4 main columns, 4 secondary columns, and a system of beautifully carved balusters. 

The top 3rd floor has only 1 compartment with the way up being a wooden staircase with 9 steps.

HIEN LAM CAC was built at the same time as The Mieu (1821 - 1822 - under King Minh Mang), located right in front of The Mieu. This is a project considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings worshiped at The Mieu and the mandarins who had merit worshiped at the two houses Ta Tung Tu and Huu Tung Tu.

Hien Lam Cac is a 3-storey wooden architectural work, built on a high rectangular foundation, paved with Bat Trang bricks, built with bricks, lime mortar and embossed ceramic pieces for decoration. From the yard, step up to the ground by two systems of stone steps in the front and back, each system has 9 steps. The two sides of the steps are decorated with dragons in the middle, which is the limit of the path reserved for the King. The first floor is divided into three rooms and two wings, around the three outer sides of the two wings are brick walls to reinforce the bearing capacity of the columns and cover the interior. On the third row of columns from the front, a row of panels is erected, with an arched door in the middle of each room. The truss system, triple-layer panels, and panels on this floor are all embossed with stylized dragon motifs transformed into leafy vines. On the middle door hangs a large horizontal lacquered board with the three words "Hien Lam Cac" on a green background, with a frame carved with 9 dragons playing with clouds painted in red and gilded.

Nguyá»…n ÄÃ¬nh Chiá»ƒu Walking Street in Huáº¿ is a hidden gem that offers a delightful mix of local charm, culture, and relaxation right in the heart of the city. I spent an evening here during my recent trip to Huáº¿ and was absolutely enchanted by its peaceful ambiance and riverside beauty.

Stretching along the Perfume River, this walking street is smaller and more intimate than some of the more commercial pedestrian streets in Vietnam, but thatâ€™s exactly what makes it special. Itâ€™s clean, well-maintained, and has a uniquely calm and romantic atmosphere â€” especially around sunset, when the sky turns golden and reflects off the water.

What I appreciated most was the blend of local life and gentle tourism. Youâ€™ll find local families taking walks, street performers playing traditional Vietnamese instruments, and small stalls selling art, souvenirs, and light snacks. There are also several charming cafÃ©s and teahouses where you can sit and enjoy the view while sipping a cold drink or Vietnamese coffee.

The street is beautifully lit in the evening, with colorful lanterns and tasteful lighting that enhances the cozy and poetic feel. Itâ€™s the perfect place to take a leisurely stroll, unwind after a day of sightseeing, or just people-watch and feel the rhythm of Huáº¿.

If youâ€™re visiting Huáº¿, donâ€™t miss this spot. Nguyá»…n ÄÃ¬nh Chiá»ƒu Walking Street is the kind of place that doesnâ€™t try too hard â€” it simply lets Huáº¿â€™s gentle soul speak for itself. Five stars without a doubt.

Nguyen Dinh Chieu Walking Street is a charming riverside promenade that blends local culture, scenic views, and relaxed energy. Located along the southern bank of the Perfume River, it stretches from Phu Xuan Bridge to Truong Tien Bridge and opens daily from late afternoon into the evening. As the sun sets, the area comes alive with street vendors selling snacks, drinks, and handcrafted souvenirs. The LED-lit bridges and river breeze create a peaceful backdrop for strolling, people-watching, or catching impromptu street performances.

The street is compact but full of characterâ€”ideal for a short walk or a casual night out. Itâ€™s pedestrian-only, making it safe and quiet compared to busier city zones. Locals gather for music, games, and evening hangouts, while visitors enjoy the mix of food stalls, art displays, and photo spots. Itâ€™s not a major shopping hub, but itâ€™s a great place to soak in Hueâ€™s laid-back nightlife and riverside charm.

The Royal Museum of Antiquities of Hue is said to be the oldest museum in Hue. Originally built by Emperor Khai Dinh in 1923, the building itself was moved from another palace in 1845, and I was immediately impressed by its rich history. It's also fascinating to learn that Emperor Khai Dinh, a great lover of art, sought to understand his country's culture through art.

Originally named after him, the museum's name changed over the years to its current name.

Stepping inside, I was awed by the more than 8,000 beautiful royal artifacts left behind by Vietnam's last dynasty. From the resplendent throne and imperial costumes to tableware, furniture, and even mother-of-pearl flooring, the museum is filled with beautifully preserved, priceless pieces. Reading the explanation that each piece is unique, crafted by artisans specializing in royal art, I marveled at the high level of skill and meticulous work of the artisans of the time.

This museum is included in the admission ticket for the Royal Palace (150,000 VND) and is not sold separately. It is only a 7-minute walk from the East Gate of the Royal Palace, so it is recommended to visit it together with sightseeing at the Royal Palace.

Le Loi Park in Hue, is actually a 3-2 park located along the Perfume River on Le Loi Street - one of the most beautiful and historical streets of the ancient capital. This is an ideal space to relax and experience culture and nature with local people. 

---

ðŸ“ Location & general information

Address: Le Loi Street, Phu Hoi Ward, Hue City, Thua Thien Hue

Opening hours & entrance fee: open 24/7, free

Length: nearly 1km along the south bank of the Perfume River

---

ðŸŒ³ Natural & artistic space

Covered with green trees, many stone benches, beautiful flowers and leaves, fresh air - very suitable for walking, jogging, light exercise in the early morning or late afternoon.

In addition to ancient trees and colorful flowers, the park also displays stone statues and sculptures with Hue cultural nuances, serving check-in and outdoor art learning. 

---

ðŸŽ­ Community & cultural activities

Hue people: often exercise such as walking, running, and yoga in the morning, while in the evening, young people organize art performances, volleyball, and picnics. 

Events & festivals: places where public activities, festivals, outdoor exhibitions and cultural activities such as kite flying, concerts, especially during the Hue Festival take place. 

---

ðŸ›ï¸ Nearby monuments & attractions

On the banks of the Perfume River, opposite the park is Le Loi boat station, the departure point for dragon boats and river cruises, enjoying Hue folk songs, and enjoying afternoon tea on the river. 

Nearby, there are also light cafe & restaurant routes such as Le Parfum, Windows CafÃ©, Park View Restaurant - making it easy for you to combine a rest after a walk. 

Near: Truong Tien Bridge, Imperial Citadel, Royal Fine Arts Museum, Thien Mu Pagoda... convenient for your journey to explore Hue. 

---

ðŸ“ Notes & suggestions for experiences

Ideal time: early morning or late afternoon - avoid the hot noon. 

Bring water, hats or sun umbrellas - although there is a lot of shade, it is still quite hot at noon and summer. 

Try the experience: join the morning health class, listen to Hue folk songs on the boat in the afternoon, or picnic, take photos at the statue, observatory, small stage.

The perfect mountain for beginners to climb. It took me about 10 minutes to climb all the way from the foot of the mountain to the top. Climbing up is easy, but going down is quite overwhelming for those who are not used to it. Since the reign of King Gia Long, this mountain was chosen as a criminal record, a natural screen shielding the Hue citadel, meaning to protect the prosperity of the dynasty. More specifically, King Gia Long ordered each mandarin to plant a pine tree on the mountain, creating a vast green pine forest that is still a symbol of Ngu Binh today. Standing on the top, you can see the beautiful panorama of Hue below

Along with the Perfume River, Ngu Binh Mountain is a wonderful symbol of Hue. Therefore, Ngu Binh is gradually becoming an ideal destination for tourists who love nature and want to enjoy the fresh air. Ngu Binh Mountain is located about 3km from the south bank of the Perfume River, in the former location of Tu Tay Hamlet, An Cuu Village; then Thuy An Commune, Hue City; now An Cuu Ward of the city. Although this mountain is only 104m high, because it rises suddenly in the middle of flat land, in a special position, since the 17th century, it has been in the sights and caught the eye of Hue urban planners and builders. Indeed, in its history and geography books, the National History Institute of the Nguyen Dynasty clearly recorded that in 1687, when Lord Nguyen Phuc Thai moved the capital from Kim Long to Phu Xuan Village, the architects at that time used this special mountain as a screen, a feng shui element in ancient architecture. At that time, it was called Hon Mo or Bang Son. Bang is a very large bird, like an eagle for example. The reason for the name Bang Son is because the mountain looks like an eagle spreading its wings to fly. This is a natural mountain, but from the north, it looks balanced, the two wings on the east and west sides are symmetrical to each other evenly as if they were built and shaped by human hands. Moreover, the two slopes on both sides of the mountain slightly protrude forward, looking like two arms spreading forward to welcome someone. The beauty of Ngu mountain is not in the feng shui aspect of protecting Hue citadel, the beauty of Ngu mountain is that it is close to the people of Hue, it becomes a platform, a towering building and going up there on artificial steps, people can stretch their eyes to admire the gentle beauty of Hue citadel, listen to the echoes from far below, and feel like they are in some other world, otherworldly.

The most ancient and sacred pagoda in the ancient capital of Hue is Tu Dam Pagoda. Founded by Zen Master Minh Hoang Tu Dung in the late 17th century with the original name An Ton, the pagoda was renamed Tu Dam by King Thieu Tri in 1841, meaning "good clouds", symbolizing purity and compassion. With more than 300 years of history, this place is not only a Buddhist center but also a valuable cultural heritage of Vietnam. The architecture of Tu Dam Pagoda delicately blends classical and modern features. The tiled gate with sturdy stone steps opens the way to the airy campus, where there is an ancient Bodhi tree, grafted from the Bodhi tree in India in 1936, providing peaceful shade. Here is the 27m high An Ton Stupa with 7 floors, it is said that inside each floor is a bronze Buddha statue, creating a solemn and unique beauty. The main hall was rebuilt in 2006 in the style of the Hue royal palace, the surrounding space is filled with the scent of incense, very pleasant, inside is a statue of Buddha Shakyamuni and two statues of Bodhisattva Manjushri and Samantabhadra. Behind the main hall is the Ancestor's house, where the 28th Zen master Bodhidharma, the Zen master Minh Hoang Tu Dung and his successors are worshiped, showing respect for Buddhist traditions. Next to it is a souvenir room like a small museum, displaying historical relics, helping people understand more about the development of the pagoda. This is one of the pagodas to visit when coming to Hue because of the long history of Buddhist development, and the value of the historical stories it brings.

Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda in Huáº¿ is one of the most peaceful and spiritually significant places Iâ€™ve ever visited. Nestled in the heart of the ancient imperial city, this pagoda is not only a place of worship but also a cultural and historical landmark that reflects the deep roots of Vietnamese Buddhism.

What makes Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda especially meaningful to me is the legacy of one of its most revered monks: Venerable ThÃ­ch TrÃ­ Quang. I have long admired him for his intellect, his dedication to Buddhism, and especially his work translating and interpreting many important Buddhist texts into Vietnamese. His influence on Vietnamese Buddhism, both in spiritual and cultural terms, is profound. Though he has passed away, his spirit and teachings are very much alive in this sacred space. It was incredibly moving to walk through the grounds and know that this was a place he once walked, taught, and meditated.

The pagoda itself is beautiful â€” quiet, clean, and filled with the scent of incense. The architecture is traditional yet timeless, with a large main hall, well-tended gardens, and statues that inspire a deep sense of calm and reverence. The monks and caretakers are kind and respectful, and there is a genuine atmosphere of compassion and wisdom here.

If you are in Huáº¿ and seeking a meaningful spiritual experience â€” or simply want a quiet space to reflect â€” I highly recommend visiting Tá»« ÄÃ m Pagoda. For me, it was more than a visit; it was a moment of connection with history, faith, and the legacy of a great teacher.
