Tu Dam Pagoda is a famous ancient pagoda in Hue, currently located at 1 Su Lieu Quan Street, Truong An Ward, Thuan Hoa District, Hue City, Vietnam.

History
The pagoda was founded by Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung[1] around the end of the 17th century, and was later named An Ton Pagoda (å°å®—å¯º, or Tong), meaning "taking the transmission of the mind as the main principle"[2].

In 1702, monk Lieu Quan (later also a high monk) came to the pagoda, asking to study with Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung[3]

In 1703, Zen Master Minh Hoang - Tu Dung restored the pagoda. Also in this year, Lord Nguyen Phuc Chu granted the pagoda the Sac Tu An Ton Tu plaque. After the Master passed away, according to his will, his student Zen Master Thiet Vinh - Buu Hanh became the abbot of the pagoda.

In 1802, the Tay Son dynasty was overthrown. At that time, due to time and war, An Ton Pagoda was severely damaged like many other pagodas in the region [4]. However, it was not until the 12th year of Gia Long (1813) that Zen Master Dao Trung - Trong Nghia was able to organize the restoration of the pagoda [5]. 

In 1841, King Thieu Tri changed the name of An Ton Pagoda to Tu Dam-æ…ˆæ›‡å¯º (to avoid the taboo of the king's name Mien Tong) [5], meaning "the auspicious cloud of Buddhism" [6]. 

In the 9th year of Thanh Thai (1897), the king ordered the road to Nam Giao altar to be opened. Because this road passed through the grounds of Tu Dam Pagoda, the king ordered the abbot, Zen Master Thanh Hiep - Tuong Van, to move the 5 stupas containing the remains of the ancestors to the grounds of Bao Quoc Pagoda nearby. Perhaps on this occasion, the abbot had the pagoda restored again [7]. 

From the 1920s onwards, the Vietnamese Buddhist revival movement developed in all three regions. During that time, Tu Dam Pagoda was the center of the Central Buddhist Revival Movement[8].

In 1932, the An Nam Buddhist Association (later renamed the Central Vietnamese Buddhist Association) was established in Hue... In 1936, the Lam Te sect agreed to hand over Tu Dam Pagoda to the association as a place of worship and as the association's headquarters.

On December 18, 1938, the Thua Thien Provincial Buddhist Association had Tu Dam Pagoda extensively renovated, and at the same time cast a statue of Buddha Shakyamuni and other Dharma instruments to enshrine in the main hall, which was completed in 1940. Other items such as lecture halls, monks' quarters and some offices of the Provincial Association were also built during that time[9].

In 1943, the Gia Dinh Phat Hoa Pho was established; In 1951, it was renamed the Buddhist Family, and its headquarters was located at Tu Dam Pagoda[10].

In 1951, the Congress to establish the Vietnam Buddhist Sangha took place at the pagoda.

In 1951, the Conference to establish the Vietnam Buddhist Sangha (including 51 delegates from 6 groups of monks and lay people in the three regions) was also held here. At that time, the Association also approved the Most Venerable To Lien to sign on behalf of the Association to join the World Buddhist Association.

In the 1960s, Tu Dam Pagoda was the center of activities to fight against the religious policy under President Ngo Dinh Diem.

Currently, the pagoda has the office of the Hue City Buddhist Executive Committee.

I had an incredible time doing the Hai Van Pass from Hue to Hoi An with Johnny and Ky! I booked on WhatsApp with Ky, who has great English, and had super quick responses. We started with a lovely drive through rice fields to a waterfall where we swam, jumped & slid in! The highlight of this section of the road was the super cute ducklings!!! After going in the waterfall they provided us with plastic bags for our wet stuff which was very thoughtful. We then had a very good lunch - mountain chicken, morning glory, omelette and rice! We then continued driving and stopped at the beach for a wander and Johnnyâ€™s very funny magic card trick!!! The Hai Van Pass itself was beautiful and we stopped at lots of viewpoints for amazing photos!!! We also saw monkeys and stopped at a pagoda with a huge Buddha before continuing through Da Nang to Hoi An. I am so glad I was recommended these amazing guys from friends I met during my travels as it was an amazing day! Special shoutout to my easy rider Johnny who had incredible English and was so funny and chatty!!! I will remember this day for a long time - it definitely stands out as one of my favourite days in over 6 months travelling!!!

Furthermore, John's ability to anticipate our needs and concerns was truly remarkable. He went above and beyond to ensure that we were comfortable and safe throughout our journey, and he even went out of his way to help us with some unexpected challenges we encountered.

Overall, we cannot thank John enough for his exceptional guidance and care during our trip to the Hai Van Pass. He truly embodies the spirit of hospitality and service, and we would recommend him without hesitation to anyone looking for an unforgettable experience in Vietnam.

As a couple in our late 50â€™s with no experience of motorbikes we were quite nervous about the 90mile trip from Hue to Hoi an. We were picked up on time at 8am from our hotel in Hue, our large holdalls that weighed about 22Kg were sent separately to our chosen hotel in Hoi an and once weâ€™d met up with the two others in our party we were off. We did not take the highway but instead weaved through the labyrinth of paddyfields, stopping every 30mins or so for tea, coffee, water or just an photo opportunity. Duyen and his team were thoughtful and considerate of our needs.
We stopped at waterfalls to swim and lunch just before the Hai Van pass. The pass itself was not as busy as we were expecting with few lorries, mainly bikes and cars so in no way did we feel in any danger on the tight corners. We rode through Da Nang and onto our destination via the Marble mountains. We arrived around 6pm which seems long but we had so many stops it did not seem as though we had been riding all day.
I cannot recommend this tour highly enough. Our pre trip nerves were totally unfounded

Hue Traditional Handcrafts Space is a captivating journey into the heart of Hue's rich cultural heritage. More than just a display of artifacts, this exhibition masterfully recreates the atmosphere and spirit of the city's age-old artisan traditions, offering a deeply immersive and educational experience for visitors.
This authenticity brings the crafts to life, allowing visitors to appreciate the skill and dedication required to create each piece.
One of the exhibition's greatest strengths is its focus on the human element. Information panels not only describe the history and techniques of each craft but also share stories about the families and individuals who have preserved these traditions for generations. This personal touch makes the exhibition more than a historical record; it becomes a tribute to the legacy of Hue's master artisans.
Highlights of the exhibition include the stunning display of Ã¡o dÃ i weaving, where the intricacy of the brocade patterns is breathtaking, and the section on wood carving, which showcases the incredible precision and artistry of Hue's craftsmen. The scent of incense and the sound of traditional music subtly permeate the air, further enhancing the sensory experience and transporting visitors to the serene and contemplative world of these traditional crafts.
While the exhibition is comprehensive, it maintains a sense of flow and a clear narrative. It beautifully demonstrates how these crafts are not isolated skills but are deeply interwoven with the social, religious, and economic fabric of Hue. The exhibition effectively communicates that these traditions are not relics of the past but a vibrant, living part of Hue's identity today.
In conclusion, the "KhÃ´ng Gian Nghá» Truyá»n Thá»‘ng Huáº¿" is an absolute must-see for anyone interested in Vietnamese culture, history, or craftsmanship. It is a beautifully curated and profoundly moving tribute to the artisans who have shaped Hue's cultural landscape. This exhibition is a testament to the enduring beauty and resilience of traditional crafts and a powerful reminder of the importance of preserving these valuable legacies for future generations.

I came across this place by chance while walking along the Perfume River. The tour was truly a memorable experience. I had the opportunity to learn about famous crafts in Hue such as Sinh village paintings, Chuon village wine, Phuoc Tich pottery, Thanh Tien paper flowers, lantern making, incense making, conical hats, and kite making. In particular, the experience of making conical hats helped me understand more about the stages to make a hat. Through that, I appreciate and am more proud of the traditional cultural values â€‹â€‹of Hue in particular and of Vietnam in general. If you come to Hue, visit this place to experience it!

KhÃ´ng Gian Nghá» Truyá»n Thá»‘ng Huáº¿  A Glimpse into Huáº¿â€™s Artisanal Soul

If you want to step beyond the usual tourist experience and witness the quiet mastery of Vietnamese craftsmanship, KhÃ´ng Gian Nghá» Truyá»n Thá»‘ng Huáº¿ is a must-visit. This place is a tribute to Huáº¿â€™s rich heritage of traditional handicrafts, where skilled artisans keep age-old techniques alive, weaving history into every delicate creation.

The highlight? The iconic nÃ³n lÃ¡ (Vietnamese conical hat), crafted entirely by hand. Watching the process is mesmerizing the meticulous layering of palm leaves, the precise stitching, and the final, artistic touch of hand-painted designs that turn each hat into a work of art. Itâ€™s slow, detailed work, requiring both patience and skill, a reminder of the dedication that goes into even the simplest objects in Vietnamese culture.

Beyond hats, the space showcases other traditional crafts, offering a glimpse into the artistry that defines Huáº¿. Whether itâ€™s embroidery, wood carving, or lacquerware, everything here reflects a deep respect for time-honored techniques.

If you appreciate craftsmanship, history, or just want a unique souvenir with real cultural value, this place is worth your time. Itâ€™s not just about buying something itâ€™s about understanding the hands and stories behind it.

Beautiful, worth experiencing Da Vien Bridge is one of the important bridges spanning the Perfume River, connecting the two banks of Hue city. With a modern design but still in harmony with the poetic landscape of the ancient capital, this bridge not only plays a traffic role but is also a notable architectural highlight.

Da Vien Bridge began construction in 2009 and was officially inaugurated on August 31, 2012. Initially, the bridge was called Bach Ho road bridge, but after consulting with the people, the People's Council of Thua Thien Hue province decided to change the name to Da Vien Bridge. This bridge is 542.5 meters long, 24.5 meters wide, with four lanes and two sidewalks for pedestrians. In particular, on the bridge there are six gazebos, where people and tourists can stop to admire the romantic Huong River view.

Aesthetically, Da Vien Bridge has a modern style but still retains elegance, consistent with the ancient beauty of Hue. When standing on the bridge, visitors can admire the panoramic view of the Perfume River, with dragon boats floating slowly, creating a beautiful natural picture. At night, the artistic lighting system on the bridge adds to the shimmering and magical look of this place.

Not only is it an important transportation project, Da Vien bridge also contributes to promoting tourism and the local economy. With its location near the city center, this bridge makes traveling between areas more convenient, while also creating conditions for cultural and tourist activities to develop strongly.

The Nine Dynastic Urns are one of the most unique treasures of the Nguyen Dynasty, currently located right in front of The Mieu Temple in the Hue Imperial City.

Origin: Cast by King Minh Mang in 1835, consisting of 9 large bronze urns symbolizing the sustainability and longevity of the dynasty.

Meaning: Each urn bears the name of a king from Gia Long to Minh Mang and is associated with symbolic images of nature and Vietnam such as mountains, rivers, seas, animals, plants, etc. Through that, the Nine Dynastic Urns both demonstrate the power of the dynasty and are a "visual history" depicting the beautiful country.

Architecture: Each urn weighs about 2,000 to 2,600 kg, cast from a solid block of bronze, placed on a green stone pedestal, exquisitely carved with nearly 162 images of landscapes, plants, animals, and artifacts associated with Vietnam.

â€¢ Location: The Nine Urns are placed in a horizontal row in front of Hien Lam Pavilion and The Mieu Temple, creating a solemn and majestic space.

ðŸ‘‰ The Nine Urns can be seen as a symbol of the national spirit, the wealth and stability of the country under the Nguyen Dynasty
Interesting visit

Standing proudly in front of the Tháº¿ Miáº¿u (Temple of Generations), these colossal bronze urns were cast in 1835 under Emperor Minh Máº¡ng. Inspired by Chinaâ€™s ancient Nine Tripod Cauldrons, they symbolise the Nguyá»…n Dynastyâ€™s power, unity, and Vietnamâ€™s rich heritage.

Seven of these are the largest and most elaborate, dedicated to the dynastyâ€™s most prominent emperors. Each one is a masterpiece â€” engraved with mountains, rivers, animals, and celestial symbols, telling the story of a nation in bronze.

Commissioned by Emperor Minh Máº¡ng and placed in front of the Tháº¿ Miáº¿u.
Each is named after the posthumous title of an emperor and decorated with 17â€“33 engraved motifs showing Vietnamâ€™s geography, fauna, flora, and celestial symbols.

Cao Äá»‰nh is the largest, representing the founder Gia Long, weighing over 2,600 kg.

Each urn is positioned in a specific order in front of the ancestral temple, symbolising a lineage of power.

The engravings act like a bronze encyclopaedia of 19th-century Vietnam â€” mapping its geography, recording its flora and fauna, and preserving cultural icons.

They have survived multiple wars, including the destruction of much of the Imperial City during the 20th century.

Each weighs up to 2,600 kg â€” a monument not just to emperors, but to an entire nationâ€™s history and resilience.

**The Nine Urns** is a set of nine large bronze urns placed in front of The Mieu Temple, in the Imperial City of Hue, considered one of the most precious treasures of the Nguyen Dynasty. The work was cast in 1835 under the reign of King Minh Mang, symbolizing the longevity, prosperity and authority of the dynasty. 

Each urn has its own name and represents a Nguyen king from Gia Long to Minh Mang, and is also associated with the image of the country. The nine urns include: Cao Dinh, Nhan Dinh, Chuong Dinh, Anh Dinh, Nghi Dinh, Thuan Dinh, Tuyen Dinh, Du Dinh and Huyen Dinh. On the body of each urn are hundreds of elaborate carvings depicting landscapes, products, flora and fauna, weapons... reflecting the richness of Vietnam at that time. 

In terms of size, the largest urn weighs more than 2 tons, the smallest is nearly 2 tons, all cast from a single block of bronze. The making of the Nine Urns demonstrates the outstanding bronze casting skills of Vietnamese craftsmen in the 19th century. 

Not only does it have artistic and technical value, **Nine Urns** is also a sacred symbol of royalty, expressing the nation's desire for unity and eternal sustainability. Today, it is a prominent tourist attraction in the complex of Hue Monuments, attracting a large number of tourists and history and culture lovers.

The Nine Dynastic Urns â€” a set of nine large bronze urns solemnly placed in front of the courtyard of The To Mieu, right behind Hien Lam Cac, inside the Hue Imperial Citadel. This is a cultural and power symbol of the Nguyen Dynasty, cast under King Minh Mang from late 1835 to early 1837 ï¿¼ ï¿¼ ï¿¼.

â¸»

ðŸ” Introduction & Meaning
â€¢ The Nine Tripods consist of 9 bronze urns, corresponding to the temple names of 9 Nguyen kings: Cao, Nhan, Chuong, Anh, Nghi, Thuan, Tuyen, Du and Huyen
â€¢ Each urn is ~2.3m high, weighs from 1.9 to 2.6 tons, with a total mass of nearly 22,000kg of bronze
â€¢ The set of works is a unique source of documents, never repaired, with historical, geographical, feng shui, artistic and calligraphic values, recognized by UNESCO as a Documentary Heritage, and is also a National Treasure of Vietnam

â¸»

Design & Outstanding Features
â€¢ Each bronze urn is embossed with 17 - 18 images, divided into 3 floors: mountains, rivers, creatures, tools, customs, weapons... all creating an "encyclopedia" representing the life and territory of Vietnam in the early 19th century
â€¢ The Cao Dinh is located in the center, protruding 3m ahead of the remaining eight urns, to honor King Gia Long - the founder of the Nguyen Dynasty
â€¢ The Nine Urns remain in their original position, never moved or restored, preserving the original character originally intended to be created in the 19th century

â¸»

Location & How to observe
â€¢ Located in front of the The To Mieu yard, behind the Hien Lam Cac gate, in the Hue Imperial Citadel complex
â€¢ The Nine Urns is a must-see stop when visiting The Mieu and the Imperial Citadel: not only to admire the art, but also to understand more deeply the symbol of power of the ancient Nguyen kings.

A must-visit place once in a lifetime when in Hue, go to know the history of the Nguyen Dynasty of Vietnam.

Park your car outside the campus, near the Nine Cannons (09 cannons, 04 cannons on one side symbolizing the 04 seasons, 05 cannons on the other side symbolizing the five elements), after the trapdoor, 2k/motorbike

Go through the Nine Cannons, follow the canal bank by the citadel to the ticket sales area, 200k/adult.

Once inside, there are 03 forms of sightseeing:
1. Walk, if you are tired enough to walk and rest, it will take about 3 hours to visit all 17 check-in points.
2. Rent a bicycle to ride on your own in the campus, the bike can only carry 01 person, there is no saddle to carry a second person or children.
3. Rent an electric car with a driver, 300k/car, maximum 07 adults, go around the main points.

The walk is quite wide, so you should bring an umbrella, hat, water. Inside the campus, there are many places selling food, drinks, and toilets.

The Nguyen Dynasty's Nine Tripods are nine bronze cauldrons, placed in front of the temple courtyard in the Imperial City, cast in 1835 - 1837 under the reign of Minh Mang. The Nine Tripods are important objects, treasures symbolizing the eternal stability of the imperial dynasty. 
The cauldrons have different sizes, 2.3m - 2.5m high, 4.64m - 4.72m in circumference. They weigh 1935kg - 2061kg. The pairs of handles on the mouth of the cauldrons are not the same, square, round, twisted like a rope. The cauldron legs are also different, some are bent like kneeling legs, some are cast straight... 
Each cauldron has a separate name corresponding to a posthumous title of each Nguyen Dynasty emperor. On each cauldron are carved 17 motifs and 1 calligraphy painting, including themes of the universe, mountains, rivers, birds, animals, products, weapons... 
The Nine Tripods are associated with the number 9, a sacred number according to Eastern beliefs. All types of scenery are selected and arranged according to the number 9.
After nearly 200 years, the nine urns have not changed their position, remaining intact until now.
162 panels on the nine urns are a skillful combination of Vietnamese bronze casting and embossing art, between folk culture and scholarship, an encyclopedia of nature and Vietnamese people's life in the first half of the 19th century.

The Nine Peaks are nine large bronze peaks, cast during the reign of King Minh Mang in 1835, symbolizing the strength, prosperity and authority of the Nguyen Dynasty. Each peak bears the name of an emperor, starting from Gia Long and ending at the ninth peak - Can Dinh. The peaks are arranged in a straight line in front of The Mieu - a place of worship for the Nguyen Dynasty kings in the Hue Imperial Citadel.

Each peak is about 2 meters high, weighing from 1,800 to more than 2,600 kg. The special thing is that on the body of each peak are carved images of symbols representing the country: from mountains, rivers, animals, plants to weapons and precious products of Vietnam. There are a total of 162 carvings, expressing the profound vision, love of nature and national spirit of the Vietnamese people.

The nine peaks include:

Cao Dinh - symbolizes King Gia Long
Nhan Dinh - symbolizes King Minh Mang
Chuong Dinh, Anh Dinh, Nghi Dinh, Thuan Dinh, Tuyen Dinh, Du Dinh, Can Dinh - corresponding to the next kings.
The Nine Peaks are not only a symbol of royalty, but are also considered a "visual encyclopedia" of Vietnamese nature and culture in the 19th century. The art of bronze casting, sculpting techniques and layout on each peak have all reached the highest level, demonstrating the outstanding development of royal art during the Nguyen Dynasty.

Currently, the Nine Peaks are still preserved intact and are an important highlight in the journey to discover the cultural heritage of Hue Ancient Capital.

The Nine Tripods were cast during the Minh Mang era (1835-1837) and placed in front of the Thien An Temple in the Hue Imperial City (built in the 19th century and dedicated to successive Nguyen Dynasty emperors), symbolizing the emperor's life. By order of Emperor Minh Mang, the Nine Tripods were named after the posthumous titles of successive Nguyen Dynasty emperors. They are Gao Ding, Ren Ding, Zhang Ding, Ying Ding, Nghi Ding, Chun Ding, Xuan Ding, Yu Ding, and Xuan Ding, representing the sacred artifacts that embody the nation's eternal prosperity and unification.

The nine bronze tripods are similar in shape. The one on the right side of the neck is dated "the end of the 16th year of Minh Mang" (1835) and completed "the beginning of the 18th year of Minh Mang" (1837). The weight of each tripod is recorded on the left side, ranging from 3201 jin to 4307 jin. The body of the tripod is meticulously carved with 162 inscriptions, including motifs from early 19th-century Vietnamese maps, such as the East Sea carved on Cao Dinh Island, the South Sea carved on Nhen Dinh Island, and the West Sea carved on Zhang Dinh Island.

China's Nine Tripods are said to have been first cast during the reign of Emperor Yu of Xia (circa 21st century BC) to symbolize the unification of the Nine Provinces. However, the actual objects have been lost, leaving only records describing their form. The tripod has long been a symbol of the Chinese nation's legitimacy (see the classic "Quest for the Tripod in the Central Plains"), symbolizing the Mandate of Heaven and the center of royal power, not the sole domain of any single individual. Archaeologically recovered bronze tripods are often treasured artifacts in ancestral temples, adorned with either Taotie motifs or inscriptions. They were displayed in the imperial chambers or offered in sacrificial offerings. By the Shang and Zhou dynasties, the use of tripods and vessels gradually became ritualistic, with some being buried as funerary objects in tombs. Their significance lay in demonstrating authority and connecting people with the gods.

The Nine Tripods of the Hue Imperial City in Vietnam are displayed in the grounds of the King Thame Shrine and are used as sacrificial vessels in Tu Duc Hall. These tripods are uniquely significant: each dedicated to a different emperor is inscribed with his posthumous title, highlighting his achievements and accomplishments, demonstrating both the legitimacy of the succession and the continuity of the royal legacy. Each of the nine tripods bears a prestigious name and is adorned with relief carvings reminiscent of cartographic narratives, resembling miniature versions of the Golden Ou. Their craftsmanship embodies the cultural essence of the Nguyen Dynasty of Vietnam, using the carvings of the mountains and rivers to proclaim the enduring strength of the territory and the spirit of the Vietnamese nation. They are precious instruments that uphold both political and cultural traditions.

The workshop where the tripods were cast is said to be located in PhÆ°á»ng ÄÃºc, a village on the southern shore of the Hong Kong River, about three miles from Hue City, on the roadside near the Gia Vien Bridge. This area is the source of copper art in central Vietnam, and only this village remains today. Its craftsmanship, inherited from ancient methods, has survived wars and destruction. This is not only a rare and extant document, but also a model for bronze casting in Hue and throughout Vietnam, demonstrating the exquisite craftsmanship of the Gia Long and Minh Mang eras. On May 8, 2024, at the 10th session of the UNESCO Memory of the World Asia-Pacific Committee, the Hue Palace Nine Tripods Archive was inscribed on the Memory of the World Asia-Pacific Register, a true testament to Vietnamese culture.

The Nine Urns were ordered to be cast by King Minh Mang in 1835 and completed in 1837. This is an indispensable part of the cultural heritage, as an eternal symbol of the Nguyen Dynasty. The Nine Urns have been recognized by UNESCO as a world documentary heritage, affirming its unique and rare value. The Nine Urns consists of nine bronze urns, each large in size and intricately carved with 153 different motifs, including 17 motifs on each urn like a bronze encyclopedia marking the beauty of the country in the 19th century, reflecting the diversity of nature and culture of Vietnam. The urns are round in shape, with a narrow neck, and decorated with symbolic images such as mountains, rivers, trees, and animals, creating a vivid picture of the country. Remember to download the Hue Monuments app to discover the meaning of each motif on each urn for a more interesting sightseeing experience.
Be sure to read the description of the designs on the urns.

The Nine Urns of the Nguyen Dynasty are nine bronze urns, placed in front of the The Mieu courtyard in the Hue Imperial Citadel. The Nine Urns were ordered to be cast by King Minh Mang in the winter of 1835 and inaugurated on March 1, 1837. King Minh Mang ordered the casting of the nine urns to symbolize the everlasting imperial career of the Nguyen Dynasty. The name of each urn is the posthumous name (name after death) of the Nguyen Dynasty kings:
Cao urns: posthumous name of King Gia Long
Nhan urns: posthumous name of King Minh Mang
Chuong urns: posthumous name of King Thieu Tri
Anh urns: posthumous name of King Tu Duc
Nghi urns: posthumous name of King Kien Phuc
Thuan urns: posthumous name of King Dong Khanh
Tuyen urns: posthumous name of King Khai Dinh
Du urns and Huyen urns: have not yet become the posthumous names of any king.
The Nine Urns are placed in front of Hien Lam Pavilion in a horizontal row, opposite The Mieu.

A special mention goes to the 9 urns, all different and rich in symbolic motifs representing Vietnam, which you should take the time to look at... full explanations are on panels at the top of the stairs.

Nine Tripod Cauldrons of Hue - Unique Cultural Wonder

The Nine Tripod Cauldrons of Hue are not just simple bronze cauldrons but also unique works of art, containing many profound meanings about Vietnamese history and culture?

Cast in the 19th century under the reign of King Minh Mang, the Nine Tripod Cauldrons are placed in the courtyard in front of The To Mieu, Hue Imperial City. Each cauldron has its own name and is decorated with sophisticated patterns, symbolizing the virtues of the people and the prosperity of the country.

Cá»­u Äá»‰nh(Nine Dynastic Urns) is a remarkable symbol in my heart ðŸ©·ðŸ©·ðŸ©·ðŸ©· and for the Nguyá»…n Dynasty, located in the courtyard of the Tháº¿ Miáº¿u(Temple of Generations) within the Imperial City of Huáº¿. These nine bronze urns were cast under the reign of Emperor Minh Máº¡ng in 1835 and are one of the most poetic, symbolic, and historically significant artifacts of the Nguyá»…n court. They are not only physical representations of the dynastyâ€™s power and longevity but also deeply woven into Vietnamese art, poetry, and historical narratives.

Poetry in Bronze:
The creation of Cá»­u Äá»‰nh is itself an act of artistry and imagination. Each urn represents one of the Nguyá»…n emperors and is adorned with intricately carved images reflecting various aspects of the empireâ€™s geography, culture, and natural beauty. The carvings depict mountains, rivers, animals, plants, and even historical battles, capturing the essence of the land the Nguyá»…n rulers governed. Each image has its own story, and together they form a detailed tapestry of Vietnamâ€™s landscape and heritage.

The poetic element of the Cá»­u Äá»‰nh is found not only in its visual design but also in its symbolism. In Confucian tradition, an urn or cauldron (Ä‘á»‰nh) is a powerful representation of authority and governance. The nine urns, standing tall and immovable, are metaphors for the unshakable rule of the dynasty and the emperorâ€™s deep connection to the land and its people. This sense of permanence and cultural richness has made them a recurring theme in poetry, literature, and art.

Inspiration for Art and Culture:
The Cá»­u Äá»‰nh has been immortalized in many forms of Vietnamese art, including poetry, painting, and music. Artists have long been inspired by the grandeur of these urns and the natural imagery they display. Poets often used them as a metaphor for the lasting legacy of the Nguyá»…n Dynasty, drawing connections between the power of nature and the resilience of the emperors who ruled Vietnam.

In traditional Vietnamese music, references to the Cá»­u Äá»‰nh evoke a sense of nostalgia and reverence for a bygone era. The peaceful and dignified presence of the urns in the heart of the Imperial City has been likened to the calm and wisdom of the emperors themselves, providing an emotional depth to many compositions.

Historical Significance:
Beyond their beauty, the Cá»­u Äá»‰nh also serve as historical documents, representing the Nguyá»…n Dynastyâ€™s efforts to record their reign and connect it to the vast history of Vietnam. Each urn is dedicated to one emperor, from Gia Long, the dynastyâ€™s founder, to later rulers. Together, they signify the lineage and continuity of the Nguyá»…n Dynasty, a dynasty that lasted over 140 years.

During the Nguyá»…n era, these urns were regarded as symbols of the empire's stability and prosperity. They were a statement of Vietnamâ€™s sovereignty, crafted during a time when the country was asserting its strength amidst both internal challenges and foreign influence.

Romantic Legacy in History and Art:
The Cá»­u Äá»‰nhcontinues to stir emotions not only as historical artifacts but as a living part of Vietnamâ€™s cultural identity. For many, the image of the nine majestic urns standing in serene silence within the Imperial Citadel serves as a powerful reminder of the fleeting nature of power, but also of the enduring nature of beauty and legacy. These urns are more than just physical relics; they embody the spirit of an era in Vietnamese history and the poetry that is drawn from the connection between ruler, land, and people.

Whether captured in a painting, referenced in a poem, or admired by visitors to Huáº¿, the Cá»­u Äá»‰nh has left an indelible mark on Vietnamese culture. It bridges the gap between the grandeur of the past and the contemplation of the present, embodying a poetic tranquility that has survived through the ages, making them not only a relic of a glorious dynasty but a continuing source of inspiration for generations to come.

One of the must-visit quarters within the Imperial Enclosure of the Hue Palace.

Emperor Minh Mang ordered the casting of these nine majestic bronze urns to commemorate the first nine emperors of the Nguyen Dynasty.  They were then cast between the years 1835 and 1837.

The one in the middle of the nine is the most ornate, as it commemorates the Founding Emperor of Nguyen Dynasty, Gia Long.  Each of the urn bears the posthumous title for the respective Emperor.  The Cao urn  of 1835 commemorating Gia Long has the name â€œCaoâ€ meaning height.  It weighs 2,604kg as the most prominent urn out of the nine.

As with many other features of the Imperial Enclosure, these nine urns are also testament to the Vietnamese royaltiesâ€™ respect of ancient China.  The existence of the nine urns certainly echoes the nine urns of the Xia, Shang and Zhou dynasties, which were the earliest Chinese dynasties (during the Bronze Age) in history.  During this time in the 19th Century, bronze was a particularly precious metal in Vietnam.

The three-storied structure right at the courtyard of the Nine Dynastic Urns is the Famous Soul Porch, (Hien Lam Cac), built in 1821.  At three stories this building is the tallest one within the Imperial Enclosure.  There was also an imperial order that it remains the tallest building in the Palace.

In the central courtyard, we can see Cuu Dong, nine funerary urns installed by Minh Mang in 1835.

The urns are made of bronze and stand over two meters tall. They are decorated with beautiful floral motifs and traditional symbols. They represent the nine emperors of Vietnam and were part of various ancestor worship ceremonies.

The Nine Urns (9 urns) are located in San The Mieu in the Imperial City. These nine urns were cast from late 1835 to early 1837 and were completed. On March 4, 1837, the royal court held a grand inauguration ceremony under the direct leadership of King Minh Mang.

The Nine Urns represent the dream of the eternal existence of the Nguyen Dynasty and the prosperity of the country. This is clearly shown in the naming as well as the size and embossed motifs on each urn.

The name of the Dinh is also the posthumous name of the King after his death and was worshiped at The Mieu: Cao Dinh ("Cao" is the temple name of King Gia Long) is placed in the middle, followed by Nhan Dinh ("Nhan" is the temple name of King Minh Mang), Chuong Dinh ("Chuong" is the temple name of King Thieu Tri), Anh Dinh ("Anh" is the temple name of King Tu Duc), Nghi Dinh ("Nghi" is the temple name of King Kien Phuc), Thuan Dinh ("Thuan" is the temple name of King Dong Khanh), Tuyen Dinh ("Tuyen" is the temple name of King Khai Dinh); and Du Dinh and Huyen Dinh had not yet symbolized any race when the August Revolution permanently abolished the Nguyen Dynasty. 

Nine urns were arranged in a horizontal row under the Hien Lam Cac threshold, each urn was placed on a large, very sturdy stone slab, located in order opposite the altars in The Mieu. Cao Dinh alone was placed 3m forward with the intention of honoring the great achievements of the first king of the dynasty.

The value of the Nine Dynastic Urns lies primarily in their large size and the sophisticated bronze casting skills of the craftsmen of Phuong Duc, Hue. The tallest is 2.5m, the shortest is 2.3m. <st1:place w:st="on">The waist circumference ranges from 4.64m to 4.72m. The heaviest weighs 2061kg, the lightest 1935kg. The pairs of handles on the mouth of the urns are not exactly the same, the square pair is cast, the round pair is cast, the twisted pair is rope-like. The legs of the urns are also different, some are bent in the style of kneeling legs, some are cast straight... 

In terms of art, each urns has 17 embossed images with themes of the sky, sea, mountains, rivers, birds, fish, flowers, fruits and weapons (famous landscapes and products of Vietnam). All 153 panels on the Nine Dynastic Urns are 153 independent, complete carvings, a skillful combination of bronze casting and embossing art in our country in the early 19th century.

The Nine Dynastic Urns are truly a rare cultural heritage, with multi-faceted value for Hue culture in particular and the whole country in general.

Ancient temple of Nguyen's dynasty.
The Nine Dynastic Urns is one of the most valuable works of art inÂ HueÂ in particular and inÂ VietnamÂ in general. The Dynastic Urns include 9 urns situated in the front of Hien Lam Pavilion, opposite The Mieu Temple and to the southwest of Hue Imperial City. The Nine Dynastic Urns was started its construction in December 1835 and completed in June 1837 under King Minh Mang. This artwork represents the unity and the beauty of the country as well as the sustainable and permanent existence of Nguyen Dynasty. The pictures selected to display on the 9 Urns could also regarded as a vivid encyclopedia of Vietnam country at that time. The Nine Dynastic Urns is one of the fascinating tourist attraction.
The Nine Dynastic Urns is one of the most outstanding artworks in tangible cultural treasures of Hue Citadel. The impressive aesthetic characteristics and the high technical qualifications have turned it into one of appealing tourist attractions in Hue.
The southwest corner ofÂ Hue CitadelÂ is a unique and attractive architectural ensemble mentioned as an indispensable Hue attraction - that is relic complex including Hien Lam Pavilion, The Mieu Temple and The Nine Dynastic Urns. These works are linked together on the architectural space and on the function in the harmonious landscape overall. Hien Lam Pavilion is the memorial built to remember Kings of Nguyen Dynasty. The Mieu Temple is home to worship Kings of Nguyen Dynasty. This is also the place the imperial court sacrificing the deceased Kings... Meanwhile, The Nine Dynastic Urns is a combination of 9 bronze urns placed horizontally below Hien Lam Pavilion's threshold corresponding 9 worshiping place in The Mieu Temple. Prominent among them, an urn is situated in the center, alone in the first row high up 3m high forward with implications for honoring the great contributions of the first King of the Dynasty (Emperor Gia Long).
The valve maintains and preserves 9 screws. These are objects that need to be preserved.

In the courtyard of the "To Mieu" temple, the 9 bronze funerary urns. Each bears the name of a highly honored emperor. Although they appear similar at first glance, they all differ in weight and size. Cao is logically the most imposing with its 2.50 m height, 1.38 m diameter and 2,602 kg. In fact, their dimensions represent the stability and permanence of the dynasty. The landscapes and picturesque sites of the different regions of the country engraved on their surface represent the unity of dynastic power. Each one features 17 traditional motifs such as stars, rivers, mountains, seas, ships, precious maritime or forest products of Vietnam... Cao carries the Vinh Te Canal, the Saigon River, the Mekong and the Perfume River, Nhan, the Perfume River and the imperial Mount Ngu... These nine dynastic urns are nothing more nor less than a veritable encyclopedia on the country and the people of Vietnam.

The nine urns had the names of the seven first emperors cast onto the body. The last two do not have names on them. The Nine Dynastic Urns are lined up under the terrace of Hien Lam Pavilion, in accordance with the altars in The Temple. Only the Cao Urn stands in the front of the others because Emperor Minh Mang believed Gia Long was the Emperor who had greatest contribution to the Nguyen Dynasty. Take time to notice the carvings of the seasons, mountains etc on these bronze works of art.

The Nine Urns are the most valuable bronze works of art in Hue in particular, and Vietnam in general. All were cast in Hue in late 1835, completed in early 1837, used as a symbol of the country's wealth, unity and the dream of a lasting dynasty. Each urn has a separate name engraved in Chinese characters, the name taken from the temple name (name for worship) of a Nguyen Dynasty king. And that urn is considered the symbol of that king. 
- Cao Dinh: King Gia Long - Nhan Dinh: King Minh Mang - Chuong Dinh: King Thieu Tri - Anh Dinh: King Tu Duc - Nghi Dinh: King Kien Phuc - Thuan Dinh: King Dong Khanh - Tuyen Dinh: King Khai Dinh. 
Du Dinh and Huyen Dinh do not represent any king, although in addition to the above mentioned kings, the Nguyen Dynasty had 6 other kings: Duc Duc, Hiep Hoa, Ham Nghi, Thanh Thai, Duy Tan, Bao Dai.

The Nine Urns is a set of 9 bronze urns, placed horizontally under the Hien Lam Pavilion, across the yard and corresponding to the 9 king worshiping rooms in The Mieu. Among them, there is 1 urn in the middle of the row, placed 3m higher with the meaning of honoring the great contributions of the first king of the dynasty (Gia Long). Each urn is engraved with a separate name, the "temple name" symbolizing each emperor who was worshiped at The Mieu after his death, such as: Cao Dinh - King Gia Long; Nhan Dinh - King Minh Mang; Chuong Dinh - King Thieu Tri; Anh Dinh - King Tu Duc; Nghi Dinh - King Kien Phuc; Thuan Dinh - King Dong Khanh; Tuyen Dinh - King Khai Dinh; Du Dinh and Huyen Dinh do not symbolize any king because the success of the August Revolution ended the feudal period of the Nguyen Dynasty, bringing our country into a new page of history.

The Nine Urns were ordered by King Minh Mang to be cast in the winter of 1835 and inaugurated on March 1, 1837, consisting of nine bronze urns, inspired by the Nine Urns of the Xia Dynasty in China, placed in front of the courtyard of The Mieu Temple in the Imperial City of Hue.

The Nine Urns are statues symbolizing the ruling power of the monarchy.

Each urn has a separate name corresponding to a posthumous name of each Nguyen Dynasty emperor, respectively: Cao urns, Nhan urns, Chuong urns, Anh urns, Nghi urns, Thuan urns, Tuyen urns, Du urns, Huyen urns.

The Cao urns correspond to the altar and shrine of King Nguyen The To (King Gia Long), placed in the middle of the Nine Urns and are the only urns moved forward 3 meters with the meaning of honoring the founding king of the dynasty.

In general, all nine urns have the same general shape: round, narrow neck, flared mouth, two handles on the mouth, three legs below the urns. On the neck of the cauldron, on the right side, the year of casting is inscribed as â€œMinh Mang 16th year At Muiâ€, which is the year 1835.

Each cauldron is carved with 17 motifs and 1 calligraphy, including themes of the universe, mountains and rivers, birds and animals, products, weapons, etc.

Emperor Minh Mang - the second Nguyen emperor - had these urns made to symbolize the might of the emperors and the nation in 1835-1837. Nine urns were named after the Nguyen emperors. Famous landscapes and produce were selected from different regions in the country to decorate these urns
The Lord casts the cauldron, the King casts the urn. How magnificent.

Nine Urns
The Nine Urns is the most valuable bronze work of art in Hue in particular, and Vietnam in general. All were cast in Hue in late 1835, completed in early 1837, used as a symbol of the country's wealth, unity and the dream of a lasting dynasty. Each urn has a separate name engraved in Chinese characters, the name taken from the temple name (name for worship) of a Nguyen Dynasty king. And that urn is considered the symbol of that king.
- Cao Dinh: King Gia Long
- Nhan Dinh: King Minh Mang
- Chuong Dinh: King Thieu Tri
- Anh Dinh: King Tu Duc
- Nghi Dinh: King Kien Phuc
- Thuan Dinh: King Dong Khanh
- Tuyen Dinh: King Khai Dinh
Du Dinh and Huyen Dinh do not represent any king, although in addition to the above mentioned kings, the Nguyen Dynasty also had 6 other kings: Duc Duc, Hiep Hoa, Ham Nghi, Thanh Thai, Duy Tan, Bao Dai.
The sizes and weights of the urns are not the same. Cao Dinh is 2.5m high and weighs 2601kg - it is the highest and heaviest urn. Huyen Dinh is 2.31m high and weighs 1935kg - it is the lowest and lightest urn. Around the side of each urn are carved 17 scenes. Thus, there are 153 scenes embossed on the Nine Urns. These are images of mountains, rivers, moons, stars, trees, flowers, animals, weapons, vehicles, boats, etc. We can see those 153 carvings as 153 paintings. We will see the Red River on Tuyen Dinh, the Mekong River on Huyen Dinh, and the Huong River on Nhan Dinh.

Nguyá»…n ÄÃ¬nh Chiá»ƒu Walking Street in Huáº¿ is a hidden gem that offers a delightful mix of local charm, culture, and relaxation right in the heart of the city. I spent an evening here during my recent trip to Huáº¿ and was absolutely enchanted by its peaceful ambiance and riverside beauty.

Stretching along the Perfume River, this walking street is smaller and more intimate than some of the more commercial pedestrian streets in Vietnam, but thatâ€™s exactly what makes it special. Itâ€™s clean, well-maintained, and has a uniquely calm and romantic atmosphere â€” especially around sunset, when the sky turns golden and reflects off the water.

What I appreciated most was the blend of local life and gentle tourism. Youâ€™ll find local families taking walks, street performers playing traditional Vietnamese instruments, and small stalls selling art, souvenirs, and light snacks. There are also several charming cafÃ©s and teahouses where you can sit and enjoy the view while sipping a cold drink or Vietnamese coffee.

The street is beautifully lit in the evening, with colorful lanterns and tasteful lighting that enhances the cozy and poetic feel. Itâ€™s the perfect place to take a leisurely stroll, unwind after a day of sightseeing, or just people-watch and feel the rhythm of Huáº¿.

If youâ€™re visiting Huáº¿, donâ€™t miss this spot. Nguyá»…n ÄÃ¬nh Chiá»ƒu Walking Street is the kind of place that doesnâ€™t try too hard â€” it simply lets Huáº¿â€™s gentle soul speak for itself. Five stars without a doubt.

Located along the southern bank of the Perfume River, it stretches from Phu Xuan Bridge to Truong Tien Bridge and opens daily from late afternoon into the evening. As the sun sets, the area comes alive with street vendors selling snacks, drinks, and handcrafted souvenirs. The LED-lit bridges and river breeze create a peaceful backdrop for strolling, people-watching, or catching impromptu street performances.

The street is compact but full of characterâ€”ideal for a short walk or a casual night out. Itâ€™s pedestrian-only, making it safe and quiet compared to busier city zones. Locals gather for music, games, and evening hangouts, while visitors enjoy the mix of food stalls, art displays, and photo spots. Itâ€™s not a major shopping hub, but itâ€™s a great place to soak in Hueâ€™s laid-back nightlife and riverside charm.

Nguyen Dinh Chieu Walking Street is one of the most vibrant and bustling destinations in Hue, especially in the evening. Located along the banks of the poetic Huong River, this street is not only a gathering place for local people but also attracts tourists from all over to visit, have fun and experience Hue culture. 

With an open walking space, Nguyen Dinh Chieu Street brings a relaxing, pleasant atmosphere, ideal for entertainment and walking activities. Along both sides of the street are a series of eateries, souvenir shops, and stops to enjoy Hue street food. You can easily find specialties such as banh beo, banh nam, bun bo Hue, and many other snacks.

Hien Lam Cac is a special architectural work located in the The Mieu area of Hue Imperial City, part of the Complex of Hue Monuments - World Cultural Heritage.

â¸»

ðŸ” Main information about Hien Lam Cac:
â€¢ ðŸ“ Location: Located in front of The To Mieu, in the Hue Imperial City area.
â€¢ ðŸ›ï¸ Function:
â€¢ Built in 1821 under the reign of King Minh Mang,
â€¢ A memorial to honor the meritorious mandarins, civil and military mandarins and kings of the Nguyen Dynasty.
â€¢ A place to offer incense and commemorate ancestors who have contributed to the country and the court.
â€¢ ðŸ—ï¸ Architecture:
â€¢ The tallest 3-storey wooden building in the Imperial City (about 17m high),
â€¢ Considered the maximum height limit in the Imperial City - no building is allowed to be higher to maintain its solemnity.
â€¢ The floors are covered with glazed tiles, intricately carved with dragons, phoenixes, and royal motifs.

â¸»

ðŸ”¸ Meaning of the name â€œHien Lam Cacâ€:
â€¢ â€œHienâ€ means glory, â€œLamâ€ means forest â€“ that is, the forest of talented people and famous officials.
â€¢ The name shows respect and gratitude for the great achievements of our ancestors.
Great

Hien Lam Cac was built in 1821, considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings. 
is a 3-storey wooden building with harmonious proportions on a high foundation. 
The first floor has 3 rooms, 2 wings, and three brick exteriors. Above the middle door hangs a large horizontal lacquered board with three words "Hien Lam Cac", a frame carved with 9 dragons playing with clouds, painted red and gilded. 
The second floor has 3 rooms, the front and back sides are built with shutter doors, and the outside is a meticulously crafted wooden railing system. 
The third floor has 1 room, the front and back sides are built with shutter doors. The roof is covered with yellow glazed tiles, and in the middle of the top is a wine gourd made of yellow enamel placed on a five-color cloud table. 
Hien Lam Cac is sturdy thanks to 24 wooden pillars, 4 of which are 3-storey high, serving as the backbone of the building. The triple-link systems, panels, and rafters are embossed with stylized dragon motifs. 
Hien Lam Pavilion is one of the few buildings in the imperial citadel that survived the war.

Hien Lam Cac was built from 1821 to 1822 under the reign of King Minh Mang, to honor the founding fathers of the Nguyen Dynasty. This work not only has architectural value but is also an important memorial in Vietnamese history. Hien Lam Cac is 17m high, the tallest building in the Hue Imperial Citadel area. Its architecture is designed with high-rise wood, with a rectangular high ground, paved with Bat Trang tiles. The work is divided into three floors, each floor has its own beauty and artistic value. The first floor stands out with sophisticated sculptures, while the second and third floors bring a solemn and peaceful space.

Hien Lam Cac is an architectural work located right in front of The Mieu inside the grounds of Hue Imperial City, built together with The Mieu (1821-1822 under King Minh Mang). This work is considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings worshiped at The Mieu and the mandarins who had merit worshiped at the two houses Ta Tung Tu and Huu Tung Tu.

Hien Lam The 3-storey architectural works have high aesthetic value, built mainly of wood on a high rectangular foundation, the floor is paved with Bat Trang bricks, built with bricks, lime mortar and embossed ceramic pieces for decoration. From the yard, step up to the ground by two systems of stone steps in the front and back, each system has 9 steps. The two sides of the steps are carved with dragon shapes in the middle, which is the limit of the path reserved for the King.
Very well maintained
Lovely well restored place to visit.

This structure is the tallest in the Imperial City and also the tallest in the Capital. According to construction law, no structure in the Capital is allowed to be higher than Hien Lam Cac. Thanks to that, the Capital still has open space and maintains the solemnity of the Imperial City.

At 17 meters, it is the tallest structure in the Citadel. It has three floors, and the emperor prohibited any building in the citadel from exceeding the height of Hiá»ƒn LÃ¢m CÃ¡c.
It was built in 1821 by Emperor Minh Mang to honor all those who made the Nguyen dynasty reach its greatest splendor.
It has a pyramidal shape. The ground floor is built of stone and consists of five rooms. The second floor is built of wood and consists of three rooms. The upper floor is also built of wood and consists of a single room.
Inside, we find an exhibition with information about the site and magnificent views of the central courtyard.

This place attracts tourists inside the Hue Imperial City.

Hien Lam Cac - an ancient architectural work located inside the grounds of the Hue Imperial City. This relic was built in 1821 and is one of the places with important historical significance during the reign of King Minh Mang.

In the itinerary to explore the Hue tourist map, Hien Lam Cac is an extremely interesting destination that should not be missed. With a prime location near the shrine area with a height of more than 17m, Hien Lam Cac is considered one of the tallest and most beautiful works in the Imperial City.

Hien Lam Cac is located inside the Hue Citadel, located on Hai Muoi Ba Thang Tam Street, Thuan Thanh Ward, Hue City. This work is a monument commemorating the contributions of the Nguyen Dynasty kings and mandarins who were loyal and built a prosperous country.

Ancient Hue Hien Lam Cac architecture, unique beauty
The Hien Lam Cac is made of high-quality wood, 3-storey high architecture, built on a rectangular ground, the entire floor is paved with Bat Trang tiles. From the front yard moving up to the ground, visitors will have to go through a system of stone steps in the front and back, each side has 9 steps. The steps are shaped like dragons, the middle path is reserved for the king.

In the third row of columns from the front, a row of panels is erected, between each room is an arched door. The types of rafters, triple-layer panels, panels on this floor are all carved with super impressive flying dragons. Above the main entrance is a large horizontal lacquered board with three Chinese characters "Hien Lam Cac", the frame is carved with 9 dragons painted in red and gilded.

Entering Hien Lam Cac, on the right side there is a staircase to the 2nd floor, the railing is divided into decorative compartments in the shape of "thá»•" and "váº¡n" characters with geometric lines carved with dragons at the beginning and end. 

Above the 2nd floor there are three compartments with the front and back of the shutter doors, surrounded by rows of meticulously crafted balusters. Supporting the roof truss of this floor are 4 main columns, 4 secondary columns, and a system of beautifully carved balusters. 

The top 3rd floor has only 1 compartment with the way up being a wooden staircase with 9 steps.

HIEN LAM CAC was built at the same time as The Mieu (1821 - 1822 - under King Minh Mang), located right in front of The Mieu. This is a project considered a memorial to commemorate the achievements of the Nguyen Dynasty kings worshiped at The Mieu and the mandarins who had merit worshiped at the two houses Ta Tung Tu and Huu Tung Tu.

Hien Lam Cac is a 3-storey wooden architectural work, built on a high rectangular foundation, paved with Bat Trang bricks, built with bricks, lime mortar and embossed ceramic pieces for decoration. From the yard, step up to the ground by two systems of stone steps in the front and back, each system has 9 steps. The two sides of the steps are decorated with dragons in the middle, which is the limit of the path reserved for the King. The first floor is divided into three rooms and two wings, around the three outer sides of the two wings are brick walls to reinforce the bearing capacity of the columns and cover the interior. On the third row of columns from the front, a row of panels is erected, with an arched door in the middle of each room. The truss system, triple-layer panels, and panels on this floor are all embossed with stylized dragon motifs transformed into leafy vines. On the middle door hangs a large horizontal lacquered board with the three words "Hien Lam Cac" on a green background, with a frame carved with 9 dragons playing with clouds painted in red and gilded.

Hai Ba Trung Walking Street in Hue is a new and vibrant destination, attracting many tourists and locals. With a length of 850m, the street is designed in a modern style, paved with neat stone and has a green tree system to create shade. Operating from 6pm to 12am on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, this place becomes an ideal space for nightlife and entertainment activities. Visitors can enjoy a variety of cuisines from street food to Hue specialties at stalls and restaurants along the street. Street art activities such as music performances, dancing and handicraft displays take place regularly, creating a bustling and attractive atmosphere. The walking street is also close to other famous attractions in Hue, convenient for combining in a journey to explore the city. Security is guaranteed with the presence of functional forces, helping visitors feel secure to enjoy the entertainment space. This is truly a must-see destination when coming to Hue, offering unique cultural and entertainment experiences.

Le Loi Park in Hue, is actually a 3-2 park located along the Perfume River on Le Loi Street - one of the most beautiful and historical streets of the ancient capital. This is an ideal space to relax and experience culture and nature with local people. 

---

ðŸ“ Location & general information

Address: Le Loi Street, Phu Hoi Ward, Hue City, Thua Thien Hue

Opening hours & entrance fee: open 24/7, free

Length: nearly 1km along the south bank of the Perfume River

---

ðŸŒ³ Natural & artistic space

Covered with green trees, many stone benches, beautiful flowers and leaves, fresh air - very suitable for walking, jogging, light exercise in the early morning or late afternoon.

In addition to ancient trees and colorful flowers, the park also displays stone statues and sculptures with Hue cultural nuances, serving check-in and outdoor art learning. 

---

ðŸŽ­ Community & cultural activities

Hue people: often exercise such as walking, running, and yoga in the morning, while in the evening, young people organize art performances, volleyball, and picnics. 

Events & festivals: places where public activities, festivals, outdoor exhibitions and cultural activities such as kite flying, concerts, especially during the Hue Festival take place. 

---

ðŸ›ï¸ Nearby monuments & attractions

On the banks of the Perfume River, opposite the park is Le Loi boat station, the departure point for dragon boats and river cruises, enjoying Hue folk songs, and enjoying afternoon tea on the river. 

Nearby, there are also light cafe & restaurant routes such as Le Parfum, Windows CafÃ©, Park View Restaurant - making it easy for you to combine a rest after a walk. 

Near: Truong Tien Bridge, Imperial Citadel, Royal Fine Arts Museum, Thien Mu Pagoda... convenient for your journey to explore Hue. 

---

ðŸ“ Notes & suggestions for experiences

Ideal time: early morning or late afternoon - avoid the hot noon. 

Bring water, hats or sun umbrellas - although there is a lot of shade, it is still quite hot at noon and summer. 

Try the experience: join the morning health class, listen to Hue folk songs on the boat in the afternoon, or picnic, take photos at the statue, observatory, small stage.

Located in the heart of Hue city, Hue ironwood bridge (or Hue walking bridge) is located on the southern bank of the poetic Huong River and lies between Truong Tien Bridge and the famous Phu Xuan Bridge of Hue. If you do not know, this bridge is an architectural work symbolizing the friendship between Vietnam and Korea, fully sponsored by KOICA with an investment capital of 6 million USD and completed in November 2018. By 2019, Hue ironwood bridge was officially put into operation to serve the community. 

In addition, Hue ironwood bridge is also a point to extend the walking route on the Huong River starting from Nguyen Dinh Chieu Walking Street to Ly Tu Trong Park. Hue ironwood bridge is nearly 400 m long - 4 m wide, a combination of brown wood and copper yellow, extremely interesting and unique. The bridge is made of 100% imported high-quality ironwood from South Africa, so it is extremely moisture-resistant and strong. In addition, the ironwood bridge has a railing system made of 4,100 beautiful golden-colored copper bars imported from Korea, weighing more than 7 tons, creating interesting highlights as well as providing a solid structure for the bridge. In particular, this bridge is also equipped with a waterproof electrical and lighting system, so even if it is submerged in water 4 meters deep, the bridge will still operate normally.

Hue Lim Wood Bridge - A new gem in the heart of the ancient capital

Located on the romantic Perfume River, Lim Wood Bridge quickly became a destination attracting tourists because of its modern beauty blending with the ancient features of the ancient capital of Hue. This place is not only a traffic bridge but also a cultural space, an ideal tourist destination for visitors to see beautiful scenery and experience the unique culture of Hue.

Lim Wood Bridge is designed with modern architecture, using rare iron wood materials, creating luxury and sustainability. The bridge railing is designed with soft curves, combined with a sparkling lighting system, creating a romantic and attractive scene in the evening.

Lim Wood Bridge is considered one of the most beautiful places to watch the sunset in Hue. When sunset falls, the Hue sky is dyed a brilliant orange-yellow color, beautifying the river scene more poetically. Visitors can watch the last rays of sunlight sparkling on the water, creating a beautiful natural picture.

Lim Wood Bridge is not only a simple bridge but also a cultural space, where many cultural, artistic and community activities take place. Visitors here can participate in traditional festivals, enjoy art performances, or simply walk on the bridge, enjoy the fresh air and admire the beautiful scenery of the Perfume River.

Ideal check-in location: With its unique design and poetic scenery, Lim Wood Bridge quickly becomes an ideal check-in location for tourists. Visitors can save beautiful moments with relatives and friends here.

Lim Wood Bridge is an emerging destination in Hue, promising to bring visitors interesting and unforgettable experiences. With modern beauty blending with the ancient features of the ancient capital, Lim Wood Bridge is a new gem that adds brilliance to the picture of Hue tourism.

Note:

- Tourists should come to Lim Wood Bridge in the afternoon to see the most beautiful sunset.
- You should bring hats, hats, and sunscreen if you come here at noon
- Maintain general hygiene and do not litter.

Located on the poetic Huong River, the Lim Wood Pedestrian Bridge is one of the famous and favorite destinations in Hue, Vietnam. With its unique beauty and sparkling lighting system, this bridge is not only a unique architectural work, but also a great place to sightsee and relax. 

The choice of using lim wood is not only for aesthetics, but also shows respect and connection with the traditional values of local culture. Lim wood is not only beautiful, but also very durable, contributing to ensuring the safety and long-term durability of the project. 

The Lim Wood Pedestrian Bridge has a simple but sophisticated design, with curved lines and in harmony with the surrounding landscape. The structure of the bridge is designed with interwoven lim wood bars, creating a flexible and sturdy network. 

The length of the bridge is about 400 meters, with a width of about 4 meters. The two sides of the bridge are surrounded by wooden railings, creating a sense of safety and comfort for users. 

In particular, the bridge is designed with soft curves, helping to create a harmonious and beautiful look with the Huong River below. At night, the shimmering RGB lighting system on the bridge further enhances the magical beauty of the project. 

The RGB lighting system on the Lim Wood Walking Bridge is one of the special highlights of this project. RGB LED lights are installed along the bridge body, creating an extremely impressive and sparkling lighting effect. 

Choosing to use the RGB lighting system on the Lim Wood Walking Bridge not only helps to increase the beauty and aesthetics of the project, but also brings many other practical benefits. 

Walking on the Lim Wood Walking Bridge, visitors can enjoy a relaxing and quiet space. With the gentle sound of waves, cool breezes and beautiful natural landscapes, this bridge becomes an ideal place to rest, exercise or simply enjoy the scenery. 

Many visitors like to stop on the bridge, enjoy a cup of coffee or ice cream, or sit on the stone benches along both sides of the bridge to enjoy the scenery. This is a peaceful space, helping visitors escape the noise and stress of daily life. 

Especially in the evening when the RGB lighting system is turned on, the bridge becomes even more sparkling and magical. Visitors can enjoy this romantic space, take souvenir photos or simply watch and relax. 

With the surrounding wonderful natural beauty, the sparkling RGB lighting system and rich entertainment activities, the bridge has become an attractive destination for visitors when visiting Hue. Hopefully this article has provided you with an overview of the Lim Wood Walking Bridge and provided useful information for your trip. We wish you an enjoyable and meaningful experience while exploring this destination!

As I walked through the streets of Hue with a 50,000 dong banknote in hand, I never imagined I'd find a place where I could see the exact same view depicted on the note. I found it south of the Flag Tower, facing the Huong River.

The building in the foreground depicted on the note is Chi Man Lou, Nguyen Luong Dien in the background, and the Imperial Ping Phong Mountain towering in the background. When I saw the scene before my eyes and compared it to the note, it was exactly the same. I was so moved that I stared at it for a while.

According to the explanation, Chi Man Lou was once a place where decrees of the Nguyen Dynasty and the results of the imperial examinations were announced to the public. Nguyen Luong Dien was a building where the emperor used to cool off, and Imperial Ping Phong Mountain is a mountain that is said to attract good energy to Hue according to feng shui. Learning the significance of each building and mountain made me realize that it's not just beautiful scenery, but is deeply connected to the history of the dynasty and the lives of its people, making it even more fascinating.

If you visit Hue, why not bring along a 50,000 dong banknote and stand at the Shih Man Tower? Comparing it with the banknote will surely be an unforgettable experience.

Phu Van Lau is a famous ancient architectural work located on the southern bank of the Perfume River, right in front of the Flag Tower of Hue Citadel. This is where the Nguyen Dynasty used to post important edicts of the king, announce the results of the Royal Examinations, or announce major events to the people. 

Phu Van Lau was built in 1819 under the reign of King Gia Long, and was renovated many times by the following kings. The work has a two-storey structure, roofed with royal tiles, with elegant architecture, imbued with the style of the Hue royal court. The lower floor is a high platform, open on all four sides, creating a wide view; the upper floor is a square four-roofed building, with softly curved roof corners, and gilded wooden pillars. 

Not only having administrative and informational value in the feudal period, Phu Van Lau is also a cultural symbol of the ancient capital. This place has witnessed many important events, reflecting the political and social life of the Nguyen Dynasty. 

Today, Phu Van Lau is still preserved as an important historical relic, located in the complex of Hue Monuments recognized by UNESCO. With its beautiful location and sophisticated architecture, this is an ideal stop for tourists when visiting the Le Duan - Nguyen Dinh Chieu axis along the poetic Huong River.
This place is outside the Imperial City. If you are diligent, you can walk out to take pictures. The pictures are very beautiful.

Standing from the opposite side near the river bank is the angle to see the whole front of this construction. On weekdays, there are also many tourists visiting, perhaps only in the afternoon or early morning when it is quiet.

ðŸ›ï¸ 1. Location and role

Location: Located right in front of the Flag Tower and Ngo Mon Gate, facing the Perfume River (Phu Hoa Ward, Hue City).

The project is located in the axis of Thai Hoa Palace â†’ Ngo Mon Gate â†’ Flag Tower â†’ Phu Van Lau â†’ Nghenh Luong Dinh â†’ Perfume River â†’ Ngu Binh.

---

ðŸ—ï¸ 2. History and function

1. In 1819, under King Gia Long, the old Bang Dinh was upgraded to a 2-storey building, called Phu Van Lau, used to post royal decrees, edicts, and results of the Hoi and Dinh examinations.

2. In 1829, King Minh Mang organized an elephant-tiger fight in front of the building, a 3-day birthday celebration in 1830, and other celebrations.

3. It is also a place for infantry and cavalry parades and naval review on the Perfume River.

4. Under the reigns of Minh Mang, Thieu Tri, and Tu Duc, the tradition of reading royal edicts here was maintained - officials and elders came to kneel and pay their respects.

5. The building has undergone several restorations (in 1904, it was damaged by a storm and had to be cut and reconnected; 1993â€“1995 was the most recent major restoration).

---

ðŸ§± 3. Architecture & decoration

Two floors, 16 ironwood columns, double roof covered with yellow glazed tiles.

The ground floor is airy, with a railing ~65cm high, usually left empty when not listed.

The upper floor has four sides with wooden panels, the main side is a square window, the two sides are "yin-yang" windows, the wooden railing is beautifully and elaborately carved.

The stone stele on both sides of the building is engraved with â€œå‚¾è“‹ä¸‹é¦¬â€ (Khuynh cÃ¡i háº¡ mÃ£): anyone passing here must â€œtilt their hat and get off their horseâ€ to show respect.

In front of the building are two small bronze cannons facing each other.

---

ðŸŒ¿ 4. Cultural and tourism values

Cultural symbol: the mark of the Nguyen Dynasty royal style, the place to issue national edicts, post examinations, and organize court ceremonies.

Artistic architecture: the harmony between lim wood - glazed tile roof - decorative art creates an elegant, ancient look.

Printed on the 50,000 VND polymer banknote, this is a familiar image certifying historical and cultural values.

An ideal tourist destination to watch the Perfume River, take photos at dawn, dusk and moonlight nights next to the heritage.

---

ðŸ—ºï¸ 5. Time & Notes for Visiting

Suitable time: Early morning, sunset or late afternoon to enjoy the quiet space, take pictures of poetic scenery.

Renovation history: Preserving the traditional shape of ironwood and glazed tiles, the renovations do not lose the ancient quality.

Tourism value: An indispensable part when visiting the ancient capital of Hue; convenient routes such as from Truong Tien bridge, Le Duan street.

Phu Van Lau is an iconic architectural work of the ancient capital of Hue, located right in front of the Flag Tower and opposite Nghinh Luong Dinh, on the banks of the poetic Huong River. Built in 1819 under the reign of King Gia Long and completed under the reign of King Minh Mang, Phu Van Lau was once the place where the Nguyen Dynasty court posted important edicts, golden plaques honoring successful doctors and held ceremonies of ceremonial, cultural or military significance. With a two-storey architecture, nearly 12m high, each side is more than 11m wide, the work is built of precious ironwood, roofed with royal glazed tiles, demonstrating the solemnity and grandeur of the feudal monarchy. The lower floor of the building has no walls, creating an airy space; the upper floor has square and round windows symbolizing the harmony of yin and yang. In front of Phu Van Lau are two stone steles engraved with the words "Khuynh cai ha ma", requiring passersby to tilt their hats and dismount as a sign of respect for the court. Over the past two centuries with many historical events and natural disasters, Phu Van Lau has been restored many times to preserve the original architecture. The building not only has historical and cultural value but is also a symbol of the tradition of studiousness, honoring the intelligence and culture of Vietnam. Today, Phu Van Lau is a prominent tourist attraction of the Complex of Hue Monuments, recognized by UNESCO as a World Cultural Heritage, and is also printed on the 50,000 VND polymer banknote of Vietnam.

Phu Van Lau is a famous symbolic structure of Hue, located right on the banks of the Perfume River, in front of Ky Dai and Ngo Mon. I came here on a sunny morning, the air was very pleasant, the wind from the river blew coolly, looking at the whole scene I saw an ancient, peaceful scene true to the ancient capital. Phu Van Lau was built in 1819 under Gia Long's reign, initially as a place to post the king's edicts and orders, and later became a highlight with special historical and cultural value.

The building has delicate and elegant architecture, with two floors of glass-tiled roofs, eight ironwood columns supporting the roof, and the surrounding area open to all four sides. I really like the simplicity and elegance of Phu Van Lau, not too massive but majestic, reminiscent of a golden age. Standing from here, I can see the Perfume River, Ky Dai, and in the distance Truong Tien Bridge, all blending into a picture of Hue.

If you have the opportunity to come to Hue, I recommend stopping by Phu Van Lau to feel the nostalgic space, take some souvenir photos, or simply sit quietly watching the flow of people passing by, listening to the temple bells ringing in the distance. A simple experience but leaves many unforgettable aftertaste.

Phu Van Lau is a building located on the main axis of Hue Imperial Citadel: Thai Hoa Palace - Ngo Mon Gate - Ky Dai - Phu Van Lau - Nghinh Luong Dinh - Huong Giang - Ngu Binh. 
Phu Van Lau is 11.67m high, with a roof covered with yellow glazed tube tiles, with 16 dark red columns, a system of railings around it, the lower floor is left empty. The second floor has four sides with panels, silk-framed style, round windows on both sides, wooden railings on the outside, on the front windows hang gilded red-lacquered horizontal lacquered boards, decorated with stylized "two dragons worshipping the moon" vine. 
In 1974, during the renovation, some wooden structures, columns, rafters, and crossbeams were replaced with reinforced concrete. 
Phu Van Lau was built by order of King Gia Long. Initially, it was a small building called Bang Dinh, used as a place to announce royal edicts, royal decrees or golden boards announcing the results of the royal examinations and royal examinations. 
In 1819, the communal house was replaced by Phu Van Lau, which was a place to issue calendars or organize recreational activities for the people...
On both sides of the front of Phu Van Lau, there were two small bronze cannons facing each other.
In front of Phu Van Lau was a small pavilion located next to the Huong River called Nghinh Luong Dinh.
On the bank of Huong River opposite Phu Van Lau, there was Phu Van Lau Wharf (Van Lau Wharf).
Although Phu Van Lau had been renovated many times, it still retained the typical architectural style of the Nguyen Dynasty, a beautiful work of art of the Nguyen Dynasty, a unique heritage in the architectural complex of the ancient capital.

These fortified defensive structures are called bunkers, built mainly of concrete and brick, with a simple but sturdy design, to withstand attacks and protect troops during the resistance war against the French. The architecture of bunkers is usually rectangular or square, with entrances designed discreetly to avoid enemy detection. Inside, the space is quite limited, only enough for a few soldiers to shelter and carry out combat activities. Many artifacts have been found in these bunkers, including weapons, ammunition and military living utensils. The bunkers on Vong Canh hill are also associated with many interesting folk stories. One of the prominent stories is about a soldier who died here, said to have become a spirit to protect this area. Local people often recall that on moonlit nights, the soldiers' whispers can be heard, as a reminder of the nation's painful but also proud past. This is a unique architectural work, when walking around Vong Canh hill, remember not to miss this important historical relic area.

Vong Canh Hill in Van Nien area. During the reign of King Tu Duc, it was chosen as a place to view the Perfume River (or since the reign of King Thieu Tri?) and has gradually changed.
The hill area has been cleared and widened, the pine trees are also taller and denser, making the hill's scenery cool even in the hot noon, but also partially covering the river view, and somewhat covering the main purpose of the hill's name: Vong Canh.
I don't know which direction the hill will face in the future! To create Vong Canh, it should create a more open space, so that you can see further from the hill; or to make a park, there should be many places to rest, entertain... and lose the meaning of Vong Canh.

I just had a very interesting experience at An Dinh Palace and want to share it with everyone. Built in the early 20th century, this palace not only has a special architectural beauty but also contains interesting historical stories. 

The first impression of this place is its splendid appearance, not inferior to any mansion in Europe. The architecture has a neoclassical style mixed with a bit of Asian style, making me feel like I have gone back in time to the prosperous period of the Nguyen Dynasty. The decorative details are very sophisticated, from the sculptures to the patterns on the walls. The interior is equally impressive, with galleries and living spaces that satisfy both aesthetics and history. 

One thing I feel a bit regretful about is that the number of visitors is quite large on weekends, so sometimes it feels a bit crowded. However, this does not reduce the attractiveness of An Dinh Palace. If possible, you should choose a mid-week visit, you will certainly have the opportunity to enjoy the space more fully.

Along the way to the palace, the green landscape with rows of ancient trees makes me feel comfortable and want to spend more time here. Overall, this is a pretty good destination for those who love to explore historical architecture and want to learn more about Hue culture. It is worth visiting at least once.

AN DINH PALACE

If you have the opportunity to visit Hue, do not miss An Dinh Palace, a beautiful architectural work of the Nguyen Dynasty, where the antiquity and sophistication in every detail will captivate you at first sight.

An Dinh Palace was built in the early 20th century under King Khai Dinh, as the residence of the royal family, especially King Khai Dinh and King Bao Dai after his abdication. This work bears the mark of Asian-European cultural exchange, expressed through sophisticated architecture with a combination of Western classical elements and Vietnamese traditions.

The highlight of An Dinh Palace is Khai Tuong Palace, a 3-storey building with elaborately carved walls, meticulous paintings and a space filled with light through stained glass windows. This was once a place where photography was completely prohibited, but now, after many renovations, you can freely visit and capture impressive moments here.

The vast grounds of An Dinh Palace, surrounded by trees and colorful flower beds, create a peaceful space, completely separate from the modern life outside. In addition to Khai Tuong Palace, you can learn more about the history of the Nguyen Dynasty through other areas such as the crescent lake, the main gate with its artistic architecture, or the remaining relics. 

ðŸ“ Address: 179 Phan Dinh Phung, Phu Nhuan Ward, Hue City. 
â° Opening hours: 7:30 am - 5:30 pm daily. 
ðŸ’¸ Entrance fee: About 50,000 VND/person.
