This palace has a unique blend of Asian and European architecture, marking the history of the Nguyen Dynasty over a century. Built in 1902 under King Thanh Thai, An Dinh Palace was originally the private residence of King Khai Dinh. In 1917, the king renovated the palace in a modern style, completed in 1919, creating a masterpiece of neoclassical architecture. The palace was then transferred to Crown Prince Vinh Thuy (King Bao Dai) in 1922. This was also where King Bao Dai's family lived after the August Revolution in 1945, before Lady Tu Cung donated the palace to the revolutionary government. Recognized by UNESCO as a World Cultural Heritage, An Dinh Palace is not only an architectural work but also a witness to the ups and downs of Vietnamese history, associated with figures such as King Khai Dinh, King Bao Dai and Queen Nam Phuong. Truly overwhelmed by the subtle blend of modern Roman style and traditional Vietnamese motifs. From the outside, the main gate is two stories, decorated with embossed porcelain and glass, appearing splendid with dragons, phoenixes and sophisticated patterns. Trung Lap Communal House has an octagonal structure and an ancient roof. The most prominent is Khai Tuong Tower, a three-story building with an elaborately carved facade, combining oriental motifs such as the four sacred animals, the eight treasures and European styles such as angels and the North Star. The first floor of Khai Tuong Tower displays six oil paintings depicting the Nguyen Dynasty tombs, which are valuable works of art, while the Cuu Tu Dai Theater was destroyed in 1947. The campus is very large, surrounded by moss-covered yellow walls, creating a luxurious and ancient beauty. This place used to be the setting for famous movies such as Gai Gia Lam Chieu or the MV Khong The Cung Anh Suot Kiep by singer Hoa Minzy, recreating the tragic stories of Queen Nam Phuong. Walking around the palace, every little corner here tells a story, from the exquisite murals to the quiet space, making me feel like I'm lost in a golden age.

Famous as the largest incense village in Hue today, Thuy Xuan incense village is located peacefully on Huyen Tran Cong Chua Street, about 7-8km from the city center, and is also very close to two other famous tourist attractions in Hue, Tu Duc Tomb and Vong Canh Hill. 
With an age of more than 700 years and appearing since the Nguyen Dynasty, Thuy Xuan incense village used to supply incense to the royal court, mandarins and people living around Thuan Hoa and Phu Xuan areas. Through many changes and ups and downs, Thuy Xuan incense village is still there today. Many generations of people have continued to inherit the incense making tradition of their ancestors to create fragrant incense branches, serving the spiritual life of local people and neighboring areas.

During my trip to Hue, I had the opportunity to visit Thuy Xuan Incense Village - a famous and colorful traditional craft village. 

ðŸ‘‰ Space: Colorful bundles of incense are arranged in many eye-catching shapes such as flowers, circles, hearts. The bright colors make the whole space come alive, ideal for sightseeing and taking photos. 

ðŸ‘‰ Experience: Visitors can see the incense making process with their own eyes - from choosing ingredients, drying, dyeing to finishing the product. The villagers are friendly, always ready to chat and introduce the long-standing tradition. 

ðŸ‘‰ Feeling: For me, walking here brings peace like a yoga session for beginners or a yoga session at home. The slowness and meticulousness of the incense making profession reminds me of the spirit of online yoga, online yoga at home, comprehensive yoga for beginners. The Flag Tower (Ká»³ ÄÃ i) is a historic building in Hue, the ancient capital of central Vietnam, and one of the city's symbols.

Overview and Features:

Name: It is also known as Ká»³ ÄÃ i (Flag Stand) or Cá»™t cá» Kinh thÃ nh Huáº¿ (Hue Imperial Palace Flagpole). In English, it is called the Flag Tower.

Location: It is located in the center of the south side of Hue Imperial Palace (Hue Citadel, Great Interior), in front of the Mercury Gate (Ngá» MÃ´n).

History: It was built in 1807 during the reign of Emperor Gia Long (Gia Long), the first emperor of the Nguyen Dynasty, at the same time as the Royal Palace.

Composition:

Base: It consists of a three-tiered, gabled brick base. These three tiers, from top to bottom, represent "Heaven," "Earth," and "Man," and are said to be based on the Confucian idea of â€‹â€‹the Three Principles. The entire base is approximately 17.5 meters tall.

Flagpole: Originally made of wood, it was repeatedly destroyed and damaged by typhoons and war, and the current one was rebuilt in 1948 or 1969 out of reinforced concrete. Including the flagpole, it is approximately 37 meters or 29 meters tall (depending on the source), and can be seen from anywhere in the city.

Function: During the Nguyen Dynasty, a flag was hoisted here to send signals to the Imperial Court during festivals, ceremonies, and emergencies.

Historical Significance: At important turning points in Vietnam's history, particularly its independence from France and the end of the Vietnam War, the Vietnamese flag (a red flag with a yellow star) was hoisted atop the pagoda, making it a symbolic site of these historic moments. The Vietnamese flag still flies there today.
For many tourists visiting Hue, the palace is an important attraction that gives a sense of the city's history along with its majesty.

The flagpole is built in the middle of the South side of Hue Citadel, within the Nam Chanh Fortress. This is considered the place where the royal flag is hung. Hue Flagpole was built along with other structures in the Imperial City in the 6th year of Gia Long, i.e. 1807, and underwent many renovations in 1829, 1831, and 1840. Over time, Hue Flagpole has witnessed many changes of the country. Hue Citadel Flagpole consists of 2 main parts: the flagpole and the flagpole. The flagpole consists of 3 truncated floors stacked on top of each other. The 1st floor is over 5.5m high, the 2nd floor is about 6m high, and the 3rd floor is over 6m high. The total height of the flagpole is 17.5m. On the left of the flagpole, there is a small path to go up. At the top of each floor, there is a 1m railing, decorated with hollow tiles, and there is also a rainwater drainage system.

ðŸ  Introduction

The Hue Imperial City Flagpole (also known as the Hue Ky Dai) is one of the important historical and cultural symbols of the ancient capital. Located right in front of Ngo Mon Gate, the flagpole was built during the reign of King Gia Long in 1807 and was the place where the national flag was hung during important ceremonies of the Nguyen Dynasty.

ðŸ¯ Architecture & Landscape

The flagpole consists of three sturdy brick platforms and a steel pole nearly 37 meters high. Standing here, you can have a panoramic view of the Hue Imperial City, the Perfume River and Truong Tien Bridge in the distance. In the morning or at sunset, the sunlight shines on the red flag with a yellow star fluttering in the sky, creating an extremely majestic and proud scene.

ðŸ“œ Historical Value

The flagpole is not only an architectural work but also a witness to history. During the Nguyen Dynasty and the resistance period, this place was the command point, where the flag was hung to affirm national sovereignty. Today, the flagpole still flies the national flag - the sacred symbol of Vietnam.

ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’¼ Sightseeing experience

Visitors can easily visit when visiting Hue Imperial City. The surrounding area is clean, spacious, and has many beautiful photo angles. In particular, at night, the flagpole area is brightly lit, creating a solemn yet poetic atmosphere.

â­ Conclusion

The Hue Imperial City Flagpole is a sacred, ancient, and proud symbol of the ancient capital. If you come to Hue, you should definitely stop here to feel the historical spirit and the majestic beauty of the heritage land.
Right across from the Hue Royal Palace. You will pass by here on your way to the palace. ðŸ‘

Ky Dai, also known as the flagpole, is an architectural relic and symbol of power during the Nguyen Dynasty. Located in the complex of relics of the Ancient Capital, it is one of the bright spots of tourism in Hue, attracting many domestic and foreign "travelers" to visit every year. Ky Dai was officially built in the 6th year of Gia Long (Dinh Mao year 1807). At first, it was simple, but until the reign of King Minh Mang, it was continuously renovated many times in 1829, 1831 and 1840. At that time, on the occasion of ceremonies, welcoming the tour or urgent reports, Ky Dai had regulations on flag signals. On top of the flagpole, there is also an observation post called Vong Dau, from time to time the guards have to climb up and use the Thien Ly telescope to observe the coast.
Worth to go around the citadel using the tricycle service. And then stop at entrance of inner Palace door to visit the interior

The Hue flagpole (flagpole) was first built by Gia Long in 1807, originally a wooden pole nearly 30m high. Later, Thieu Tri replaced it with a wooden pole 32m high in 1846. In 1904, the flagpole was destroyed by a storm. Thanh Thai had the flagpole recast from a cast iron pipe. In 1947, the French occupied Hue and shot down the flagpole. In 1948, the flagpole was rebuilt from concrete, 37m high. 

Reading before 1945x, the flagpole was used to hang the Ly flag of the Nguyen Dynasty and also served as an observation tower and watchtower. In 1945, Bao Dai abdicated, the red flag with yellow star of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam flew on the Hue flagpole. In 1947, France established the Republic of Vietnam and invited Bao Dai to be the head of state. The flag of the Republic of Vietnam was replaced. In 1968, the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam captured the Flag Tower and replaced the flag for 28 days before the Army of the Republic of Vietnam recaptured it. In 1975, with the victory of the Hue - Da Nang Campaign, the red flag with the yellow star officially flew on the Flag Tower until today.
Beautiful and majestic. Outside has spacious, green space.
Flag Tower

It is a very worth-visiting place when coming to the ancient capital. The space is wide and airy, standing at the foot of the flagpole, you can clearly feel the majesty of the construction associated with the history of the Nguyen Dynasty. At night, the area around the Flag Tower is lit up, creating a sparkling scene, many tourists and locals often come to walk or take pictures. This is not only a historical relic but also an interesting check-in location, easy to combine with a visit to the nearby Imperial City. The experience is both cultural and close to everyday life, very worth stopping by.

After the capital of the last dynasty of Vietnam

Walking through the city of Hue, you can sense its presence from anywhere: this approximately 29-meter-tall flag tower. It feels like a symbol of the city, watching over us from afar.

Originally built from wood in 1807 during the reign of the first Emperor Gia Long, it has since collapsed several times, and the current structure was rebuilt from concrete in 1969 during the Vietnam War. It was heartbreaking to learn that this tower once served as both a lookout post and a gun battery, becoming a fierce battleground between the Viet Cong and US forces. Hearing that the flag was replaced so many times during the Tet Offensive in particular brought the fierce fighting back to mind. Seeing the bullet holes still visible on the walls brought home the tragedy of war.

The approximately 17-meter-tall pedestal is also distinctive, with three levels. The top section represents "heaven," the middle section represents "earth," and the bottom section represents "man," and this is apparently based on the ideas of the Chinese philosopher Xunzi. In addition to this pagoda, there are many other Nguyen Dynasty buildings in Hue that have three-tiered bases, so I'd like to keep an eye out for them when I visit other historical sites in the future.
So beautiful, my feet are tired

**Ky Dai** is a large flagpole located in the middle of the front of Ngo Mon Gate, in the Imperial Citadel of Hue, considered a majestic symbol of the Nguyen Dynasty capital. The project was built in 1807 under the reign of King Gia Long, then restored, enhanced and completed by the reigns of King Minh Mang, Thieu Tri and Dong Khanh. 

Ky Dai consists of two main parts: **flag tower** and **flag pole**. 

* **Flag tower** is rectangular in shape, consisting of three overlapping floors, gradually narrowing from bottom to top, built of solid bricks and stones. Each floor has a walkway and entrance, both for decoration and convenient for management and protection. 

* **Flag pole** is located on the top of the highest floor, made of large ironwood (later replaced by steel), about 37 meters high. On the pole hangs the national flag, during the day it is the yellow flag of the Nguyen Dynasty, currently it is the red flag with a yellow star. 

Historically, **Ky Dai** was not only a place to hang flags to announce events, festivals, or military signals, but also a strategic position to observe the entire Hue Citadel and surrounding areas. During the resistance war, this place witnessed many battles for control of the flag.

Today, Ky Dai is a prominent highlight in the complex of Hue Monuments, often appearing in souvenir photos of tourists, especially sparkling when lit up at night.
